HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
A Superpower Goes Its Own Way, at Its Peril

BYLINE:  By GEOFFREY WHEATCROFT; Geoffrey Wheatcroft's most recent book is "The Controversy of Zion."

 BODY:
ROGUE NATION
American Unilateralism and the Failure of Good Intentions
By Clyde Prestowitz
328 pages. Basic Books. $26.
 Nothing is harder for Americans to understand than the extraordinary complex of responses that the United States evokes today throughout the rest of the world: incomprehension, resentment, admiration, fear, envy and, as one might say, shock and awe. The incomprehension is mutual. Few nations have ever needed more "to see ourselves as others see us," in the phrase, than Americans today. 
 At this astonishing juncture in history, when the United States has demonstrated overwhelming military might and the ability to act as it pleases, Clyde Prestowitz steps back to try to view his country in perspective. Now president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group in Washington, he has had a long and varied career, partly spent outside America, which gives him an advantage most of his compatriots lack. His theme in "Rogue Nation" is American unilateralism, not only in the mainstream of foreign policy but also in various tributuaries. Mr. Prestowitz recites a familar and gloomy litany -- small-arms control, global warming and Kyoto, the International Criminal Court and plenty of other areas where Washington has thwarted international consensus.
There is nothing new about national egoism, after all; great powers have always pursued their own interests. Yet even when they didn't do so in a decorous way, or with what high-minded earlier Americans called a decent respect for the opinions of mankind, older powers necessarily had some regard for the views and interests of other countries. Even at the apogee of British might 100 years ago, when their neighbors often saw the English as perfidious and hypocritical, Britain pretended to pay some attention to those neighbors and tried to retain some of their good will.
The United States, under the Bush administration, Mr. Prestowitz suggests, is quite different, with a disrespect for the opinion of mankind that verges on the indecent. If its attitude toward its foes is Accius' "Oderint dum metuant" -- "Let them hate us so long as they fear us" -- the administration's attitude toward its friends is borrowed from the 19th-century statesman Prince Schwarzenberg: They will be astonished by the magnitude of our ingratitude.
As Mr. Prestowitz perceives, the real trouble with current American policy is not so much that it is unilateral and highhanded as that it doesn't even understand the cynical, older notion of enlightened self-interest. Washington acts on the principle that "they need us more than we need them," a belief that has been encouraged by some of the more simple-minded exponents of globalization as the latest version of the American way. Quite apart from being a little ill mannered, this isn't even true.
That applies in the Middle East, above all in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Although it's often said that only the United States can untie that knot, one could also put it the other way around: unilateral and unaided American power cannot effect a political solution in the Holy Land in the same way that it can achieve an effortless military victory in Mesopotamia.
At the same time, nearly the most significant thing about the Israeli-Palestinian issue is the wedge it is driving between the United States and Europe. Once again there is a great gulf of perception, not least because of the way this story is covered in the news media. If you knew about it only from television in the United States and in Europe, Mr. Prestowitz observes, it might be two completely different stories.
For numerous Americans, Indonesia, Taiwan and Latin America -- all of which Mr. Prestowitz touches on -- are little more than names, though also markets and sources of cheap labor. Mr. Prestowitz is depressed, as he might be, by the ignorance of the outside world found among his countrymen, some of whom seem to echo the English insularity parodied by Nancy Mitford: "Abroad is unutterably bloody and foreigners are fiends."
In reality, as Mr. Prestowitz recognizes, relations between the United States and Europe are now crucially important. Even if Europe doesn't exist as a military factor, it is a fully fledged superpower in global economics. When Europe acts as one body and speaks with one voice -- as it increasingly does in economic matters -- the United States needs to recognize it as an equal, which can't be given orders. The European Union's gross domestic product will soon be more than $9 trillion, twice Japan's. Although the United States is at present still ahead with $10 trillion, it would only take a shift in exchange rates to reverse that.
It is at least possible that the real threat to American dominance may come not from violent Islamism or from the "Japanese challenge" (the subject of Mr. Prestowitz's last book, "Trading Places"), but from an old Europe that has its own economic weapons to hand. No more than a European demand for oil sales to be billed in euros rather than dollars would be needed to put serious pressure on the American currency. 
Writing in a virtuous strain just this side of self-righteousness (itself a venerable American tradition), Mr. Prestowitz says that "we need to rethink American exceptionalism," recognizing that other people's problems "are our problems too and that we don't have all the answers." This is not a popular message in Washington today, but that's where it needs to be heard.

HEADLINE: Newcomer Charges Bosnia Business Barricades 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina 

 BODY:
When Benjamin Herzberg concluded in 2001 that the air had gone out of the Internet bubble, he decided to quit his job at a software company in New York City and follow his wife to another high-wire destination: Bosnia.
 To say that Mr. Herzberg traded Silicon Alley for Sniper Alley does not quite capture his journey: Serbian gunmen no longer menace the main street in Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital. 
 These days, the risk for an ambitious new arrival here is to fail quietly -- to sink without a trace into the quicksand of a country that has soaked up billions of dollars in aid and frustrated foreigners since 1996. 
That almost was his fate. After moving here with his wife, Deborah Isser, the chief of staff for the international community's high representative, he tried his luck at comic book publishing, something he had done earlier in his career. Mr. Herzberg, 33, who grew up in Paris and holds French and Israeli passports, encountered so much red tape that he ended up publishing his comic in France.
As frustrating as it was, that experience has served him well. A few months later, Paddy Ashdown, the high representative, hired him to tackle Bosnia's encrusted rules as an agent of the international community, with the goal of reforming its economy.
Mr. Ashdown, a British politician with an ear for a catchy phrase, had declared in a speech that the only way to sweep away the barriers to business in Bosnia would be to bulldoze them. It fell to Mr. Herzberg to turn Mr. Ashdown's oratorical flourish into a workable program.
Since November 2002, he has devised and led the Bulldozer Initiative, a program of 50 economic reforms to make Bosnia more business-friendly. His goal was to get the changes passed in 150 days, a tight timetable chosen to inject a sense of urgency. 
The last of the reforms was adopted by Bosnia's three Parliaments on May 29, a month later than Mr. Herzberg had hoped, but months -- potentially years -- earlier than otherwise.
"This man has made an idea into a fantastic reality, arguably the biggest success we have achieved in this country," said Mr. Ashdown, who speaks of Mr. Herzberg with the pride of a favored son.
"The beauty of what Benj has done is that he has, for the first time, created the voice of a civil society here," he added. "Businessmen now interface directly with the government."
A scholarly looking fellow, Mr. Herzberg was not the most obvious person to drive Mr. Ashdown's bulldozer. The son of a garment dealer and a social worker, Mr. Herzberg views himself as a businessman.
"I'm not a diplomat," he said. Indeed, he complains that in Bosnia "the regulations are piled on top of each other like some kind of disgusting layer cake."
While he may need to polish his skills as a statesman, Mr. Herzberg has sold the reform agenda to Bosnians by using his considerable skills as a showman -- skills he developed during the hyper-oxygenated days of the Internet, when he was peddling e-commerce solutions.
The Bulldozer Initiative has won praise from local and foreign executives, even those who despair that the country will ever shake off the twin legacies of a civil war and a centrally planned economy.
"It's very important, particularly because it happened so quickly," said Wolfgang Wenzel, director of Volkswagen's assembly plant on the outskirts of Sarajevo. "You've got an old elite here, which is struggling to transform itself from a socialist to a market-oriented economy."
By mobilizing the support of businesses and promoting the campaign relentlessly in the news media, Mr. Herzberg was able to overcome the vested interests and inertia that usually doom such efforts.
The reforms, he noted, were all proposed by local businesspeople, based on the bureaucratic hurdles their companies faced. That made them harder for politicians to resist or to water down.
"Benjamin Herzberg was the first person from the international community to ask us what our problems were," said Tomislav Grizelj, the head of a wastewater treatment company in Sarajevo.
As an exercise in law writing, it was not Jeffersonian. The reforms include such humdrum items as easing a regulation requiring publishers to put bar codes on magazines and newspapers.
To obtain a bar code, publishers had to supply 12 free copies to various national libraries. Under the new rule, they still have to get the code, but no longer have to give away as many copies.
Mr. Herzberg said he avoided more sweeping reforms -- like an overhaul of the tax system -- because they could not be achieved on an accelerated timetable, and because some would conflict with the work of other organizations, like the European Union or the World Bank.
"Some of the businessmen said, 'I pay too many taxes,' " Mr. Herzberg recalled. "We had to be realistic."
Some critics said that by setting its sights low, the Bulldozer Initiative devalued the concept of economic reform.
"Changing a few articles in a commercial regulation is not a reform," said Senad Pecanin, the editor of the weekly magazine Dani. "A reform is changing the constitutional structure."
Others, however, say Bosnia has to start somewhere. And some of the regulations are less trivial than they sound. For half a century, for example, companies that build factories and office buildings have been required to pay a percentage of the construction cost to the city to maintain atomic bomb shelters. Never mind that these shelters were rarely used -- even during the civil war of 1992 to 1995. The money is often diverted to political parties.
"It is completely meaningless," said Stojan Presic, a businessman in the town of Doboj, who proposed eliminating the fee.
Mr. Presic, who built an office for his new trading company, said he would have saved only about $600 if he did not have to pay the tax. But he would not have felt cheated. "Whenever people talk to me about taxes, I feel like my ears are growing, and I'm turning into a donkey," he said.
Now, Mr. Herzberg is preparing for the next set of reforms, which he says must be pushed by the local people themselves. Given Bosnia's dismal record, he concedes that they could easily stall.
"That's a risk," he said. "But we have to allow people to build their own state. We can't just say, 'it will never work.' "

HEADLINE: Wall at Ground Zero 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Wall Once Unseen, Now Revered" (news article, June 23): 
 I disagree with your characterization of the memorialization of the World Trade Center bathtub wall as an act of reverence. 
 By turning the wall into a museum piece, Daniel Libeskind's design for ground zero robs the wall of its ability to perform the very function for which it was built: providing a stable foundation for uniquely giant office towers. Moreover, by refusing to rebuild on the footprints of the twin towers, Mr. Libeskind's design actually weakens the ability of the bathtub wall to hold back the river. 
A truly dignified memorial would focus on the human victims of 9/11 and would be surrounded by a revitalized downtown, not a hole in the ground.

RICHARD JOFFE
New York, June 23, 2003

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Was Higher Than Expected This Month 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence was higher than expected in June, driven by optimism about the economy's prospects six months from now, the Conference Board said yesterday. 
 The Conference Board's consumer confidence index was little changed at 83.5 this month, compared with 83.6 in May. The reading was forecast to fall to 82. 
 A separate gauge in the report measuring the attitudes of consumers about conditions in six months rose to 95.9, the highest since September, from 94.5.
The lowest interest rates in four decades, three months of rising stock prices and $330 billion in tax cuts are reinforcing expectations for faster growth in the second half, economists said. Federal Reserve policy makers are expected to lower their benchmark rate at the conclusion of their two-day meeting today to guarantee the economy strengthens enough to create jobs.
The economy has lost 342,000 jobs over the last six months, and the unemployment rate has risen to 6.1 percent, the highest in more than eight years. The number of people who said jobs are plentiful now fell to 11.4 percent from 12.3 percent in May. That may explain the decline in the index measuring attitudes about the current economy, which fell to 64.9 from 67.3 for the second consecutive monthly drop.
The divergence in the current conditions and expectations index is similar to that after the Persian Gulf war in 1991. In December 1991, the current conditions index fell to 22.5, the lowest since February 1983.
By March 1993, the current conditions index had risen to 42.1. In contrast, the expectations index rose to 100.7 in March 1991 from 55.3 two months earlier.
The Conference Board's report showed the number of people expecting more jobs to become available six months from now rose to 19 percent in June, the highest in a year, from 17.9 percent, while the number of people expecting business conditions to improve rose to 23.9 percent from 22.8 percent a month earlier.
"While postwar euphoria has dissipated, falling gasoline prices, low mortgage rates, impending tax cuts and rising equity markets have buoyed consumers' spirits despite sluggish labor markets," said Steven Wood, principal economist at Insight Economics in Walnut Creek, Calif.
So far, consumers are in no rush to spend. In the next six months, 5.9 percent of Americans surveyed for the Conference Board's report said they planned to buy new cars, down from 7.7 percent last month, and 3 percent said they planned to buy a new home, down from 3.8 percent. 
One reason is that the number of people expecting incomes to rise over the next six months fell to 16.9 percent in June from 17.1 percent in May.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Other Countries Outline Program to Curb Carbon Emissions 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24 

 BODY:
An array of industrialized and developing countries agreed today on the outline of a cooperative research program aimed at capturing and storing carbon dioxide, the main smokestack emission linked to global warming.
 The agreement came halfway through a three-day conference in McLean, Va., organized by the Bush administration, which has argued for more than a year that a technological breakthrough will be needed to stabilize levels of so-called greenhouse gases that trap heat in the atmosphere. 
 A buildup of those gases has been blamed by many scientists for most of a 50-year warming trend that could raise sea levels and disrupt climate patterns if emissions are not reduced. Most industrialized countries have ratified the Kyoto Protocol, a binding treaty that would require reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases. It awaits ratification by Russia to take effect. 
The Bush administration has rejected that approach, saying climate science remains too uncertain to justify mandatory measures. It favors voluntary programs for curbing growth in the gases and long-term research on new nonpolluting energy sources or ways to sop up emissions from the burning of fossil fuels like oil, natural gas and coal.
"Regardless of what target you choose," Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said, "no goal is going to be achieved unless we develop the new technologies to get there."
One justification for pursuing that approach, administration officials and independent experts at the meeting said, is a projection that 90 percent of the increased demand for electricity worldwide in the next half-century will be met by burning fossil fuels. The administration wants to find ways to continue using coal, which remains plentiful and cheap, without adding to the atmosphere's burden of greenhouse gases.
At the meeting, officials from the United States, the European Union, Canada, Australia, Russia, Japan, China, India and several other countries said they planned to sign a charter on Thursday under which they would coordinate research projects on the process, called carbon sequestration.
Energy experts from private environmental groups who attended the conference said that devising such techniques was important, but added that without binding limits on emissions, there would be no impetus for power generators to use modernized equipment.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Little Changed as Investors Await Fed Rate Action

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors made few moves yesterday ahead of a decision on interest rates, leaving blue chips moderately higher and technology stocks narrowly lower in a light trading session. 
 A mixed batch of corporate and economic news, including a sales warning from Advanced Micro Devices and a better-than-expected reading on consumer confidence, gave investors added reason to take a wait-and-see approach. 
 Investors were anticipating that the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee would announce today that it is once again lowering rates to stimulate the economy. Analysts say that expectation has already been factored into the market's rallies over the last few weeks and that investors at this point are more concerned with what the Fed has to say about the economy's health. 
"What are significant are the Fed's comments about what they say they see as far as economic growth and the risk of deflation," said Brian Bush, director of equity research at Stephens Inc. in Little Rock, Ark. "Since the Fed brought up the risk of deflation in their last meeting, I think investors will want to see their assessment as to how real that perceived risk is." 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.90 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 9,109.85. The market's broader gauges were mixed. The Nasdaq composite index fell 5.14 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,605.61. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.81 points, or 0.2 percent, to 983.45. 
Wall Street's primary focus was the Fed, which began a two-day meeting yesterday and will deliver a decision on interest rates today. 
The Fed said last month that the economy was poised to recover in the second half of the year, but also that another cut could be in the offing because of the threat of deflation. In deflationary economies, unemployment worsens and the demand for products slackens. 
"What we are looking for tomorrow is confirmation of what the Fed has already told us," said John Caldwell, chief equity strategist for the McDonald Financial Group, a unit of Cleveland-based KeyCorp. 
If the Fed does reduce borrowing costs, it would be the 13th time it has done so since the beginning of 2001, and it would bring interest rates to their lowest level since the 1950's. 
The Conference Board said yesterday that its consumer confidence index was stable in June, reflecting a more upbeat mood about the economy and the stock market's longer-term prospects even in the face of a still difficult business climate. 
The board, a private research group, reported that the index crept back to 83.5 from a revised 83.6 in May, better than the reading of 82 that analysts had forecast. 
Kroger rose 93 cents, to $16.83, on quarterly profits that were a penny a share higher than Wall Street had predicted. 
BellSouth climbed 47 cents, to $27.49, after announcing it was increasing its quarterly dividend to 23 cents from 21 cents. 
Merrill Lynch advanced 92 cents, to $46.64, after Prudential Securities raised its recommendation on the stock to buy from hold. 
But Advanced Micro Devices fell 28 cents, to $6.31, after cutting its second-quarter sales estimate to $615 million from $715 million. It cited deterioration in the personal computer and handset markets in Asia.

Treasury Prices Soar
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday amid divisions among economists about whether the Federal Reserve would cut its target benchmark rate a quarter-point or a half-point at a monetary policy meeting that ends today.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 19/32, to a price of 103 5/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 3.25 percent from 3.32 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond jumped 17/32, to 116 22/32. The bond's yield dropped to 4.33 percent from 4.40 percent on Monday.

PERSON: Gladys Heldman 

HEADLINE: Gladys Heldman, 81, a Leader In Promoting Womens Tennis 

BYLINE:  By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
Gladys Heldman, an instrumental figure in the formation of women's professional tennis, died Sunday at her home in Sante Fe, N.M. She was 81.
 The Sante Fe Police Department reported that Ms. Heldman died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The police report said she had been experiencing health difficulties. 
 Ms. Heldman, the founder, publisher and editor of World Tennis magazine, began playing tennis at age 25. As an amateur, she was ranked No. 1 in Texas. She competed in the United States National Championships four times and at Wimbledon in 1954.
Off the court, Ms. Heldman was an indomitable force. She started World Tennis magazine in 1953 as a forum for the sport's views and problems. During its early years, the magazine was a one-woman operation, with Ms. Heldman as editor in chief, layout editor, art director and advertising director. She sold the magazine toCBS Publications in 1972.
The magazine helped transform Ms. Heldman into an advocate for women's tennis and one of the most influential people in the game.
In 1970, she used her status to help nine of the top women's players, led by Billie Jean King and Rosie Casals, form their own pro tour.
She arranged for the Houston Racquet Club to sponsor a tournament and had nearly all the players in the group sign $1 contracts with World Tennis to play in the tournament. Heldman persuaded her friend Joseph Cullman, chairman of Philip Morris, to donate prize money and sponsor five tournaments.
Despite suspensions and economic sanctions, the women's pro tour evolved into the Virginia Slims tour.
"Without Gladys, there wouldn't be women's professional tennis," King said in a statement Monday. "When I accepted that $1 contract from Gladys more than 30 years ago, I knew we were all part of something special and that women's tennis had been changed forever because of her vision."
Gladys Medalie Heldman was born May 13, 1922, in New York City. Her father, George Z. Medalie, was a New York lawyer and judge. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Stanford University, she married Julius Heldman, a former United States junior tennis champion, in 1942.
The Heldmans' daughters, Carrie and Julie, were accomplished players; Julie was ranked as high as No. 5 in the world in 1969 and 1974.
Ms. Heldman was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in 1979. She is survived by her husband, her daughters and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: RECONSTRUCTION; 
Crime and Poor Security Hurt Relief Effort in Iraq, U.N. and American Officials Say

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 24 

 BODY:
United Nations and United States officials said today that getting emergency supplies of food, water and medicine to postwar Iraq had proved much more manageable than anticipated, but that rampant crime and lax security were hampering efforts to rebuild the country's damaged infrastructure.
 International officials and delegates convened here today to discuss the reconstruction challenges facing Iraq, to begin appeals for relief and reconstruction aid, and to lay the groundwork for what role other countries, through the United Nations, will play. The meeting came as the United Nations tried to regain its footing and its international standing after the fractious Security Council debates that preceded the American-led invasion of Iraq in March. 
 Reconstruction broadly refers to covering the most basic of human needs that still elude a large portion of Iraq's 24 million people: electricity to charge a light bulb, water to quench a thirst, hospitals to handle a medical emergency, and a classroom in which to educate a child.
Andrew S. Natsios, director of the United States Agency for International Development, said he was pleased with how quickly administrators have been able to move into the reconstruction phase of the occupation and said that "there is a midterm goal of getting the public services -- electricity, water, sanitation -- stood up so that they're functional in the country because so many things are dependent on them."
But, Mr. Natsios noted, "we can't do our work unless there's security." 
He said that security in northern Iraq was relatively good but that Baghdad "is the most problematic at this point."
He laid blame for Baghdad's problems on a cadre of former members of the Hussein government, disgruntled police officers, and former Baath Party members intent on sabotaging security efforts.
Mr. Natsios' views were largely shared by Mark Malloch Brown, head of the United Nations Development Program, which sponsored the meeting today, although he was more cautious in his assessment.
"In any country where 60 percent of the population is dependent on food rations and where urban services are disrupted, you can never really relax on the humanitarian side," he said. "But it's right that one's real focus should be on the reconstruction."
Mr. Brown said Iraq's crime problem was fostered by demobilized Iraqi soldiers without jobs or incomes who have taken to the streets in frustration. He added that a transition from an American occupation to an Iraqi-led government would ease political tension.
"Humanitarian is a hearts business and reconstruction is a minds business," he said. "The importance of today is that there is a turning of the page and a common recognition that moving toward an Iraqi government supported by a functioning, reformed Iraqi economy is what unites the international community."
The United Nations has raised nearly $2 billion for aid to Iraq since March and is appealing for another $259 million for food and medical supplies to meet the country's needs through the end of the year.
According to a draft of a United Nations briefing circulated today at the meeting, one in five Iraqis lives in "chronic poverty." Since the Persian Gulf war of 1991, the report said, about 70 percent of Iraq's water and sanitation services have been seriously impaired.
Congress has allocated $2.4 billion for Iraqi reconstruction, and Mr. Natsios visited the United Nations today to arrange for a needs assessment program for Iraq and to schedule a pledging conference for this fall to raise more money.

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION; 
Impact on Universities Will Range From None to a Lot

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Universities across the country began grappling yesterday with the meaning of Monday's Supreme Court rulings on affirmative action.
 For the University of Michigan, the rulings will definitely mean a revision of its admissions procedures for undergraduates, although what form that will take is unclear. For other campuses, the predictions range from no change in California, where the state Constitution bars universities from taking race into account, to significant change in Texas, where the 1996 Hopwood court decision barring the use of affirmative action is now inoperative. 
 "For us, it's a good thing," said Larry R. Faulkner, president of the University of Texas. 
At most universities, officials said that changes would probably take weeks or months to take shape, but that they would probably be in place by the fall. The court barred mechanical formulas that take race into account, but endorsed the concept of affirmative action.
Mary Sue Coleman, Michigan's president, said that the university would abandon the practice of awarding 20 points to minority applicants that the court had disallowed, and make its process more individualistic and more holistic, as the court directed. 
Dr. Coleman said that the university, which receives about 25,000 applications for 5,000 seats in its freshmen class, reviewed many files individually now, after using a point system as a primary screen. But there will probably be more applications to read under a new system, she said. And while faculty members might take on some of the reading, Michigan is likely to have to expand its admissions staff.
"We may be spending more money -- I know that," Dr. Coleman said in a telephone interview. "But for us, since the court has said 'O.K., here's what you need to do,' we'll gladly do it. The court has laid out the path. I'm just so confident we can do it."
Some universities that admit undergraduates on two paths -- one on pure academic measures and the other by taking race, ethnicity and other student characteristics into account -- were less certain about the changes they might have to make.
Joseph Marshall, dean of enrollment at the University of Massachusetts, said he believed that his campus's limited point system might still be acceptable.
The campus, which received more than 25,000 applications for 5,000 spots in its freshman class, admits two-thirds of its freshmen based strictly on their SAT scores and grade-point averages in high school. But then it applies a point system in admitting the remaining third of the class. Among the categories that earn points are race, military service, coming from a foreign country and athletic or musical ability. 
"Up to this point, I have felt comfortable using this model," Mr. Marshall said yesterday. "And I don't necessarily feel uncomfortable now. I don't know yet whether we will change anything, but I want to get a legal review."
At Ohio State University, which uses a similar model, Mabel Freeman, assistant vice president for undergraduate admissions, said that her office was likely to have to make changes. It admits about 80 percent of its students -- including more than half of its minority students -- based on five academic measures, including class rank, grade-point average and scores on the ACT or SAT. 
In accepting the rest of the class, Ohio State looks at factors like leadership, work experience, community service and a prospective student's contribution to diversity, including economic, racial or geographic. Work experience could add 15 points; being an underrepresented minority brought 25. The cutoff score for admission this year was 139.
"Yes, we do points -- we did do points," Dr. Freeman said yesterday, amending her comments as she spoke. 
"We thought until this week that we were being consistent with Bakke," she said, referring to the Supreme Court's ruling 25 years ago on the use of affirmative action in college admissions. 
Dr. Freeman said that she did not know whether the current approach would work under the court's new rulings, and that she was seeking legal advice so she could be sure the university was in compliance.
At the University of Texas, the Hopwood court decision ended consideration of race or ethnicity in admissions. But a state law passed after that decision gives any students in the top 10 percent of their class the right to attend the university. 
Dr. Faulkner said that with some effort, the university had been able to raise the number of Hispanic and African-American students to about the levels they were before Hopwood or higher, and that he planned to retain those practices. But he said the university could do even better by adding affirmative action.
"We may be able to add the best practices in affirmative action to the best of our race-neutral approaches and come out with an overall package that would be better," he said.
Dr. Faulkner said the court's decision this week would make an even bigger difference to the university's graduate and professional schools, which have seen their minority representation decrease.
"We carry out a holistic review now for a large fraction of our freshmen class applicants and for all of our graduate and professional school applicants," Dr. Faulkner said, "so we have a process that can be modified to include the kinds of considerations that are now permissible under the Supreme Court's decision. We are not talking about a complete revamping of what we do."
One limitation, he added, is that the students entitled to enter under the state's 10 percent rule have become a larger and larger portion of the entering class. This fall, they will account for about three quarters of the class -- up from less than 60 percent a year ago -- and that leaves the university less discretion in filling the class. Dr. Faulkner said he had asked the Legislature to cap the number of entitlement seats to 55 percent or 60 percent of each class.
Another new question for universities this week is how the Supreme Court decisions will affect summer programs and scholarships for minority students.
"Because of the compelling interest in diversity that was stated in the decision, anything one is doing to recruit and attract and mentor minority students should be in line with that compelling interest," said Nancy Cantor, chancellor at the University of Illinois.
Dr. James C. Moeser, chancellor of the University of North Carolina, said he could not answer definitively, but that he, too, was optimistic.
"The court said the government has a compelling interest in promoting diversity in American education," Dr. Moeser said. "This is what we're doing. These minority summer programs are just proactive steps to identify outstanding students and to overcome the barrier that they think Chapel Hill is either inaccessible or unobtainable."

HEADLINE: At a Hearing, Ostrich Plumes And Pleas for Freer Cabarets 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK HEALY

 BODY:
Opponents of New York City's longstanding cabaret laws, some dressed in fishnet stockings and ostrich plumes, spoke at a forum about the laws yesterday evening, carrying signs with slogans like "The Waltz is Illegal in New York City."
 The six-hour hearing at New York Law School was attended by about 190 people, most critical of the laws. It began a process of gathering facts, complaints and suggestions about the 77-year-old laws. The commissioner of consumer affairs, Gretchen Dykstra, who has called the laws outdated, said yesterday that it was too early to say what direction the city would go. 
 Under the laws, clubs, bars and restaurants that offer dancing must have two-year licenses, which cost $600 to $1,000, based on capacity.
The city has 332 licensed cabarets, and has padlocked 11 unlicensed ones this year. From 1999 to 2003, the city closed 20.
Sebastian Holzmeister, who owns the Lunatarium, a club in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, complained at the hearing, "As soon as I have two or more people engaged in a synchronized activity, I have to obtain a cabaret license."
He added, "You should be free to dance; you should be able to move your body."
Eric Demby, of Legalize Dancing NYC, a group that has been lobbying to eliminate the cabaret laws, said that until the laws were changed, the Department of Consumer Affairs should stop enforcing them. "This is an issue that has hampered the culture and economy of New York City." 
Earlier, four panels, made up of representatives of restaurants, the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce and cabarets and clubs along with members of the City Council, debated the laws. The panel discussions often veered from cabarets to talk of the smoking ban, noisy patrons, club security and other issues.
James Capalino, who represents several Manhattan nightclubs, said the discussion foreshadowed broad night-life regulations for bars and clubs. The real issue is not dancing, Mr. Capalino said, but how big and loud a club is and its proximity to residential neighborhoods.
"This administration is going to move in the direction of some sort of legislation of night life," Mr. Capalino said in a panel discussion. "It's almost inevitable that it's going to happen."
David Rabin, president of the New York Nightlife Association, said changing the cabaret laws would have little effect on night life because of zoning and building and fire codes. But Mr. Rabin said he worried that more restrictive laws would further harm already struggling clubs.
"It sounds to me like they're trying to broaden the regulations at exactly the wrong time," he said.
Ms. Dykstra said in a telephone interview before the hearing, "I don't think we've necessarily heard a case for overhauling the cabaret laws."
Few on the panels praised the existing cabaret laws. Norman Siegel, a civil rights lawyer, said the laws restrict the First Amendment rights of dancers and should be scrapped.
Jen Miller, 30, who lives on the Lower East Side and is a member of the Dance Liberation Front, another advocacy group, invoked not the Constitution, but the Declaration of Independence. 
"I'm here as a dancer. And as a citizen I have a right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. And what is the pursuit of happiness if not dancing?"

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Oracle, in Pursuit of PeopleSoft, Relents on Merger

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 

 BODY:
Showing signs that it is serious about its hostile bid for PeopleSoft, Oracle said today that it would drop its objection to PeopleSoft's latest move to acquire J. D. Edwards, a rival maker of business software. Oracle also left open the possibility that it would increase its $6.3 billion bid for PeopleSoft.
 Last week, PeopleSoft increased its bid for J. D. Edwards, which had been a stock-for-stock deal, by offering a combination of stock and cash worth roughly $1.75 billion. That merger offer does not require the approval of PeopleSoft shareholders and has been welcomed by J. D. Edwards executives. 
 Oracle, by dropping its objection to that amended bid, is waiving one of the terms it set out as part of its offer for PeopleSoft, which many in the industry initially viewed as an attempt to interrupt the J. D. Edwards deal. Even so, Oracle's message today was anything but conciliatory.
An Oracle spokesman said the company reluctantly altered its earlier position in hope of coaxing PeopleSoft into discussions. "Although we have provided this waiver, we continue to view the amended merger agreement as an unlawful device to deprive PeopleSoft shareholders of their right to vote with respect to the J. D. Edwards merger," said Jim Finn, an Oracle spokesman. "We hope that with this waiver, PeopleSoft will finally agree to meet with us, as their shareholders are demanding." 
PeopleSoft executives said Oracle's shift in position on the J. D. Edwards deal was irrelevant. "Oracle is just blowing smoke again," said Steve Swasey, a spokesman for PeopleSoft. "Removing the waiver means nothing when Oracle still has pending litigation in Delaware that opposes the PeopleSoft-J. D. Edwards transaction." 
Last week, Oracle sued PeopleSoft in Delaware, arguing that the company was not acting in the best interest of its shareholders and demanding that it rescind its amended offer for J. D. Edwards. 
Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle's chief executive, said today at a conference in London that he had not ruled out the possibility of increasing Oracle's offer. But for now, he said, the company is standing by its offer of $19.50 for each share of PeopleSoft. "Never say never," Mr. Ellison responded when asked if Oracle would raise its bid. But he added, "We think the offer we have on the table is fully valued and very fair." 
Government regulators in several states convened via teleconference today to discuss the impact of an Oracle acquisition of PeopleSoft on consumers in their states. Last week, Connecticut announced that it had filed a lawsuit against Oracle, contending that an Oracle takeover of PeopleSoft would violate the state's antitrust laws and would damage the state's economy.
While it is unclear how many states are actively investigating the proposed merger, the deal is getting a lot of attention because many state governments are PeopleSoft customers. Connecticut, for example, is finishing the first stage of a $100 million installation of PeopleSoft software products in state offices.
"The states are themselves affected purchasers," said Gary Reback, an antitrust lawyer with Carr & Ferrell who is working with PeopleSoft. "Normally, the state attorneys general would just need to find out if their consumers are affected." Mr. Reback said nearly a quarter of PeopleSoft's sales are to the public sector, including many public university systems.
Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, said he was encouraged by the number of states interested in opposing Oracle, though he would not elaborate on which ones may join his state in filing lawsuits. 
Mike Viesca, a spokesman for Greg Abbott, the Texas attorney general, called today's conference call "a first-round routine call" to discuss the states' concerns.
In a separate statement, Mr. Abbott said the state had not taken any legal action to block Oracle's proposed takeover, but that it was watching developments closely. "We take great interest any time a situation threatens competition and puts the customer, whether an individual or government entity, in jeopardy of paying higher prices for a particular product," Mr. Abbott said.
A spokesman for the attorney general of California, where both Oracle and PeopleSoft have their headquarters, said that the office was also monitoring developments. 
PeopleSoft and Oracle may know more about whether the hostile takeover will face regulatory hurdles by Monday, the deadline for the Justice Department to request more information from Oracle about the competitive implications of the proposed acquisition.
A request typically indicates that federal regulators are beginning an investigation into a matter, Mr. Reback said.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL RELA ESTATE; 
Finally, a Ballpark Gets a Neighbor

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex. 

 BODY:
Since 1994, the red-brick stadium that is home to the Texas Rangers has loomed majestically over more than 200 acres of parking lots and vacant land that were part of the development package. But now the ballpark is about to get its first neighbor: a division of Siemens, the German electronics company.
 The $48 million project currently under construction will occupy 14.1 acres and consist of two curved three-story stone and glass buildings, with 180,000 square feet of offices and 70,000 square feet for research and development. 
 The national real estate company Trammell Crow, which is based in Dallas, will own the buildings and lease them to Siemens Dematic Postal Automation, a designer and manufacturer of mail-sorting systems.
The project has prompted more interest than a building of its size usually does because voters in this suburban city midway between Dallas and Fort Worth have been waiting nearly a decade for the ballpark to attract the interest of developers. 
In 1991, voters overwhelmingly approved a half-cent sales-tax increase to finance $135 million of the cost of a new $190 million, 48,000-seat stadium for the Rangers. In promoting the sales-tax referendum, city officials and the previous owners of the team, led by a former oil executive named George W. Bush, said that the stadium would bring economic benefits to Arlington, including commercial development of the area adjacent to the ballpark.
Four years after the stadium opened, the Dallas billionaire Thomas O. Hicks bought the Rangers for $250 million, more than three times the amount Mr. Bush and his partners paid in 1989. The deal included the right to develop 217 acres around the ballpark.
Mr. Hicks's company, the Southwest Sports Group, also has a half-interest in the proposed Victory development next to the American Airlines Center, the new hockey and basketball arena near downtown Dallas, and is trying to develop 65 acres around a minor-league ballpark that it just opened in Frisco, a city of 58,000 just 24 miles north of Dallas. Both the arena and the ballpark received large public subsidies.
Many sports economists are skeptical of whether stadiums ever serve as engines of economic development, but they are particularly dubious of arenas located in suburbs. "If you have a suburban site and surround it with a sea of asphalt, you really militate against economic spillover," said Robert A. Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College who has studied the economic impact of stadiums.
Siemens's broker, Rick Hughes, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield of Texas, acknowledged that it was hard to persuade corporate tenants to move near the ballpark. "One of the biggest issues has been that people see this as a parking lot, not a business park," Mr. Hughes said during a recent tour of the Siemens site. "We've broken the mold."
Siemens has had a presence in Arlington since the 1960's, but needed to modernize its office and research space to continue to attract employees, said Robert B. Mawhirt, president of Siemens Real Estate, which manages more than half of the parent company's real estate assets. He said the company chose the Arlington site for many reasons, including its proximity to Interstate 30, which connects Fort Worth and Dallas, and to Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.
He said the ballpark would be a perk for the company's employees. "Why would a high-tech company want to be near a ballpark?" he said. "Why wouldn't we?"
To keep Siemens from moving to another city, Arlington came up with a $4.5 million package of tax abatements and incentives. "On an incentive basis," Mr. Mawhirt said, "we got a very good offer." Siemens also got Trammell Crow to buy three of its old industrial buildings in Arlington, with a total of 554,000 square feet, said Scott A. Krikorian, an executive vice president for the developer.
Siemens hopes eventually to build another 175,000 square feet of space on a 8.4-acre site at the ballpark, but initially, at least, the company does not expect to add significantly to its current workforce of 600 employees, Mr. Mawhirt said.
As a result of the Siemens deal, said Wes Jury, president of the Arlington Chamber of Commerce, his organization is talking to four other companies about building at the ballpark. "Interest has certainly heightened," he said.
For Arlington, a city of 330,000 where the median family income in 1999 was $56,000, having a major league team -- even one that has been last in its division for three consecutive seasons -- has unquestionably been a source of civic pride. But some people are bitter over the slow pace of development at the ballpark.
C. Bruce Deramus, the chairman of a group called Concerned Taxpayers of Arlington, which says it has 350 members, said the stadium had not delivered on its promises. "You've got your typical ballpark jobs," Mr. Deramus said. "That's all that's developed there now."
Richard Greene, who was the mayor when the referendum passed, said, however, that development near the ballpark was never expected to sprout overnight. "No one ever said that was going to happen in the first 10 years of the ballpark's life," he said. "We didn't build it so that there would be real estate development. We built it to keep the Rangers in Arlington."
Michael Cramer, the president of Southwest Sports, said that Mr. Bush and his partners had not focused their attention on commercial development. "Real estate was not their first priority," he said.
After acquiring the Rangers, Southwest Sports turned to David M. Schwartz, the Washington architect who designed the ballpark, to develop a master plan for the site. But by the time the plan was completed, Mr. Cramer said, the economic boom was nearly over. Another drawback, he said, was that Arlington lacked the type of upscale housing that would draw corporate executives.
Mr. Hicks said he was still hopeful that an "urban streetscape" would one day surround the ballpark. "Siemens, we hope, will be the catalyst of demand," he said. "We kind of view it as a 10-year project. It will kind of create its own life as it goes along."
In the more immediate future, he said, Southwest Sports has higher hopes for its development plans in Frisco, which is right off the Dallas North Tollway in an area that is attracting affluent young families at a rapid pace. In April, Southwest Sports opened the 10,500-seat Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Ballpark in Frisco, where its minor-league team, the RoughRiders, is based. The City of Frisco paid $22.7 million of the ballpark's $28 million cost.
Also designed by Mr. Schwartz, who was the architect of the American Airlines Center in Dallas as well, the new Double-A ballfield is intended as the centerpiece of a mixed-use development that will include offices and condominiums overlooking the ballfield.
Mr. Hicks's company has also invested in Victory, another mixed-use project being developed by Hillwood, a company owned by H. Ross Perot Jr., the son of the former presidential candidate. Hillwood spent more than $100 million to reclaim a 65-acre brownfield site opposite the American Airlines Center, with the intention of building 600 residential units, 550,000 square feet of retail space and 500,000 square feet of office space, said Jonas Woods, the company's president.
It took nearly a year to get the City of Dallas to agree to earmark $43 million in tax-increment financing for the project, in which the city issues bonds to be paid back through taxes generated from rising property values. By then, the Dallas economy had soured, and it was clear that the project was too ambitious to do at once, he said. 
In March, the company's development partner, Related Urban Development of New York, withdrew from the project. "They weren't willing to phase it in," Mr. Woods said, "so we stepped back into the role of developer."
The current office vacancy rate in Dallas is 26.8 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Yet Mr. Woods said he hoped to begin construction by early next year on the first phase, including a 251-room W hotel with 94 condominiums on top, 25,000 square feet of retail space and 50,000 square feet of office space.

HEADLINE: Employees of Baltimore Sun Approve a Labor Contract 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Editorial and business employees of The Baltimore Sun voted last night to accept a four-year contract despite an earlier announcement from their union's bargaining committee that it could not recommend the pact.
 About half an hour before a critical deadline, union members voted 319 to 102 to accept the contract, which goes into effect today with a one-time $1,500 signing bonus and "pay for performance" raises partly replacing across-the-board pay increases for all employees. 
 The contract negotiations were the first to take place in Baltimore since the Tribune Company bought The Sun and other Times Mirror newspapers across the country in 2000. They were closely watched because they came at a time when, with the economy ebbing, Tribune is trying to increase profits and also planning to buy more newspapers and television stations under the federal government's new rules permitting increased cross-ownership of media properties. Tribune's past record with striking newspaper workers is stark; it endured long walkouts at The Chicago Tribune in the 1980's and at The Daily News in New York in the early 1990's. 
Last night's contract approval came at a price. Moments after the vote was counted, union members approved by acclamation a resolution that harshly criticized the Tribune Company for its tactics during the negotiations. "The guild members of The Baltimore Sun accept this contract under bitter protest and condemn Tribune Company for its demeaning and destructive conduct," the resolution, read aloud by union officials, said in part. The company negotiated "in bad faith," the resolution continued, "hiring scabs to replace loyal Sun workers."
Talks had ended at 2 a.m. yesterday and did not resume until 4 p.m. The management of the paper made what it called its final offer about 8:30 p.m. Some aspects of the offer, including the signing bonus, were set to expire at 11:59. Copies of the documents were distributed to 600 members of the Washington-Baltimore Newspaper Guild, meeting at a local theater, for consideration. About 10:30, the union's bargaining committee announced that it could not recommend that other members support the contract, said Candus Thomson, a reporter who attended the meeting.
The tide turned about half an hour before the deadline, largely because union members recognized that management would not make any more concessions. The newspaper had already dropped one of its more contentious demands, that employees could be let go based on skill and ability rather than seniority, earlier in the day. Both sides had reached a tentative agreement on retirement benefits, and the remaining issue -- that of merit raises versus ordinary raises -- remained.
Under the contract, no raises will be given in the first year of the contract. In the second year, all union members will receive the same raise: $24 per week. In the third and fourth years, money for raises will be parceled out in two ways: $10 a week for all employees and $14 to $15 a week for merit pay, to be awarded by newsroom managers.
"We were able to find a way to guarantee wages as well as to create a pay-for-performance plan" to encourage exceptional work, said Linda Geeson, director of marketing and communications for The Sun. She called the talks "a tough negotiation," adding: "Change is always hard. We're very pleased that the union has decided to embrace change and move forward with us."
Even before the vote was cast, Ms. Thomson characterized the proposed contract as a Hobson's choice. "Management has got the gun to our heads," she said. "We looked at what Seattle got, and Detroit, and The Daily News. It's a real grim picture out there."
To some members, the signing bonus represented a windfall that was not likely to come around again. It had been increased this week from $1,000. But others objected to the contract's provisions.
Walter F. Roche, an investigative reporter for The Sun, who is a union member, called the proposal "a terrible contract" and said that despite the raises, the pay outlined in the contract "would leave us way behind."
A federal mediator had been participating in talks between the two sides for three weeks but had been unable to bring the talks to a conclusion.
"They've really ratcheted this up," Ms. Thomson said, referring to the Tribune Company. "We caucused for a while, and then they said there would be no stopping the clock. We asked that the federal mediator be involved to a greater extent, and they said no. The federal mediator also asked to be involved more, and they said no."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Infocus Loss To Widen; Falling Sales Cited 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The InFocus Corporation, the world's largest maker of multimedia projectors, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss would widen from the first quarter as sales declined on lower prices and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome. Sales may fall as much as 15 percent in the period, the company said in a statement. 
InFocus's first-quarter loss swelled to $12.5 million from $7.9 million. Sales fell 8 percent, to $145.1 million. InFocus, whose shares are listed in Oslo after the company bought Proxima of Norway in 2000, said sales were hampered by weak economies, the war in Iraq, SARS and intensifying competition because of oversupply. The company has also been hurt as clients increasingly opt for cheaper products. Shares of InFocus fell 5.2 kroner, or 13 percent, to 35 kroner in Oslo trading. They have dropped 13 percent this year. In Nasdaq trading, shares fell 96 cents, or about 17 percent, to $4.75. Sales were also slowed as Chinese authorities shut down the company's import operation in the country after an investigation. InFocus said it was working with authorities in China and the United States to resolve the matter.

HEADLINE: Russian Economy Builds on 3 Years of Growth 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 24 

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin appears to be off to a strong start on his newly announced capitalist plan to double Russia's economy in a decade.
 In the first five months of this year, Russia's gross domestic product rose 7.1 percent, about double the rate of the comparable period last year. Oil and gas production, the locomotive of modern Russia's economy, is up 11.5 percent. Russia, which exports more oil than any nation except Saudi Arabia, is increasing its oil output this year for the fifth consecutive year. 
 The Russian Central Bank is forecasting a reversal of years of capital flight, with a net capital inflow of $2 billion in the second quarter.
Top government and World Trade Organization officials have predicted to reporters here in recent days that Russia will join the organization next year, joining the world's economic mainstream. The pro-Western shift seems to have considerable public support: in a poll of Russians that was conducted this month by the Public Opinion Foundation, 73 percent of respondents said they wanted to see Russia join the European Union.
Today, Mr. Putin started the first state visit by a Russian leader to Britain since 1874. The visit highlights Britain's having become the largest foreign investor in Russia, with two oil deals announced this year that amount to nearly $17 billion. During his four days in London, Mr. Putin is expected to preside over the signing of documents sealing the petroleum producer BP's investment of $6.75 billion to create Russia's third-largest oil company.
The recent economic numbers follow three years of solid growth, making Russia a confirmed member of a group of three major developing countries that are showing high growth. India is expecting to grow by 5 percent this year, Russia by 5.4 percent and China by 7 percent, as growth in Japan, the United States and Western Europe is expected to be marginal. Partly because of anemic growth opportunities in the world money centers, an influx of foreign capital has made Russia's RTS stock index jump by about one-third so far this year.
But beneath Russia's encouraging numbers, many analysts say, is an overdependence on oil and gas income.
"On first sight, everything is good," Christof H. Ruhl, the World Bank's chief economist in Russia, said in an interview. "But that does not mean that they will double in 10 years. There is a lack of diversification. This high growth is still tied to high oil prices."
With oil and gas sales accounting for about half of exports and about half the national budget, oil and gas contributed to a 23 percent jump in Russia's world trade in the first five months of this year, compared with the similar period in 2002. Because of high oil prices, Russia now exports almost double what it imports.
"The economy remains vulnerable to a downturn of oil prices," Anne O. Krueger, first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said Friday in a news conference here. While saying that Mr. Putin's goal of doubling the economy was realistic, she warned of "excessive regulation and corruption" and its "drag on private sector development." 
James A. Baker III, the Reagan-era secretary of state, expressed similar sentiments in a speech here last week to American and Russian business leaders. "Russia, in short, has come far," he said. "But huge challenges remain. Russia's core manufacturing sector remains in decline, with much of its infrastructure obsolete."
Russia's monopolies often give the country the look of a place where mediocrity is protected. According to research by the Brunswick UBS investment bank, eight conglomerates control 85 percent of Russia's largest 64 privatized companies.
"Despite Putin's reassuring words, the fact of the matter is that Russia's business world, under the surface, is still eyeball-deep in organized crime," The Russia Journal, an English-language daily read by foreigners here, warned last week in an editorial headlined "Killing With Impunity."
Changes in laws have created 40 million landowners. But Russia's farm production remains stagnant, millions of acres of arable land lie fallow, and Russia imports about 40 percent of its food.
While the country's leaders have accepted a central concept of supply economics, that lower tax rates can result in greater tax collection, a huge amount of the economy remains off the books. To encourage Russians to pay their taxes, the nation two years ago adopted a flat income tax of 13 percent.
With lowered taxes and four years of economic growth, Russians now have more money to spend, which has drawn the attention of foreign investors.
As food consumption increases, Tyson Foods Inc., the Arkansas meat producer, is considering buying a Russian poultry farm, and Metro, Germany's largest retailer, plans to invest $1.2 billion here. With Russians using their savings to remodel their Soviet-era apartments, Ikea, the Swedish furniture group, is spending $44 million to build two new furniture stores.
After personal incomes officially expanded by 14 percent last year, the General Electric Corporation set an ambitious goal to increase its Russian sales tenfold, to $3 billion, by 2010. With three million Muscovites owning cars, Goodyear is studying the purchase of a Russian tire manufacturer.
While stuck in traffic jams, Moscow's middle class can study billboards that confirm Moscow has become a standard stop on the world tours of major North American musicians. In large Cyrillic characters, advertisements announce concerts here this month by Julio Iglesias, Elton John, Diana Kroll and Engelbert Humperdinck.
With elections in December to decide control of the Parliament, Mr. Putin is working hard to push the new oil revenues through the state system into the pockets of the people. Unpaid state salaries are being paid up, and in October, 33 percent increases in state salaries are to take effect.
Last week the Duma, the lower house of Parliament, voted to abolish the 5 percent national sales tax and reduced the value-added tax by 10 percent.
With oil revenues high, economists predict that these measures will not knock the government off course in its efforts to reduce inflation to 12 percent, down from 15 percent last year. But the government could crank up public spending this fall to earn good will for the parliamentary elections.
All polls indicate that Mr. Putin will easily win another four-year term next March. But the December parliamentary elections remain a question mark, and the Communists have a chance of once again becoming Russia's dominant party. And Mr. Putin has been able to push through the Duma a series of free market economic changes because he has enjoyed a coalition majority that his predecessor never had.
Will Russia rise to meet the challenge of his 10-year plan? Mr. Putin responded Friday in a nationally televised news conference, "This won't be an easy task for Russia."
Speaking only days after meeting with President Bush in St. Petersburg, Mr. Putin sounded like a Russian Republican. He called for lower taxes, and for a program to "deregulate the economy and get the state out of areas where its presence is not justified and stifles economic activity."

HEADLINE: Voting and Running at Same Time Tests Six Democrats 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24 

 BODY:
Senators John Kerry and Bob Graham took the Senate floor on Friday to sharply criticize the major Medicare bill that is on the table, describing it as insufficient and riddled with gaps in insurance coverage.
 But when the Senate held a succession of votes over the past week to change the bill, those two Democratic presidential contenders and two equally ambitious colleagues, John Edwards and Joseph L. Lieberman, were often missing in action. Mr. Kerry and Mr. Edwards did not vote last week on any of the five initial efforts to alter the Medicare prescription drug plan that will no doubt figure in the presidential campaign. Mr. Graham voted on two and Mr. Lieberman just one. 
 The sporadic voting continued today as Mr. Edwards cast his first votes on the Medicare plan, weighing in on nine amendments. Mr. Lieberman voted once but missed eight other votes; Mr. Kerry and Mr. Graham missed all nine votes. 
The absences illustrate just one of the difficulties of running for president while keeping your day job.
"Occasionally it presents you with some tough choices," said Senator Kerry, of Massachusetts. "But once you have made the commitment to run for president, I think you have got to run."
The six members of Congress seeking the Democratic presidential nomination are finding that juggling legislative duties with a demanding national campaign can wreak havoc on schedules, touch off legislative one-upmanship, send voting records into a tailspin and disrupt sleep.
"I have long days and short nights so I am particularly grateful every week when the Sabbath comes," Mr. Lieberman, of Connecticut, said in telephone interview recently as he made a routine race to the airport, this time to head to a campaign appearance in Oklahoma.
Except for Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, all the Congressional candidates have missed votes. Republicans are keeping tabs and have posted the Democrats' attendance records on the Republican National Committee's Web site.
The committee's most recent count has Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri missing 89 percent of House votes this year as he pursues the White House. In the Senate, Mr. Kerry has missed 41 percent, Mr. Lieberman 26 percent, Mr. Edwards, of North Carolina, 20 percent and Mr. Graham, of Florida, 14 percent. The National Taxpayers Union has asked that the lawmakers return some pay -- $616.33 for each day absent.
It is not always the Congressional responsibilities that suffer; the senators in particular have had to discard carefully arranged campaign schedules on short notice to hurry back to Washington, most recently for tax votes when their presence was crucial in the closely divided Senate.
Mr. Kerry postponed a major health care policy speech to be on hand for one roll call. Aides to Mr. Edwards count at least four times since the start of the year that he canceled campaign events or returned to Washington for votes, including once when he took a hotel room near the Capitol rather than go home in the middle of the night and wake his family.
Though they are trying to set themselves apart, the candidates show some signs of a herd mentality when it comes to Congressional votes. "You don't want to be the only guy to go back," an adviser to one campaign said, "but if one goes back, I think they all go back."
Mr. Gephardt, the former House Democratic leader, has been the least visible of the Washington lawmakers. His spokesman, Erik Smith, said that was because his vote was rarely decisive in the House, where Democrats are significantly outnumbered.
Mr. Kucinich said he made it a point to cast every vote, though he said it often required a frantic mix of flight connections and catnaps as he hopped around the country on long weekends. "I don't think any of my constituents looking for a new job would be able to keep their existing job for too long if they didn't show up for it," Mr. Kucinich said.
The absences on the Medicare votes were glaring because the issue has such a high profile. Two Democratic amendments drew low levels of support that could have been raised by the attendance of the candidates, though their votes would not have changed the outcome.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, who decided against making a presidential bid, conceded that absenteeism could be a concern, but he said no one had yet refused to return for a big vote. And Mr. Daschle said he saw an advantage in having Democratic lawmakers roaming the United States, speaking out on the economy, health care and foreign policy.
"It amplifies our ability to take our message to the country," he said. "Each one of those candidates has his own megaphone. And by and large, our message, regardless of candidate, is similar."
Congress has not been a particularly good platform from which to run for president in recent years, with the "Washington insider" image providing a handy line of attack for opponents. That, however, has not stopped lawmakers from trying.
In 1996, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, left Congress to devote all his time to his candidacy, but that was after he had the Republican nomination nailed down. The Democratic contest is anything but settled, and some current Congressional contenders could be back fulltime early next year if not before.
Until then, the candidates are also trying to use their legislative platforms to aid their presidential drives, which can result in some friction. In mid-May, Mr. Edwards heralded his leadership in opposing offshore oil drilling, a position that has been popular with voters in key presidential states like California and Florida. His office released a letter showing how senators were uniting to fight a provision in the energy bill that they saw as a prelude to a push for new rigs.
Just one problem: Mr. Graham was circulating the letter and his staff was miffed that Mr. Edwards jumped the gun. "It stole a little bit of our thunder," said Paul Anderson, Mr. Graham's spokesman. 
Mike Briggs, a spokesman for Mr. Edwards, said that the letter was released in response to a request by a news organization and that Mr. Graham's office was informed. In the end, Mr. Edwards was not on hand when the disputed provision was upheld in a vote this month. He was campaigning in Tennessee.

HEADLINE: Bush Offers Pakistan Aid, but No F-16's 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: CAMP DAVID, Md., June 24 

 BODY:
President Bush offered Pakistan a tightly conditioned package of $3 billion in aid today, a move that seemed intended to bolster an unsteady ally that only two years ago was still under strict American sanctions for defying the United States by developing its own nuclear weapons program.
 But in a lengthy meeting today with Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, here at the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains, Mr. Bush said he would not provide the F-16 fighters that Pakistan has sought for 14 years. A senior administration official said that Mr. Bush had made clear that the new package of aid was dependent on continued cooperation in battling terrorism and a permanent end to assisting the North Korean nuclear program. 
 General Musharraf, who has publicly denied that his country aided North Korea in building uranium-enrichment facilities, told the president that he understood that any kind of military aid to the North is "a no-go area," the senior official told reporters today.
Much as he hands out visits to his Texas ranch as a badge of alliance solidarity, or a sense of closeness to some allies, Mr. Bush invited General Musharraf for an unusual midweek visit to Camp David as a way of elevating the status of his trip to the United States.
He praised the general, who gained power in a 1999 military takeover, for working "to build a modern Pakistan that is tolerant and prosperous." That praise reflected General Musharraf's decision to align himself with the United States after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Mr. Bush's father suspended all aid to Pakistan in 1990 for refusing to stop its nuclear program.
Now Mr. Bush and his aides seem to regard the nuclear capacity as a fait accompli, and they are again using the lure of aid and trade to help General Musharraf fend off fundamentalists who seek an Islamic state with an Islamic bomb.
So today marked the first time in years that Washington has talked of a long-term aid program for the country, one whose details are still undefined. Administration officials said today that it would require Congressional approval, and that General Musharraf understands that failure to democratize, curb terrorism and stop proliferation would halt aid. "I'm not calling those conditions," a senior administration official told reporters, "but let's be realistic. Three years down the road, if things are going badly in those areas, it's not going to happen."
General Musharraf and Mr. Bush appeared at ease with each other at Camp David today and chatted about their new-found closeness. But in private, Mr. Bush's aides say they are concerned that General Musharraf's promises to democratize Pakistan are moving slowly at best, and that his political support is eroding.
They are concerned about the general's control over his country's nuclear infrastructure -- particularly the Khan Research Laboratory, which appears to be the source of aid to North Korea -- which one senior official said recently could be "weaker than advertised."
"It's the country that worries us the most," one official said in an interview last week, "because it's the only nuclear power in danger of falling into the wrong hands."
Pakistan and India were both subject to severe economic sanctions after they both tested nuclear weapons in 1998. But those sanctions were largely lifted after the Sept. 11 attacks. Now, with the proposal of aid, Mr. Bush has gone in the opposite direction, rewarding Pakistan for its help in pursuing terrorists --including the arrest of more than 500 people both governments say are suspected of links to Al Qaeda and deployment for the first time of the Pakistan Army in the restive border region with Afghanistan.
Officials said that Mr. Bush spoke only in private -- not during their public sessions -- about worries that Pakistan has become a major source of proliferation.
In the past, General Musharraf has denied that his government provided North Korea with the designs for centrifuges to enrich uranium, which American officials suspect has been used to create a second nuclear project. But American intelligence agencies say that the evidence appears solid, and last fall they said that American satellites watched as a Pakistan Air Force aircraft picked up missiles last summer in North Korea. Some officials believe that was payment for the nuclear technology.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has said he has been assured by General Musharraf that all aid to North Korea had ended. But the issue remains enormously sensitive, and one reason to keep even General Musharraf's Pakistan at some distance by refusing, for instance, to deliver the 71 F-16's.
In December 1998, the United States paid Pakistan $325 million for Washington's decision not to deliver the jets. But the issue has never gone away in Islamabad, and Mr. Bush said today, to laughter, that "the president is not afraid to bring up the issue of F-16's -- he has been a strong advocate for the sale of F-16's to Pakistan."
American officials say that any agreement to sell planes would enrage India. The administration also fears giving military aid that could, in a change of government, end up in the wrong hands.
General Musharraf said today that the search for Osama bin Laden continues. Asked if Mr. bin Laden was in the tribal areas of Pakistan bordering Afghanistan, the general said "your guess, sir, is as good as mine." More than a year ago, General Musharraf said during a visit to the White House that he believed Mr. bin Laden was probably dead.
Mr. Bush, asked about both Mr. bin Laden and Saddam Hussein, said "we'll find them, it's a matter of time." He added later, "It could take a day, or it could take a month, it could take years."
