Fox Television to Add HDTV To Prime Time by Fall 2004
The Fox Television Network, which had previously shunned high-definition broadcasting, plans to transmit at least half its prime-time schedule in HDTV beginning in the fall of 2004, said Peter Chernin, the president of the News Corporation.
 The move brings the network in line with its three main broadcast competitors, which already transmit the bulk of their prime-time dramas and comedies in the highest available quality of digital television or will do so soon. Page C5. 

NBC Wants to Form Vivendi Alliance
NBC is planning to join the bidding for the nonmusic entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal but wants to form an alliance with Vivendi rather than buy Vivendi out. C3.

Abercrombie Settles Investigation
Abercrombie & Fitch has agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle an investigation in which California accused it of illegally requiring employees to purchase and wear its apparel. A16.

No Deal Near on Child Tax Credit
Republican Senate leaders said there would be no agreement with the House this month to increase the child tax credit for 6.5 million low-income families. A18.

Investors Await Fed Rate Action
Investors made few moves ahead of a decision on interest rates from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 36.90 points, to 9,109.85, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 1.81 points, to 983.45. The Nasdaq composite index fell 5.14 points, to 1,605.61. C11.

A.M.D. Cuts Forecast for Sales
Shares of Advanced Micro Devices fell 28 cents after the company cut its second-quarter sales forecast by $100 million, to about $615 million. Advanced Micro said sales of PC and cellphone chips this month have missed estimates in Asian markets, including China, as shoppers stayed home to avoid severe acute respiratory syndrome. C5.

Contract Reached at Baltimore Sun
Editorial and business employees of The Baltimore Sun voted to accept a four-year contract despite an earlier announcement from their union's bargaining committee that it could not recommend the pact. It includes a $1,500 signing bonus and merit raises on top of modest annual pay increases. C11.

Official of Stolt-Nielsen Is Charged
Richard Wingfield, who was with Stolt-Nielsen Transportation Group and was manager of the tanker trading division, was charged with price-fixing and bid-rigging by prosecutors in the United States. C15.

Federal Inquiry Into Pediatrix Billing
Shares of the Pediatrix Medical Group fell 24 percent after the company said a federal prosecutor was conducting a civil investigation into its Medicaid billing practices. C2.

Consumers Appear More Optimistic
Consumer confidence was higher than expected in June, driven by optimism about the economy's prospects six months from now, the Conference Board said. C11.

New Neighbors for Texas Rangers
A division of Siemens will occupy two three-story buildings under construction next to the stadium that is home to the Texas Rangers. Commercial Real Estate. C10.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: CALIFORNIA -- ARCHITECTURE; 
There's More than Oil in Downtown Los Angeles

BYLINE:  By Frances Anderton

 BODY:
 First the 1952 Superior Oil building in Los Angeles was turned into the trendy Standard Downtown hotel. Now other postwar downtown office buildings are going residential, thanks to an adaptive-reuse ordinance passed in 1999. 
The Pegasus Apartments, inset top left, opened last week in the former Mobil Oil Corporation building of 1949, by Welton Becket (designer of the Capitol Records building), opposite the Standard. The Kor Realty Group, developer of the Avalon, Maison 140 and Viceroy hotels, is a developer of the Pegasus, which retains features like the vertical aluminum fins on the building and nickel-plated doorknobs. The interior designer of the hotels, Kelly Wearstler, did the restrained Pegasus interiors, above in a model apartment. Rents range from $1,100 a month to $6,500 for a penthouse. 
 Earvin Johnson, the basketball player turned urban developer, above right, is also investing in downtown. Canyon-Johnson Urban Fund, a joint venture with Canyon Capital Realty Advisors, recently bought the 1964 Transamerica Center Tower, designed by William Pereira, another celebrated postwar Los Angeles architect. Transamerica, top right, sat for many years in the underdeveloped South Park area. Now the neighborhood is "the hottest investment opportunity," said Kenneth Lombard, managing partner of Canyon-Johnson. The company expects a residential and commercial mix for the tower and companion low-rise buildings. Development may start this year.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
A Prickly Courtship For Orchestra and Hall

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
The marriage of the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall is showing early signs of strain. That at least was the impression left by separate recent telephone interviews with Zarin Mehta, the executive director of the Philharmonic, and Robert Harth, the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall.
 When the merger made the news on June 2, it seemed a completely top-down policy decision. The plan was worked out secretly and hastily by the boards of the two institutions and was thrust upon their administrators, many saying that they learned of it in The New York Times. Mr. Harth conceded that "the alacrity with which things happened was surprising to everyone." 
 If he was among the surprised, he masked it well during subsequent joint interviews for the news media with Mr. Mehta. They tried to reassure those rattled by the news -- just about everyone in the classical music world -- that Carnegie Hall could accommodate the Philharmonic without significantly compromising its own offerings. The plan's success was all a matter of working out the details, they said.
But more recently Mr. Harth and Mr. Mehta expressed diverging thoughts on some of those details, especially the question of how the hall's weekly schedule will look once the Philharmonic moves in with its roughly 130 concerts a year and extensive rehearsal schedule.
That move would end the orchestra's four-decade residency at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center and return the Philharmonic to the hall where it had played since 1891. 
"People think that we are simply going to graft the current Philharmonic schedule on top of the Carnegie Hall schedule," Mr. Harth said. "The opportunity here is to create a merged institution that is forward-thinking. We are looking at new ways of presentation and new types of scheduling." In economically challenging times "business as usual is not working," he added.
Forward-thinking. Sounds good. Except that the Philharmonic, however splendid an orchestra, has not been forward-thinking since the 1970's, when it took a chance on Pierre Boulez as music director when mainstream concertgoers knew of him as only a thorny serialist composer. It would be great if a major American orchestra embraced Mr. Harth's vision and loosened its commitment to the subscription-series format. Though this conventional way of organizing a season may make it easier to sign up regular concertgoers, it inhibits creative programming.
Rethinking the subscription format is not on the table, Mr. Mehta said. "I don't want change just for the sake of change if something is already working," he said.
He added that just as the New York Philharmonic must fit into the host's season schedule when it travels to the home of the Berlin Philharmonic, orchestras and ensembles visiting Carnegie Hall will have to accommodate the New York Philharmonic's schedule. Mr. Mehta said he was sure there would be adequate available nights and weekend slots. Visiting orchestras "will find a way of coming in when we can get the dates," he said.
"Not that they will get second-rate dates," he added.
Yet with, say, the Vienna Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra and the San Francisco Symphony all competing for three consecutive nights on a weekend in the fall, somebody is going to get either second-rate dates or no slots at all. From Mr. Mehta's description, it sounds as if business as usual will remain the operating mode of the New York Philharmonic. 
Mr. Mehta's ready use of the pronoun "we" raises another question: Who exactly will be in charge of programming at Carnegie Hall? Mr. Mehta said initially that he would tend to the Philharmonic's schedule and that Mr. Harth would attend to everything else. But in his recent interview Mr. Mehta came across as a co-artistic planner for the entire operation. 
"I expect to have a lot of input," Mr. Mehta said. "If this is going to be a merger, we have to hold hands and together do what's best for the art."
He pointed to Carnegie Hall's innovative Perspectives series, in which distinguished artists (Gidon Kremer, Maurizio Pollini, Mitsuko Uchida and James Levine among them) have been invited to plan a series for themselves and other artists and ensembles (orchestras, chamber groups, choruses) and explore a theme or repertory. Once the Philharmonic becomes Carnegie's partner, the orchestra and its individual players will be readily available for the Perspectives series. What if a selected artist is not interested in the Philharmonic? I can imagine powerful institutional pressure coming to bear to include the Philharmonic in some way in every Perspectives series.
Then there is the sensitive issue of Lorin Maazel. Even his ardent defenders would have to concede that during his first season conducting the Philharmonic, this brilliant technician and powerful musician has divided listeners with his penchant for precision-controlled and willful performances. His contract ends with the 2005-6 season. If the merger proceeds, contingent in part on whether Carnegie's backstage office, storage and library space can be expanded adequately, the Philharmonic is ready to move in the fall of 2006. 
Perhaps Mr. Maazel will be the transitional figure that many see him as and step aside when his contract ends and before the move. Then again, maybe his contract will be extended so that he can take the orchestra to its new home. Or will the Philharmonic's administration embrace this merger as a chance to inaugurate a new era with a younger and more innovative music director?
But even if the Philharmonic hired a conductor from my dream list, like David Robertson, Robert Spano, Kent Nagano or some other dynamic musician, and it became the hippest and most forward-thinking orchestra in the United States, its looming presence would still profoundly change the character of Carnegie Hall. 
Back at Lincoln Center, the challenge of filling those Philharmonic dates at Avery Fisher Hall looks formidable. In March the London Symphony Orchestra played three exhilarating all-Berlioz programs under Colin Davis to ecstatic receptions. But suppose Lincoln Center's Great Performers series tried to expand a three-concert appearance like that one into a monthlong residency. Would music lovers in New York turn out for, say, 15 programs by the London Symphony? And for all orchestras, even major ones, international touring has long been a prestige-boosting, good-will-generating and money-losing proposition. Jane S. Moss, the vice president for programming at Lincoln Center, said in a recent interview that in planning the center's future it is "unlikely that we will simply take what we do and quadruple it." There has to be a "comprehensive new vision," she added. More power to her. But she sure has a lot of dates to fill.
This discussion does not even begin to address the raft of issues that lawyers at the Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall are starting to analyze. For example, when the endowments are merged, what happens to gifts restricted by definition to either Carnegie Hall or the Philharmonic? What about the legal entanglements of combining boards? Imagine Harvard and M.I.T. merging. In the world of New York culture, the merger of a storied concert hall and a prestigious orchestra is of comparable significance and complexity.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fall as Sales of New and Existing Homes Climb 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25 

 BODY:
A surprise drop in orders for costly United States-made goods in May damped hopes for a brisk economic recovery, even as home sales soared and the Federal Reserve reduced rates today to give growth an added lift.
 Orders of durable goods fell 0.3 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today. Private economists had forecast a rise of 1 percent. 
 The value of orders tumbled to $168.3 billion, the lowest level since June 2002.
The report on durable goods and positive data on the housing sector were released a few hours before the Fed cut short-term interest rates a quarter-point, to a fresh 45-year low of 1 percent.
Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders of durable goods edged up 0.2 percent, much slower than expected. Excluding military-related products, orders of durable goods rose 0.3 percent.
"This report also reveals that the economy is truly facing considerable headwinds from the manufacturing sector," said Anthony Chan, the chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.
"I think the Fed remains concerned about these headwinds and that's one of the reasons they cut rates," Mr. Chan added.
The gloomy factory news was tempered somewhat by strong housing data.
The Commerce Department said that sales of new single-family homes climbed 12.5 percent in May, to a record annual rate of 1.157 million units.
And the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes jumped 1.2 percent in May, to 5.92 million.
"Housing is the one economic sector that seems to be carrying the day while others struggle, and thank God for that," said Carl Tannenbaum, the chief economist at LaSalle Bank in Chicago. "But how many laps can this particular runner go before it hands off the baton to another runner?"
"These housing numbers are just extraordinarily impressive," said Cary Leahey, a senior economist at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown in New York. "Buying a home is a big vote of confidence in the economy."
The report on durable goods showed broad weakness, with orders falling in categories like cars, communications equipment and machinery.
May was the fourth month in six that overall orders have fallen. In April, orders of durable goods plunged 2.4 percent, revised down from a 2.3 percent drop.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Decline as Fed Eases Rate Less Than Anticipated

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks dropped yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by less than some economists had expected. General Electric and Microsoft led the decline.
 While the central bank reduced its overnight lending rate a quarter point to the lowest in 45 years, some money managers and traders were anticipating a half-point cut. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.13 points, or 0.8 percent, to 975.32, its lowest close since June 3. The Dow Jones industrial average slid 98.32 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,011.53, the lowest since June 9. The Nasdaq composite index declined for a fifth trading day, losing 2.95 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,602.66. 
General Electric, the world's biggest company by market value, lost 67 cents, to $29.26. Microsoft, the No. 1 software maker, shed 44 cents, to $25.26. It has lost 3 percent in the last five days of trading. General Electric is selling its Tokyo-based life insurance unit to the American International Group for about $2.6 billion.
Carnival, the cruise line company, fell after second-quarter profit declined 34 percent as it cut the prices of trips.
Carnival slipped $1.01, to $31. The company reported earnings of 19 cents a share, missing the average analyst estimate of 22 cents, according to Thomson First Call.
Verity plunged $5, to $12.33. Verity, which makes software for Internet search engines, predicted fiscal first-quarter and full-year profit that trailed analysts' expectations. It said slack demand for computer-related products had not improved.
Dupont Photomasks, which makes templates for producing computer chips, dropped $1.14, to $19.43. It said fiscal fourth-quarter revenue would be $80 million, missing the average analyst forecast of $82 million. The company also said its chairman, Peter Kirlin, resigned.
Freddie Mac rose 80 cents, to $50.83. Freddie Mac, the No. 2 mortgage financier, said it would restate its profit for the last three years higher by $1.5 billion to $4.5 billion. The restatement is a result of a change in the way Freddie Mac books profit from its hedges.
Cisco Systems, the world's biggest maker of computer-networking equipment, added 12 cents, to $16.87. Nextel Communications, the wireless carrier, gained 41 cents, to $16.95. Lehman Brothers Holdings included both companies on its annual list of "10 Uncommon Values."
The list has outperformed the S.& P. 500 72 percent of the time since it was first issued in 1949. Amgen, Burlington Resources, Exelon, Harrah's Entertainment, Hewlett- Packard and JetBlue Airways also made the Lehman list.
Banc of America, the biggest United States lender to individual companies, jumped $1.10, to $78.65. The company said it would raise its quarterly dividend 25 percent, to 80 cents a share.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Reuters)
Treasury prices slid lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by just a quarter point, disappointing bond bulls who were betting on a more aggressive easing.
The Fed chopped 0.25 point off its funds rate, taking it to a four-decade low of 1 percent, but the market had been leaning toward a half-point reduction.
The two-year note auctioned yesterday was priced to yield 1.179 percent. By late in the day, the yield had increased to 1.32 percent.
The benchmark 10-year note declined 1 11/32, to a price of 101 26/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, climbed to 3.41 percent from 3.25 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond lost 2 10/32, to 114 13/32. Its yield rose to 4.46 percent from 4.33 percent.

HEADLINE: Fed Statement On Decision To Cut Rate 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, reduced its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 1 percent. In a related action, the Board of Governors approved a 25 basis point reduction in the discount rate, to 2 percent. 
 The committee continues to believe that an accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with still robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing important ongoing support to economic activity. Recent signs point to a firming in spending, markedly improved financial conditions, and labor and product markets that are stabilizing. The economy, nonetheless, has yet to exhibit sustainable growth. With inflationary expectations subdued, the committee judged that a slightly more expansive monetary policy would add further support for an economy which it expects to improve over time. 
The committee perceives that the upside and downside risks to the attainment of sustainable growth for the next few quarters are roughly equal. In contrast, the probability, though minor, of an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation exceeds that of a pickup in inflation from its already low level. On balance, the committee believes that the latter concern is likely to predominate for the foreseeable future. 
Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were Alan Greenspan, chairman; Ben S. Bernanke; Susan S. Bies; J. Alfred Broaddus Jr.; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jack Guynn; Donald L. Kohn; Michael H. Moskow; Mark W. Olson; and Jamie B. Stewart Jr. 
Voting against the action was Robert T. Parry. President Parry preferred a 50 basis point reduction in the target for the federal funds rate. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, St. Louis, Kansas City and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Freddie Mac Understated Pretax Profit 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Freddie Mac, the second-largest financier of mortgages, understated its pretax profits for the last three years by as much as $6.9 billion, in part because it wanted to report those gains in future years, the company said yesterday.
 The errors resulted from complex technical decisions in the way that Freddie Mac accounted for the money it made on its portfolio of mortgages and derivatives as interest rates fell, the company said. Since January, Freddie Mac has been conducting an internal inquiry into those decisions by its managers, and earlier this month, it fired its president, saying he failed to cooperate with that inquiry,and pushed out two other top executives for undisclosed reasons. 
 For the first time, Freddie Mac also acknowledged that it had in some cases deliberately manipulated accounting rules so that its profits would be near Wall Street's forecasts. The company said that the deliberate misstatements had a minor effect, while most of its problems were caused by accidental errors. It did not identify the people responsible for the manipulations. 
"The information we are disclosing today reflects poorly on Freddie Mac's past accounting, control and disclosure practices," said Gregory J. Parseghian, the chief executive. "Management is aggressively addressing these issues."
Freddie Mac also pledged yesterday to provide more information about its performance each quarter and to encourage investors to judge it using standard accounting rules. Those moves threw an uncomfortable spotlight on Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac's larger corporate cousin, which says its performance is best measured using nonstandard accounting.
While Freddie Mac understated its profits last year, some investors and economists contend that Fannie Mae suffered a large loss that it did not have to recognize because of the complexity of accounting rules. Fannie Mae disputes that analysis and says it does not have Freddie Mac's problems.
Yesterday, Freddie Mac rose 80 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $50.83. Fannie Mae fell $1.12, or 1.6 percent, to $67.88.
Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae are government-sponsored but publicly traded companies that are supposed to keep mortgage rates low by connecting investors with banks and other companies that make home loans. Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae buy those loans, then package them into securities, which they sell to investors. The two companies own or guarantee almost half of all United States mortgages, and some economists and competitors complain that because of their size and connection to the government, they are a serious risk to taxpayers.
Representative Richard H. Baker, a Louisiana Republican who has proposed legislation to tighten oversight of the companies, said yesterday that the size of Freddie Mac's restatement "underscores the importance of what has been previously observed by many -- that current regulatory oversight is not adequate." But the companies have enjoyed strong support in Congress, where they are viewed as making housing more affordable.
To correct the earlier inaccuracies in its reports, Freddie Mac will restate its earnings higher for 2002, 2001 and 2000, the company said yesterday. The effect will be to lower Freddie Mac's reported profits in the future, although it will probably not cause the company to become unprofitable. Freddie Mac has said repeatedly, and emphasized again yesterday, that the restatement has no impact on the actual results of its business last year, and simply affects when the profits it made in 2002 are reported. 
Freddie Mac also said yesterday that it would substantially change the way it reports its results. In the future, it will encourage investors to judge its results under standard accounting rules, rather than a nonstandard accounting measure that had previously been its principal gauge of profit and loss. That change will increase the volatility of Freddie Mac's reported earnings.
Since January, Freddie Mac has been examining its accounting for the last three years at the behest of PricewaterhouseCoopers, its new auditor. PricewaterhouseCoopers replaced Arthur Andersen as Freddie Mac's accountant last year.
On June 6, Freddie Mac fired its president, David W. Glenn, and forced out both its chief executive, Leland C. Brendsel, and its chief financial officer, Vaughn A. Clarke.
Martin F. Baumann, Freddie Mac's new chief financial officer, said its books had been "an accounting mess with a lot of accounting errors." He said the company had hired more accountants and given them more authority to examine its books.
The company will add $1.5 billion to $4.5 billion to its reported earnings, Mr. Baumann said. Almost all of that adjustment will be recorded for its last three annual statements, with a small adjustment to its earlier reports. On a pretax basis, the restatement will be $2.3 billion to $6.9 billion.
In addition to restating its earnings, Freddie Mac said it would provide some information that Fannie Mae, its competitor, now does not. Freddie Mac will report each quarter its fair market balance sheet, a measure that some investors and economists say they believe is the best overall measure of performance for financial institutions, including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Fair value balance sheets give investors the market prices of all of a company's assets and debts, including its derivative positions. The difference between assets and debts is the company's equity, which belongs to shareholders.
Supporters of fair value say that financial companies have a very high ratio of debt to equity, making their long-term health very vulnerable to changes in interest rates that may not have an obvious short-term impact. Still, some banks and insurance companies have resisted providing fair value balance sheets, arguing that it can be misleading.
Mr. Baumann said the fair value balance sheet is one of the most important measures of the company's health.
"We manage ourselves largely on that basis," he said. "One of the key things we look at is growing the fair value of our shareholders' equity, quarter after quarter."
Fannie Mae provides a fair value balance sheet only once a year. Last year, Fannie Mae's balance sheet showed that the company was only marginally profitable, while it reported earnings of $6.4 billion under the nonstandard accounting measure that it favors.
Chuck Greener, a spokesman for Fannie Mae, said Fannie Mae would not promise to provide its fair value balance sheet each quarter, although he said the company would consider doing so if investors requested it.
"We do not have the problems that Freddie Mac has, and therefore the solutions they have proposed for their business do not pertain to Fannie Mae."

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Lowers Key Rate To 1%, Lowest Level Since 1958 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25 

 BODY:
Trying to bring the long economic downturn to a halt at last, the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates by a quarter of a point today, taking them to their lowest level since 1958.
 To the disappointment of the stock and bond markets, the Fed rejected a half-point cut and explained in a statement that the economy appeared to be improving but could still benefit from easier credit. 
 "Recent signs point to a firming in spending, markedly improved financial conditions, and labor and product markets that are stabilizing," the Fed's statement read. "The economy, nonetheless, has yet to exhibit sustainable growth."
In a sign of how radically the Fed has changed its focus over the last three years, officials also said that concerns about price declines, rather than inflation, were "likely to predominate for the foreseeable future." The statement, economists said, signaled that the Fed, while still viewing the risk of deflation as minor, planned to keep interest rates low for an extended period. 
Stocks and bonds fell after the midafternoon announcement, with the Standard & Poor's 500 index closing at 975.32, down 8.13 points. 
The fall in the Fed's benchmark rate, to 1 percent from 1.25 percent, will quickly reduce rates on many business, home equity and credit card loans, as well as the return on money market funds. Mortgage rates, which are set by the market, are unlikely to change significantly, economists said, because investors had expected the Fed to act.
Retirees and other people who rely on fixed investments for income will take an effective pay cut. But the overall decline in borrowing costs for households and companies is likely to help the economy, analysts said.
Reflecting the recent debate within the Fed over how much help the economy needs, Robert T. Parry, president of the San Francisco Fed, voted against his 11 colleagues on the rate-setting committee and favored a half-point cut. The committee's decisions are usually unanimous; before today, Mr. Parry last dissented in 1989. 
The Fed has cut rates 13 times since the beginning of 2001, first in a failed effort to prevent a recession and more recently in hopes of halting a period of slow growth and persistent layoffs. But the hangover from the 1990's boom, combined with wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and a series of corporate scandals, has caused the worst hiring slump in 20 years and the longest one since the period before World War II. 
Most worrisome to Fed officials, a continuation of the downturn would increase the likelihood of deflation, a sustained decline in prices that could cause wages to fall and debts to become effectively larger. While reiterating that they consider the risk small, officials said today that the chance of "an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation exceeds that of a pickup in inflation from its already low level."
The economy has recently shown signs of improvement, like increases in manufacturing activity and retail sales, which appear to have pushed the Fed toward the smaller rate cut. A recently passed tax cut, the already low level of interest rates and this year's decline in the dollar, which helps American companies compete with foreign rivals, have also caused most economists to predict a rebound in coming months.
"There's just a lot of stimulus in the pipeline already," said James O'Sullivan, an economist at UBS Warburg. "So it's very reasonable to think that growth is going to be stronger in the second half of the year."
But most forecasters and Fed officials have been predicting a return to healthy growth since early last year, only to be surprised by the depth of the problems created by the bubble in stocks and business spending, particularly on technology. A further decline in interest rates will not necessarily cause companies to build factories or buy more equipment, some economists say.
"We've got a world awash in excess supply," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley and one of the first analysts to discuss deflation as a serious possibility. "Companies don't want to exacerbate the imbalance."
In other economic news today, the Commerce Department reported that the decline in orders for durable goods -- large, expensive items often bought by companies -- fell 0.3 percent in May, after a steeper decline of 2.4 percent from March to April.
Having studied Japan's descent into deflation and a decade-long slump, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and other officials have come to believe that central banks should act aggressively in a bubble's aftermath, according to their recent speeches. This belief has led them over the last two and a half years to make mostly half-point rate cuts, rather than the quarter-point reductions that were common during the early 1990's downturn.
But the Fed apparently decided this time that the combination of a long slump and recent reasons for optimism, including a nearly 20 percent rise in stocks since March, argued for the more gradual move. 
"The Fed does expect stronger economic growth," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo Bank in Minneapolis, "but they are not as sure of it as the stock market."
Some Fed officials are also worried that interest rates below 1 percent could damage the nation's financial markets and the ability of companies to borrow. Americans now hold more than $1 trillion in money market funds, and much of that filters through the commercial paper market to finance corporate investments.
Many of these funds, though, have expenses that are too high to allow them to operate profitably when rates fall near zero. With the Fed's benchmark rate now at 1 percent, only 3 percent of assets in the funds fall into this category. At 0.75 percent, 15 percent of them would, according to iMoneyNet, a research company based in Westborough, Mass.
If the economy remains weak and the Fed's rate falls to 0.5 percent, almost 40 percent of fund assets would face this problem, and the money market industry might begin to shrink. 
Interest rates on many savings and checking accounts have recently fallen in anticipation of Fed action, according to BankRate.com, another research company. But the Fed's suggestion that rates will remain low could cause them to drop further.
"If anybody is still earning interest on a checking account, they probably won't be next week," said Peter G. Crane, a vice president at iMoneyNet.
By implying that it will not raise rates for months to come, the Fed seems poised to create the longest period of extremely low borrowing costs since World War II. Interest rates fell sharply during the Depression and remained low during World War II by order of the government, which needed to borrow to pay for the fighting, said Richard Sylla, an economics professor at New York University.
The executive branch gave the Fed more independence in 1951, allowing it to set short-term rates in reaction to the business cycle. With rates already low, recessions in 1953-54 and 1957-58 each caused rates to fall briefly below 1 percent.
But as inflation began to rise in the late 1960's and exceeded 10 percent in the 70's and 80's, the Fed -- particularly under Paul A. Volcker, the chairman from 1979 to 1987 -- repeatedly increased rates to reduce economic demand and keep prices more stable. 
Now the bigger threat appears to be deflation, and it is aggravated by economic growth in Japan and Germany that is even slower than it is in the United States.
"This is a new regime for the Fed," Mr. O'Sullivan of UBS Warburg said, referring to officials' focus on keeping prices up rather than down. "It is a big change from the last 20 years."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Do workers really make hay while the sun shines, or just clock out sooner?

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University and a co-editor of The Journal of the European Economic Association. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
A CORE tenet of supply-side economics is that people will work more if their take-home pay rate rises. 
 Support for this proposition has proved surprisingly difficult to find, however, especially in regard to men. 
 Studies of annual hours worked among individuals turn up a wide range of estimates of the effects, but typically indicate that work hours are only weakly associated with pay. To the extent there is a consensus among economists -- and there is more than the usual amount of disagreement here -- it is that a 10 percent rise in wages leads to less than a 1 percent increase in work hours for men and a 3 percent increase for women. 
With such small responses, tax cuts clearly will not pay forthemselves. 
Why is the supply of labor so unresponsive to pay? Two theoretical effects work in opposite directions. On the one hand, workers substitute more hours at work for time spent in leisure if the wage rate rises, as leisure time has become relatively more expensive. This is known as the substitution effect. On the other hand, if workers are paid more, they like to use their extra income to consume more of the things they enjoy, including leisure time. This is known as the income effect. The income and substitution effects roughly offset each other. 
Another factor is that many employers dictate the number of hours employees must work, so they cannot work more or fewer hours if they want to. And, of course, in a weak economy unemployment prevents some people from working at all. 
Still, in certain situations, a sizable supply response is expected. Obviously, workers must have the flexibility to adjust their hours. In addition, if wage increases are known to be temporary, the substitution effect will loom large, and the income effect will be insignificant because lifetime income is hardly affected. 
For example, if pay is expected to be exceptionally high on Thursday, and Thursday only, then workers should work extra-long hours on Thursday; they can rest on Friday. Thus, "intertemporal substitution" of work effort across days should occur in response to transitory wage changes. 
Nevertheless, most studies of transitory wage changes have found only limited evidence of such behavior. 
In a 1997 study, Colin Camerer of the California Institute of Technology and three colleagues posed a novel explanation for this anomaly: maybe many workers are "target income" earners. That is, workers have in mind a target for what they want to earn on a given day, and once they reach that level they go home. So a higher wage would cause some workers to quit earlier rather than work harder, because they would achieve their target income faster. 
To test this view, they collected data on taxi drivers in New York City. On days when fares per hour worked were higher -- for example, if waiting time between trips was low because of a convention -- they found that the average cabdriver worked less, not more. This looked like stunning support for the target-income model, and a rejection of the intertemporal substitution model.
For drivers with a lot of experience, however, they found that work effort increased on especially profitable days, suggesting that workers learn over time.
Now their findings are being debated. First, Gerald S. Oettinger of the University of Texas at Austin published a paper in the Journal of Political Economy on the daily work decisions of food and beverage vendors at a major-league baseball stadium. The vendors were independent contractors, required to work until the seventh inning, but they could choose which games to work. Vendors make more when the number of fans is high and the number of other vendors is low. Professor Oettinger found that vendors were more likely to go to work when the expected payoff was higher -- for example, on days when a larger crowd was expected because of a pivotal game or a quality opponent. The decision of whether to work at all on a high-payoff day -- as opposed to how much to work -- was not considered in the cabdriver study. 
Then, an actual experiment was conducted by Ernst Fehr and Lorenz Gotte, two economists at the University of Zurich. They persuaded Flash Delivery Services, a bicycle messenger company in Zurich, to raise the commission rate paid per delivery by 25 percent duringa preannounced four-week window for a randomly chosen half of its work force in September 2000, and for the other half two months later. The researchers found that messengers worked 20 percent more shifts when their commission rate was raised, although they put forth somewhat less effort per shift, as measured by the number of deliveries. Over the month when pay was elevated, total work effort was higher, consistent with the notion of intertemporal substitution of work for leisure.
And most recently, my Princeton colleague Henry S. Farber revisited the question of cabdrivers, studying a different set of drivers. He found that cabdrivers quit after they work a lot of hours and grow weary. How much they have earned to that point has little or nothing to do with their decision. Moreover, the amount the drivers earn varies substantially from day to day, suggesting that their target income levels, if they have them, fluctuate wildly. He suggests that the earlier findings possibly resulted from reporting errors in the data: because daily wages were derived by dividing total revenue by hours worked, any mistake in reported hours would cause a mistake in the opposite direction in the calculated wage, inducing a negative correlation between wages and hours worked. 
So where does this leave us? Perhaps most important, a distinction must be drawn between permanent and transitory changes in pay. For long-term changes -- like the decline in fares cabdrivers saw after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, discouraged tourists from visiting New York -- Professor Farber says he would not be surprised if drivers actually worked more hours to make up, in part, for lost income. 
There is little reason to believe recently enacted tax cuts will increase work effort if they are perceived as permanent. In fact, if the tax cuts are repealed, work effort will probably increase before the repeal takes effect, at least among those with flexible schedules and much experience.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 3, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about the connection between an increase in pay and the number of hours worked, misidentified the delivery service that participated in an experiment conducted by two economists at the University of Zurich. It was Veloblitz of Zurich; Flash Delivery Services provided some data.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Higher Spending Seen on Campaigns

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
In another indication that the advertising economy is improving, TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending, revised upward its forecast for this year.
 The new forecast for 2003, made on Tuesday, is for a gain of 4.3 percent compared with spending in 2002, up from a prediction in January of a 3.3 percent increase. 
 Steven J. Fredericks, the president and chief executive of TNS Media, in New York, said the revised estimate reflected factors like higher-than-expected spending in the first quarter, continued growth of advertising on Spanish-language television and record-breaking commitments by advertisers to buy television commercials ahead of the 2003-4 season.
Other forecasters have recently adjusted their predictions for this year. Last week, for instance, the dean of Madison Avenue forecasters, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann in New York, decreased his prediction of growth to 4.6 percent from 5 percent, and David Doft, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, increased his growth estimate to 3.3 percent from 3.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Broadway Joe Wants a West Side Stadium

BYLINE:  By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
IN rejoining the Jets as their ambassador at large, Joe Namath returned to the site of his New York baptism. Beyond a wide window in the Renaissance New York Hotel, noontime traffic moved through Times Square, the same but now different background used for the memorable Sports Illustrated cover heralding his rookie season in 1965 as a $427,000 quarterback.
 "I felt like the biggest jerk in town that night," he was saying now. "Here were all those people going to the theater and I was standing down there in my Jets jersey and shoulder pads. I really felt like a dork." 
 But that cover photo labeled him. Shortly after the Jets opened their training camp that summer in Peekskill, N.Y., Namath glanced across the locker room to where the late Sherman Plunkett, one of pro football's first 300-pound offensive tackles, was staring at that cover.
"'Broadway,"' Namath remembered Plunkett saying. "'Broadway Joe.' That's the reason I love that man. That cover turned out to be one of the most important things I ever did."
He has been Broadway Joe ever since, but when he led the 1968 Jets to their Super Bowl III upset of the Baltimore Colts, he was really East Side Joe. That's where his Bachelors III restaurant was. That's where his apartment with the white llama rug was. That's where the girls were.
Yesterday the only girls with Joe Namath were his daughters: 17-year-old Jessica and 12-year-old Olivia. But with his thick mane and hunched shoulders, Namath, at age 60, is on the Jets' roster again. The front-office roster.
His primary job will be to drum up support for the proposed West Side stadium that would allow the Jets to return to New York from Giants Stadium in New Jersey. That could be a tougher job than playing quarterback. He can't just drill a pass through the political defense: a weak economy and a mayoral policy that is cutting the school budget and closing firehouses.
Then again, most of the pro football world didn't think that his Jets team, a 17-point underdog, could beat the Colts. But he guaranteed it, and the Jets fulfilled his guarantee, 16-7.
It's unfair to ask Namath to guarantee a West Side stadium. He's not the quarterback this time. Robert Wood Johnson IV, known as Woody, the Jets' multimillionaire owner, is the quarterback. Namath is merely the backup, but he still speaks as confidently as he did the week before that Super Bowl.
"I'll be meeting with sponsors, with fans," he said. "We're trying to get the New York community to get behind Mr. Johnson's vision. We want to bring our team back here. Home. To New York City."
Namath was careful not to insult Giants Stadium, where the Jets have played since the 1984 season after leaving Shea Stadium, but he understands why the Jets want their own stadium.
"You don't feel the same playing in another team's stadium," he said. "I know the players would feel better playing in their own stadium. We are the Jets -- the New York Jets."
Namath's role with the Jets is connected to a coming line of Broadway Joe sports clothing. The overall value of his contract, as negotiated by his longtime agent, Jimmy Walsh, is whispered to be in the same neighborhood as his original $427,000 deal, then the most expensive in pro football history. But he proved to be a bargain.
In announcing Namath's return at a news conference, the Jets surrounded him with several of his Super Bowl teammates: Don Maynard, Winston Hill, John Schmitt, Bill Mathis, Dave Herman, Larry Grantham, Johnny Sample, Randy Beverly and Jeff Richardson, along with such later Jets as Freeman McNeil, Richard Caster, Greg Buttle and Ken Schroy.
"And there's Dr. Jim Nicholas," Namath said, glancing at the Jets' orthopedic surgeon for more than three decades. "He gave me my first physical in the restroom at Toots Shor's restaurant after he told me, 'I hear you have a bad knee."'
Namath would have his first knee operation the next day, but in an upstairs room at Shor's at an informal gathering for sportswriters to meet the Jets' rookie, one of the reporters asked him: "Just suppose, Joe, just suppose you don't make it, what happens with all the money you got? Just suppose, Joe, just suppose you don't make it."
Without raising his voice, without any braggadicio, Joe Namath looked at the reporter and said, "I'll make it."
Now his job is to help make the West Side stadium a reality. If he does, he'll deserve to be known as West Side Joe.

HEADLINE: BOXING; 
Heavyweight Dreams

BYLINE:  By GEOFFREY GRAY

 BODY:
Michael Rothberger works the night shift driving a truck for a fruit company in the Bronx and fights for $100 a round. He sleeps during the day, when he can, in his apartment or, in tougher times, in the back of his Chevy Blazer parked in the street because bad luck does not seem to change when you wake up in the dark.
 But tonight, in a comeback-from-nowhere four-rounder at the nightclub Jimmy's Bronx Cafe, a journeyman's ring misfortunes will change, he says. If not then, then never. 
 Rothberger, a stocky heavyweight who goes by the self-imposed nickname Shake and Bake, has lost his first four professional fights. The last three bouts ended in the first round, all by technical knockouts. If Rothberger loses one more time, the New York State Athletic Commission will revoke his license again. For good. 
Rothberger is matched against Mike Kelly, an airport supervisor from Philadelphia who will be making his professional debut.
"I've been given a second chance, and I'm fighting to win," Rothberger said last week before a workout at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn, a stint in which he sparred in the ring for the first time in a year. "I have to win, no question about it."
In the last five years, Rothberger, who is from Brooklyn, became one of only four fighters to be suspended by the state for poor performances, an action the state commission takes to prevent injuries or dives. The other three fighters who were suspended were has-beens, taking too many fights late in their careers. Rothberger is alone, the only fighter in the sport's recent history in New York to have been suspended at the beginning of his career.
Of the state's estimated 300 licensed fighters, Rothberger, who turns 31 next month, is also one of the many part-time pugs who often challenge rising talents, and their own better judgment, for paydays that have not really changed much in more than 20 years. On the East Coast, for instance, the standard payment for a journeyman is still $400 for a four-round fight and $600 for six; in states like Mississippi, the pay can be as little as $75 a round. 
Sometimes expenses are covered. Sometimes they are not.
"The public doesn't buy into fighting itself anymore," the local promoter Sal Musumeci, who is putting on tonight's card, said. "If the public was interested in the competitiveness of the bouts, in the sport, then purses for four-round fighters would go up." Inflation in boxing, he says, only touches the sport's silk-pajama champions, with their cable-television contracts. 
Last weekend, for instance, a tubby Lennox Lewis earned more than $7 million for 18 slumbering minutes of action in his title defense against Vitali Klitschko. When Lewis fought Mike Tyson last year, both earned more than $30 million. 
For journeymen, whom all champions at some point must pass and punish to pad their records, transportation to bouts is rarely covered. State laws mandate that promoters provide fighters with medical insurance, but only on the night of a fight. But injuries can linger.
After one of Rothberger's fights, when he was shattered by the heavy-hittingprospect Dominick Guinn (22-0 with 17 knockouts), stitches under his eye cost Rothberger $380. The promoter would not pay the bill, he said, and after paying his manager, his cut man, and losing, again, in one round, Rothberger said he was in the hole for more than $100. 
"It's horrible, the pay is peanuts, but what are you gonna do?" Rothberger said.
In the past, there have been efforts to organize fighters, and nearly all have failed. The reason, boxing insiders said, is the sport's lack of structure.
"The world of boxing is like a world of amorphous Jell-O," the cigar-chomping fight historian Bert Sugar said. "Who are fighters going to take on? The promoters? The matchmakers? ESPN? There's no single force to rally against."
Still, some try. At a news conference last month at Bally's Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, the two-month-old Joint Association of Boxers (JAB) announced an affiliation with the Teamsters union. Together, they look to offer pensions, medical coverage and collective bargaining; to date, they claim to have signed about 150 fighters. 
But for the moment, JAB still has not figured out how the union will work, and many fighters -- especially journeymen like Rothberger -- are wary of dividing their purses among more people. When the former world champion Eddie Mustafa-Muhammad, JAB's president, went to Gleason's earlier this month looking for recruits, he dropped off a stack of union cards, said hello to a few friends, then left after 15 minutes. 
"It's going to take a little more then that to help fighters," said Bruce Silverglade, who has been running Gleason's for more than 20 years. He has come across fighters with detached retinas, broken hands and the flu who would try everything they could to trick the commission's doctors into letting them fight for short money.
Silverglade's sober gaze extends to Rothberger, whom, he thinks, is lying to himself about his abilities.
"He simply doesn't have what it takes to be a fighter," Silverglade said.
Rothberger disagrees. "It's just been a little rough in the beginning, and unfair," he said. In his last fight, for instance, his trainer never showed up. A pudgy 252 pounds that night, Rothberger stepped into the ring and was on his knees after about a minute, and a wrenching punch to the stomach sent his mouth guard rolling around the canvas like a car's loose hubcap. Rothberger, with glassy eyes, was on his feet before the count of 10, but he watched the referee stop the fight, then left the ring to a chorus of obscenities.
"I need the money," Rothberger said minutes later, alone again, in a makeshift locker room at Club Amazura, an old fight hall turned nightclub near Kennedy International Airport in Queens. "I don't want to fight, the ring is the worst place in the world. But listen to me. I'll be back. You'll see. I'm just a late bloomer. All my life I've been a late bloomer. Give me a month. I'll be back."
That fight was two years ago. Rothberger has not fought since. The commission suspended his license shortly after. He pursued acting, but that business is tough, too, he said, and callbacks have been rare. Then things got worse. He split up with his longtime girlfriend. His mother died. He said that rather than pay the Jewish cemetery on Long Island to maintain the grave he went to Home Depot, spent $80 on rocks and grass, and did the job himself.
And now he will get in a ring again, 25 pounds lighter than in his previous fight.
"I read Mike the riot act," Ron Scott Stevens, the state boxing commissioner, said. "He's borderline. This is his one last opportunity."
A week ago, when Rothberger was back in the ring at Gleason's, he was wearing sneakers as he sparred. He had come straight from work, had not had time to fetch his boxing shoes and had not slept in more than 18 hours. But for a zombie, his movements were surprisingly fluid, even speedy.
After the session, Rothberger was optimistic. He had received two callbacks for an acting job, one that required him to get a Mohawk haircut. For his comeback, he did not have a game plan, he said, because when the bell rings for the first time you forget everything. You simply have to fight. 
Win or lose, he is expected back at work after the bout to drive his fruit truck through the night. He plans to be there. "Why not?" he said. "Where else am I going to go?"

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Pettitte Gives the Yankees Enough to Gain a Victory

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 25 

 BODY:
It is as if the Yankees' starters have an unspoken understanding. Since the last game Antonio Osuna pitched, on June 13, the Yankees have had no dependable right-handed setup man. In order to win, the starters have to work at least seven innings. In 8 of the 10 games since then, the starter has done that.
 The Yankees traded today for the Cleveland Indians right-hander Dan Miceli, who is a journeyman but is also an improvement over the rest of their right-handed relievers. Miceli was flying from Cleveland to Tampa tonight, so the rule stood: the starter had to go seven. Andy Pettitte was up to it. 
 Pettitte did not dazzle. He gave up 10 hits and 5 runs to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. But he economized on his pitches and worked into the eighth inning, helping the Yankees to an 8-5 victory at Tropicana Field. 
Chris Hammond pitched out of trouble in the eighth inning, and Mariano Rivera earned his 11th save in the ninth.
Pettitte has given the Yankees consistency in June, helping them to a 14-7 record despite the weakness in the bullpen. He has lasted at least seven innings in four of his five starts in June, walking just six in 30 innings. That was a marked contrast to his opponents tonight.
The Devil Rays issued 12 walks, something they had never done in their forgettable six-year history. Starter Rob Bell walked four, reliever Al Levine walked three -- consecutively -- and Jesus Colome walked five in two innings. 
The Yankees took what they were given and scored eight runs. It was easy to forget that they left the bases loaded three times.
"It's always a battle when the game seems to be dragging on," Pettitte said. "But you never complain about the runs."
There was nothing crisp about the game. The Yankees made two errors and had three fewer hits than the Devil Rays. In addition to their 12 walks, the Devil Rays had a passed ball and a wild pitch and hit a batter.
It was almost as if the artificial turf had turned into a mud pit, with the teams slogging back and forth until one finally fell. For the Yankees, it was important to win that kind of game, especially against a bad team.
"It's harder to get up the intensity when they're dragging on," said Jason Giambi, who added that he felt fine after being hit above the knee by a 95-mile-an-hour fastball from Colome. "You really need to separate yourself and say, 'Hey, we really need to win this game and not get caught up in it."'
Pettitte kept his focus, tiring in the eighth after a long top of the inning. Manager Joe Torre acknowledged that he would not have asked Pettitte to pitch the eighth if he had more confidence in the bullpen. "But we're not going to push the envelope, pitchwise," Torre said.
That was not an issue for Pettitte, who threw a reasonable 107 pitches. Pettitte walked one hitter tonight and has not walked more than three hitters in any start this season, which is crucial to the way he pitches.
"The last couple of years, I've been throwing a lot of strikes," Pettitte said. "I feel like I've been able to put the ball where I want to. I'm going to give up some hits, so I really try to just watch my walks."
Lou Piniella, the Tampa Bay manager, is famous for his contempt of the base on balls. Before the game, the Devil Rays demoted Tuesday's starter, Dewon Brazelton, to Class A after he walked four of nine hitters. 
Piniella yanked Bell quickly today, and he is growing frustrated.
"What do we have -- 20 walks the last two games?" Piniella said. "It's tough to win that way, isn't it?"
The Yankees were bound to have an easy time with Bell, a starter they have feasted on in the past. In three career starts against the Yankees for the Texas Rangers, Bell had an 11.85 earned run average and had allowed 26 hits in 13 2/3 innings. He had also allowed 10 home runs.
The Yankees received a second chance at Bell tonight, and Torre wrote out a starting lineup with a combined average of .514 (19 for 37) and seven home runs against Bell. History repeated itself.
Bell gave up seven runs, the last two being charged to him on bases-loaded walks by Levine. He did hold the Yankees without a homer, but long doubles by Hideki Matsui and Robin Ventura drove in three runs.
Ventura's double came in a five-run fourth, which put the Yankees ahead, 7-3. Pettitte kept the lead, and his focus, in a mostly forgettable game.

INSIDE PITCH
Center fielder BERNIE WILLIAMS, who had surgery to repair torn knee cartilage May 27, took batting practice with the Yankees before the game Wednesday night. He could return before the All-Star Game break.

HEADLINE: Finally, a Public Resting Place for History's Motherboards 

BYLINE:  By TOM McNICHOL

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. 

 BODY:
AT the new headquarters of the Computer History Museum in Silicon Valley, the ghosts of technologies past still roam the grounds. 
 One unoccupied room still contains dozens of worker cubicles left behind by the building's former occupant, Silicon Graphics, a computer workstation maker hit hard by the technology downturn. The empty purple cubicles mark out a kind of museum-within-a-museum, a place where the recent past suddenly turned into history. Out in the parking lot, the paint that once marked reserved spaces has all but faded, and neighboring office buildings sport a sign of the hard times: "Sublease Available." 
 Surrounded by the lessons of history, the Computer History Museum is moving forward at a considerably slower pace than Internet speed. Beginning this month, the museum is offering the first chance for the public to view some of the 5,000 computer artifacts in its new home. Over the next several years, the museum will expand in three phases, gradually assuming its mission to "preserve and present for posterity the artifacts and stories of the information age."
The slow rollout is mainly a result of the moribund state of the technology sector, which has slowed donations to a trickle. To date the nonprofit museum has raised about $54 million in pledges ($25 million of which have been collected), with little movement over the last year toward its goal of $100 million. "The fund-raising is harder than ever," said John Toole, the museum's executive director and chief executive. "But it really helps having a building, something real to show people."
The museum traces its roots to the Computer Museum in Boston, which was founded in 1979 by Gordon Bell, a longtime engineer and executive at the Digital Equipment Corporation, and his wife, Gwen. A spinoff history center in Silicon Valley was established in 1996; four years later, half of the Boston collection moved west. Since 2000, the artifacts have been stored at Moffett Field, also the home of the NASA Ames Research Center, about a mile from the museum's new headquarters. 
The Computer History Museum is still a work in progress. Of the museum's 10,000 images and 4,000 linear feet of computer documentation, most have yet to be digitized for online access, a conspicuous delay for a museum honoring the digital age. Recent visitors to the museum's Web site (www.computerhistory.org) often encountered pages filled with nothing but computer code, a glitch that certainly says something about computer history, but probably not what museum officials hope to convey.
The technology slump, however, has cut both ways for the museum. Depressed commercial real estate prices enabled it to buy its new headquarters at a discount. The building, which measures 119,000 square feet and was built expressly for its former tenant, is only nine years old. (The museum scrapped a plan to build its own space at Moffett Field when it bought the building.) 
"Silicon Graphics was building a museum in 1994 -- they just didn't know it at the time," Mr. Toole said, smiling.
The slack economy has also enabled the museum to tap some technology luminaries who are no longer quite so busy. A member of the museum's board, Donna Dubinsky, co-founder and chief executive of the hand-held-device maker Handspring, says she plans to devote more time to fund-raising for the museum once Handspring's recently announced sale to Palm is completed.
"This is an opportunity to collect and archive computer artifacts for future generations," Ms. Dubinsky said. "This stuff is lost if we don't get it now."
The museum's Visible Storage exhibit showcases about 500 of the collection's most notable artifacts. Among them is an imposing nine-foot-tall metal rack crammed with vacuum tubes and colored wires, a small portion of a 1945 Eniac, the world's first electronic digital computer. The complete Eniac filled an entire room, weighed 30 tons and could store about 200 bytes (compared with 16 million bytes on today's typical PC). 
Sitting inconspicuously on a shelf is an Apple-1, the 1976 machine that helped set off the personal computing revolution. The Apple-1 was a few mouse clicks shy of being user-friendly: for $666.66, buyers received a circuit board, a bag of parts and an assembly manual, and had to supply their own case, keyboard and monitor.
Most of the collection has been assembled through donations; the museum gets about 10 calls a week from people seeking to unload old hardware. More often than not, it has to decline computers that are too common or already in the collection. (Please, no more I.B.M. PC Jr.'s or Commodore 64's.)
Other computers have slipped into history so quickly that the museum has had difficulty acquiring them before they became expensive collector's items. Lately museum officials have taken to calling computer makers and asking them to donate their current models, before they become obsolete. Mr. Toole said that some hardware makersare unnerved by the idea that their latest device is a museum-piece-in-waiting.
"Some of them say, 'My God, we're not history yet!"' Mr. Toole said.

Fossil Expedition
Where Dinosaurs Command Respect
The Computer History Museum's exhibition of about 500 computer artifacts, Visible Storage, is open by appointment for docent-led tours every Wednesday and Friday at 1 p.m., and the first and third Saturdays of each month at 1 and 2 p.m. There is no charge. Reservations can be made by phone at (650)810-1013 or by e-mail to tours@computerhistory.org.
The museum is at 1401 North Shoreline Boulevard in Mountain View, about 35 miles south of downtown San Francisco. The main phone number is (650)810-1010. More information about the museum is available at www.computerhistory.org.

(Photographs by Kim Kulish for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Economy Slows Growth Across Canada

BYLINE: By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 25 

 BODY:
Canada's economy is growing more slowly than expected, but the government will balance its budget anyway, Finance Minister John Manley said today in a speech to a business group here.
 Contrasting the fiscal health of his country with the swelling budget deficit in the United States, Mr. Manley said that Canada now expected gross domestic product to grow by 2.2 percent this year after adjusting for inflation, down from the 3.2 percent forecast in February. 
 Mr. Manley said that two factors were holding Canada back. One was an unexpectedly sluggish economy in the United States. The second involved the recent outbreaks of two headline-making diseases: severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in people; and bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, in cattle. SARS has dented tourism and retail sales, while mad cow disease has halted beef exports. 
 ''All of these issues add up to one simple fact,'' Mr. Manley said. ''At the midpoint of 2003, we face a challenging economic environment.'' 
 Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., said, ''At the end of the day, the single most important variable factor for Canada is what happens to the U.S. economy.'' 
 The United States is by far Canada's most important trading partner, taking about 85 percent of Canadian exports. Suppliers of automotive products, lumber and steel, among other exports, have been hit this year by slack demand south of the border, as well as by a steep appreciation of the Canadian dollar, making Canadian exports cost more abroad.
 Mr. Manley said the impact of slowing growth on the national budget would be offset partly by ''contingency'' and ''economic prudence'' reserves. Such reserves have become a regular feature of the government's budget planning; 4 billion Canadian dollars ($3 billion) are available in the budget for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2004, and 5 billion ($3.7 billion) in the next year. 
 Mr. Manley said the effect of high oil and natural gas prices on energy companies' profits, and on the taxes they pay, would provide some cushion, as would low interest rates, which hold down debt-service costs. 
 Mr. Manley is one of three politicians vying to succeed Prime Minister Jean Chrtien as leader of the ruling Liberal Party. The new party leader will be chosen at a convention in Toronto in November, though Mr. Chrtien has said he intends to remain prime minister until February. So far the front-runner is Paul Martin, who preceded Mr. Manley as finance minister. 
 Mr. Martin oversaw a transformation in the federal government's finances, from persistent budget deficits to an unbroken run of surpluses starting in 1997. The surpluses have been used to reduce the national debt, which has fallen to less than 44 percent of gross domestic product this year from 68 percent in 1995. 
 Citing measures like an increase in unemployment insurance premiums and an income tax surcharge for wealthy taxpayers that were adopted in the 1990's, Paul Darby, the chief economist at the Conference Board of Canada, said, ''We're starting from a more prudent underlying structure than the United States.'' Since the start of the Bush administration, the United States budget has moved from surplus back into deep deficit, with a shortfall of $300 billion to $400 billion expected for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. 
 The slowing of Canadian economic growth has prompted speculation among analysts that the Bank of Canada will soon cut interest rates. In recent years, the gap between Canadian and American rates has widened as the Federal Reserve has cut rates while the Bank of Canada has raised them to head off inflation. 
 The Bank of Canada's governor, David Dodge, said last week that recent setbacks to the economy pointed to a ''very weak'' second quarter and ''some continuing softness'' in the third. The bank is scheduled to announce on July 15 whether it will follow the Fed's rate cut today with one of its own.

HEADLINE: A Winery Profits as India Adapts to New Tastes 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: NASIK, India 

 BODY:
Educated in Silicon Valley but seduced by Sonoma Valley, Rajeev Samant decided to come home to these dry hills northeast of Bombay to try making wine in India, a nation where annual wine consumption works out to one teaspoon per person. 
 Six years after planting his first cuttings of sauvignon blanc from France and chenin blanc from California, Mr. Samant has a big problem: "We keep running out of wine." 
 Although wine featured in the Kama Sutra, the ancient Indian erotic classic, wine drinking has not been part of modern mainstream Hindu culture. For one thing, India's traditionally hot and spicy foods tend to overwhelm the subtle flavors of most wines. 
But Mr. Samant's Sula Vineyards is a runaway success, doubling its output each year since 2000 and still not keeping up with demand.
"Last year, our three main wines were out of the market for three months," Mr. Samant, a 36-year-old Stanford University engineering graduate, said at his winery's red-roofed Mediterranean-style headquarters. Nearby, workers labored on additions that will quadruple Sula's capacity to 159,000 gallons a year by January.
Sula's success speaks to two factors transforming India's economy: globalization and the cutting of red tape. These new forces are contributing to India's projected economic growth this year of 5 percent, a peppy rate after years of slumber. 
With 20 million Indians studying or working overseas, this formerly inward-looking nation is increasingly open to new ways of doing things -- though many of the old strictures still survive, including a ban on advertising alcoholic beverages. 
Mr. Samant uses other kinds of marketing to draw attention to his wines, including sponsoring fashion shows in Bombay, where "Bollywood," the Indian mass-audience film industry, is based; wine tastings in Delhi, the political center; and dot-com parties in Bangalore, the center of the rapidly expanding technology industry. 
"We had hundreds of yuppies tasting our wine," Mr. Samant, a former executive at the Oracle Corporation, said of the Bangalore parties. "Yahoo and Merrill Lynch were our sponsors." 
The trend Mr. Samant is riding is a fast-growing taste for wine among affluent young Indians. "A lot of young women, from 22 and up, are very much into wine, something you never used to see a few years ago in this country, which is quite socially conservative," he said. "It is more acceptable for a woman to be seen holding a glass of white wine than a glass of whiskey or spirits." 
Nasik is India's wine capital, and the vineyards spreading over the red-earth hills around the town are evidence of progress in removing official obstacles to enterprise. 
When he started, "it took us two years to get the winery license," Mr. Samant said. "Today it takes one month." 
Four wineries have opened in Nasik in the last year, and the state government of Maharashtra has 40 more letters of intent for winery projects. The state's first wine festival is scheduled for August. Remarkably, all this is taking place in a state governed by a party usually regarded as Hindu nationalist -- in other words, opposed to foreign influences. 
In the decade since Mr. Samant started experimenting here, the price of irrigated land has risen twentyfold to one million rupees ($21,500) an acre. With hot days, cool nights and soil that drains well, these mildly sloping hills are producing wines with a "new world" flavor, according to Terry Damskey, a California winemaker who is Mr. Samant's partner and adviser. 
"Raj is riding something that is going to be very successful, the way the Californian winemakers did a generation ago," Mr. Damskey, who visits Nasik regularly, said in a telephone interview from his home in Geyserville, Calif.
Analysts expect Indian wine consumption to grow 20 percent a year through 2007, echoing a trend seen among the emerging middle class in China, another rapidly developing country without a strong wine tradition. Indian consumption is expected to reach 550,000 cases this year, about 8 percent of it supplied by Sula Vineyards. 
In a country with few corkscrews, much of Sula's work is educational. For example, along with the usual suggestion that merlot be served at room temperature, Sula's brochures add that this "refers to European climates, not Indian!"
"I have been to wine shops where they keep the bottle vertical, standing on a shelf, in the sun," said Pradeep S. Pachpatil, Sula's winery manager, as he offered two visitors a taste of Sula's sauvignon blanc.
Last April, the Indian Express newspaper called this wine "the most refined Indian white -- dry and refreshingly crisp, with just a hint of its spicy antecedents." 
India's winemaking boom comes during a nationwide push to adjust the economy to the requirements of membership in the World Trade Organization, which India joined in January 1995 with a promise to lower a number of trade barriers gradually. For example, import duties on wine, now as high as 250 percent, are due to fall to 100 percent by 2006. 
Even with such high duties, imports account for 40 percent of the Indian wine market, in part because vineyards like Sula struggle to keep their wines to world standards without the benefit of a well-developed domestic network of suppliers and support businesses. 
"Our corks come from Portugal," said Ajoy Shaw, Sula's winemaker, as he walked past stacks of empty clear-glass bottles imported from France. "For the sparkling wine, we order the wire holders from Spain and the gold foils from Luxembourg." 
To prepare for more competition from imported wines, Mr. Samant has been working to build brand awareness among India's middle and upper-middle classes, who can afford to pay $9 to $15 for a bottle of his wine in restaurants. Though they represent a small percentage of the national population, he said, "1 percent of a billion is 10 million," and their numbers are growing rapidly. 
After a favorable review last autumn in Wine Spectator, the influential magazine, Mr. Samant shipped some Sula wine to Italy and to San Francisco. He does not need export orders now and would have trouble filling them if he got many, but he said that a "foreign stamp of approval" was valuable publicity at home.
"When you don't have a big wine culture, people are not that confident of their instincts about wine," he said, adding that an Indian newspaper article about Sula wine being offered in some French restaurants in San Francisco can have a big impact. 
"Getting accepted and acclaimed in California means a lot for me," he said. "Ultimately, for a winemaker, psychic rewards are very important. It is not all financial."
