HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lehman Is in Talks to Buy Money Management Firm
Lehman Brothers is negotiating to buy Neuberger Berman, a money management firm, for more than $3 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the deal said.
 An official announcement is not expected this week. Lehman has been looking for acquisitions to add a less-cyclical element to its businesses. Page C2. 

Tax Burden of the Richest Declines
The 400 wealthiest taxpayers accounted for more than 1 percent of all the income in the United States in 2000, more than double their share just eight years earlier, according to new data from the Internal Revenue Service. But their tax burden plummeted. A1.

Trading Unit Lifts Goldman Sachs
The Goldman Sachs Group reported a 23 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings, propelled by another robust period of trading profit, which set it apart from other big Wall Street firms. Goldman earned $695 million, or $1.36 a share, results that were above the estimates of analysts. C7.

U.S. Expected to Sue Enron Officials
The Labor Department is expected to sue about 20 officials of Enron and its retirement plan today, contending that they breached their fiduciary duty to protect Enron employees from the huge losses they incurred when the company's stock collapsed. C5.

Regulators Deny California Request
Federal energy regulators rejected a request by California to void more than $12 billion in high-priced energy contracts signed at the height of the state's electricity crisis. A20.

G.E. to Sell Japanese Insurance Unit
The American International Group plans to pay about $2.6 billion for the Japanese life insurance business of General Electric and for G.E.'s small auto and home insurance business in the United States. C2.

F.T.C. Allows Ice Cream Merger
The Federal Trade Commission agreed to allow Nestle to proceed with the $2.8 billion merger of its United States ice cream business with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream. The two companies agreed to sell some assets. C7.

Effort to Fight Online Music Piracy
The record industry intensified its efforts to combat online piracy, announcing that it plans to sue individual computer users who share substantial amounts of music online. C4.

Netflix Wins Patent for Business
Netflix, the leader in the online DVD marketplace, was granted a patent that covers many of the basic features of its business. C4.

Sony Under Pressure to Cut Costs
There are signs that Sony, which has long prided itself on its commanding position atop the high end of the consumer electronics market, may be slipping from its perch. Moody's Investors Service lowered the long-term credit rating of Sony by one notch in recognition that the company, led by Nobuyuki Idei, above, is under growing pressure to cut prices and costs. World Business, Section W.

Medicare Bills May Come Up Short
Elderly people who have spent years waiting for a Medicare prescription drug benefit may be disappointed by the bills widely expected to pass the House and Senate this week. A1.

Ex-Rite Aid Officials to Plead Guilty
The last two defendants in the Rite Aid accounting scandal, the former vice chairman, Franklin C. Brown, and a vice president, Eric S. Sorkin, have each agreed to plead guilty to one count of conspiracy. C6.

Why Tax Cuts Will Not Pay Off
Supply-side economics says people will work more if their take-home pay rises. They do, but only slightly, which means that tax cuts will clearly not pay for themselves. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

PUB-DATE: June 27, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 4672 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"BEALS, HERVEY AND HEWITT: WOMEN PIONEERS OF ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN PHOTOGRAPHY," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through July 13). Three female photographers, saluted for their successes in early-20th-century New York. The artistic oddball was Antoinette Bryant Hervey (1857-1945), who carried out an obsessive 40-year photographic documentation of the construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and produced an epic of great artistry as well as historical value. Greenwich Village was the stamping ground of Jessie Tarbox Beals (1870-1942), the best known of the three, who engagingly turned her lens on Village haunts, architecture and personalities. Mattie Edwards Hewitt (circa 1870-1956) did homes and gardens designed for the era's rich and famous, like Conde Nast and Margaret Bourke-White. Although this mix is a little forced, individually each woman is worth a salute. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century, Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window, and a post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures. These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it." Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

* "GREAT WAVES: CHINESE THEMES IN THE ARTS OF KOREA AND JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 21). Basically a collection reinstallation with a novel mix-and-match approach, this show, spread over both the Chinese painting and Japanese galleries, traces the flow of influence from one culture to the other. Most of the action takes place in the Chinese galleries, where the art is arranged by motifs -- seascapes, landscapes, floral images -- that emerged early in China and circulated to Korea and Japan. The model proposed will provide grist for many scholarly mills in the future; the show itself is tremendous fun to look at. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7.) The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received both a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes and Leonardo da Vinci meet. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art, University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Oct. 6). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Elie Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small, truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources place them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Smith).

"NOGUCHI -- THE BOLLINGEN JOURNEY: PHOTOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS, 1949-1956," Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum (temporary space), 36-01 43rd Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 204-7088 (through Oct. 13). More than 100 photographs and drawings re-create Noguchi's travels from 1949 to 1956, on a grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The project was for an ambitious book (never completed) on the spaces and structures -- religious, monumental, classical and communal -- of familiar as well as less-documented societies. Besides providing an elegant travelogue, the photographs give some idea of the many sources that Noguchi drew on for his work. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Glueck)

* "THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF CHARLES SHEELER," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). This majestic progression of 90 vintage prints will cause some ripples in the big familiar pond of American modernism, within which Sheeler is known foremost as one of the chief instigators of Precisionist painting. But his most profound, original response to Cubism came through the camera, in tautly composed photographs of Pennsylvania farmhouses and barns, New York skyscrapers and Ford's River Rouge factory. Their confident fusion of abstraction and fact, reverence and scrutiny, puts them among the most radical art of their time; and they are an important precursor, at least in spirit, to both Pop and Minimalism. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 31). This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Smith).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 1). From 1964 to 1966, Warhol shot 500 short, silent, black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing some 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag -- but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposed the mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* "WHISTLER, WOMEN AND FASHION," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 13). A dandy, a wit and a social butterfly who cultivated his image as a star aesthete, James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) had a lifelong interest in fashion and women's clothes. This show honors the centenary of the painter's death by exploring his intense, unabashed involvement with fashion. He obsessed over what his female sitters wore, choosing the clothes they posed in and in some cases actually designing them himself. For Mrs. Frances Leyland, the fashionable subject of one of his most smashing pictures, "Symphony in Flesh Color and Pink" (done between 1871-1874), he created an elegant, loose-fitting tea gown of diaphanous pink chiffon worn over a white underdress. The display includes many major images of women in their finery and several magnificent gowns of the Whistler period along with smaller oils, drawings, pastel studies, costume designs, prints and watercolors, and relevant 19th-century fashion plates. It's a fitting tribute to a bravura brush. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

"PUERTO RICAN LIGHT: JENNIFER ALLORA AND GUILLERMO CALZADILLA," Americas Society Gallery, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through July 20). Ms. Allora and Mr. Calzadilla are young conceptual artist-collaborators who divide their time between Puerto Rico and New York, and this show brings both places together. The centerpiece is a 1965 fluorescent sculpture by Dan Flavin titled "Puerto Rican Light (to Jeanie Blake)," which derives its illuminating power from solar energy gathered in San Juan and stored in batteries in the gallery (Cotter).

ALES VESELY, "Infinite Point," Carosso Fine Art, 42 East 76th Street, (212) 744-5400 (through July 30). Mr. Vesely, a Czech sculptor, thinks in monumental terms. His materials are nature-made boulders and even mountains, combined with structures of steel. Fortunately, he's a strong draftsman, drawing his projects -- built or unbuilt -- with such flair that even in their two-dimensionality they have a vivid presence. Most impressive, among the projects rendered here, are drawings for "Mountain of Mountains," a sheer-sided peak rising from a "sculptural landscape" of desert rocks and mesas, and serving perhaps as a site for reflection on the balance between human and cosmic (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

"MARIKO MORI: WAVE U.F.O.," atrium at 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through July 31). Of late, this Japanese artist, whose past work blended science fiction, fashion and esoteric Buddhism, has been designing interactive spiritual hardware, and this podlike container is her most ambitious piece so far. It accommodates three electrode-wired participants at a time, who are treated to a son-et-lumiere projection of their brain waves, followed by an eye-rinsing aurora borealis of Ms. Mori's devising. The high-tech work is fun while it lasts and must have cost someone a fortune to produce (Cotter).

DON NICE, "Paintings on Anodized Aluminum," Babcock, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 767-1852 (through Aug. 5). Since the 1980's Mr. Nice's primary format has been the totemic arrangement of images -- mostly flora and fauna and now abstract passages, too -- in cut-out structures around a central theme. Here, the theme is almost always a bright, sunny landscape quickly observed, and surrounded by a heraldic framework that includes, along with abstract passages, stereotypical images of birds, fish, flowers and animals, representing the elements of air, earth, fire and water. A departure is that he has adopted anodized aluminum for his support rather than canvas or paper, providing a lustrous, light-struck surface. This helps enliven his by now very slick and decorative formula (Glueck).

JULES OLITISKI, "Spray Paintings of the 1960's," Ameringer Yohe Fine Art, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 445-0051 (through Aug. 1). That the spray-painted Color Field paintings that Mr. Olitiski made in the 60's once seemed such an important culmination of Modernist art history is something to ponder. Was it the merit of the paintings, which have, at their best, an expansive, confectionery prettiness? Or was it the mesmerizing rhetoric of their champion, the czar of formalism, Clement Greenberg? (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two-dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Marlerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

MERLIN CARPENTER, "Children of the Projects," American Fine Arts, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 727-7366 (through July 19). Like a grunge-generation Philip Evergood, Mr. Carpenter has created a suite of brushy, intentionally clumsy and overbearingly sentimental paintings that allegorize the plight of inner-city children. A boy in huge sneakers resembles an op-ed cartoon about escapist dreams of athletic success. Two boys in hip-hop wear, one aiming a handgun at himself, illustrate suicidal tendencies nurtured by poverty. Something is being mocked here but it's not clear exactly what (Johnson).

DONNA MOYLAN, "Paintings on a Theme," Nicole Klagsbrun, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3335 (through Aug. 1). Ms. Moylan's partly abstract, partly representational meditations on global strife of the last two years are visually engaging and poetically affecting. Feathery gestures and painted whorls following the grain of plywood panels morph into smoking, apocalyptic landscapes, sparsely populated by wan tiny people, trucks and helicopters. She evokes a curiously contradictory mood of playfulness and mournful anxiety (Johnson).

"ONLINE," Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, (212) 929-0500 (through Aug. 9). Not about Web art but the traditional use of line, this 38-artist show includes too much that is only tangentially linear. But works like Daniel Zeller's intense fields, like a zany topographical map; Hilary Harkness's fantasy of sexy girl sailors, drawn with Ingres-like refinement; and Beth Campbell's branching diagram of her own possible futures suggest that a more focused investigation of the varieties of linear expression in contemporary art would be worth pursuing (Johnson).

JOEL SHAPIRO, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000 (through July). If the sculptures of Donald Judd and Elie Nadelman had children, they might grow up to look like the best works in Mr. Shapiro's exhibition. They are the ones beautifully fabricated in various woods: airy, floating jumbles of tenuously connected boxes that visually resolve from certain angles into figures jauntily dancing or assuming graceful yoga postures. A pair of giant bronzes, however, look ponderous and overscaled (Johnson).

* DO-HO SUH, Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, (212) 255-2923, (through July 11). Mr. Suh's full-scale re-creation of his vacant New York apartment, including outer hallway and stairs leading to a nonexistent second story, is a wonderful blend of the mundane and the miraculous. From a distance, it's a ghost house, with translucent walls, stairs, doors, and kitchen and bathroom fixtures all made from sheer, slightly metallic blue, green and purple nylon. Inside you discover that everything from the door hinges to the toilet has been realized with loving attention to detail (Johnson).

"WORKS ON PAPER," Marvelli Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through July 12). Each artist in this fine show brings to paper a distinctive intensity: Dean Smith accumulates tiny, radiating pencil marks into iconic floral images; Guy Hindley draws crystalline topographical visions on mylar; Andrea Frank paints trees and animals in washes of extreme delicacy; Tim Maxwell generates swirling cosmologies out of miniaturistically detailed fragments; Nicolas Touron draws sweet, small, surrrealistic cartoons; and Kurt Lightner presents a patchy collage of shimmering color and light (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "THE NEW WORLD'S OLD WORLD: PHOTOGRAPHIC VIEWS OF ANCIENT AMERICA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through July 19). From the mid-19th century onward, photography played many roles in the frontier territories of North and South America: as a scientific instrument, a surveillance device, a definer of cultural identity and an aesthetic form. This beautiful show documents those uses and offers a sustained meditation on the shadow-play of picture-taking and politics (Cotter).

"NOT NEUTRAL: CONTEMPORARY SWISS PHOTOGRAPHY," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through July 19). It is not a good sign when an exhibition appears to be contradicted by its own title, but so it is with this gathering of photo-based work by nine artists born or living in Switzerland. Although beaming with competence, and impressively diverse, nearly everything operates comfortably within the well-defined borders of received ideas (Smith).

Last Chance

JOSE MANUEL BALLESTER AND CASTANEDA/REIMAN, Charles Cowles, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Thursday). In delicate gray washes, Mr. Ballester paints simplified, wide-angle views of coastal boardwalks under leaden skies, creating ominously dreamy moods. His show is titled "Setting Out." In the rear gallery, under the auspices of DCKT Contemporary, a two-person art team has produced "Floor Plan Landscape." This is an engagingly complex environment of stacked pieces of plywood and drywall, with gridded paintings on canvas and on the wall. Call it Home Depot Modernism (Johnson).

FREDERICK J. BROWN, "Portraits in Jazz, Blues and Other Icons," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through Sunday). This three-decade, 30-piece retrospective profiles a painter who has restlessly explored Modernist abstraction, Neo-Expressionist narrative and portraiture. His big, luxuriantly congested, storytelling pictures from the 1980's are the most visually rich and imaginatively expansive. His portraits of great jazz and blues musicians are, at their best, theatrically energetic. But a big double portrait of Willem de Kooning steals the show. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $3, students and 62+ (Johnson).

LARRY CLARK, "Punk Picasso," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-9100 (through tomorrow). This show is a walk-in tabloid that reduces looking to rubbernecking. An autobiographical collage of photographs, newspaper clippings, confessional monologues and personal memorabilia, it ranges through the artist's bouts of drug addiction, rehab, incarceration and marriage, as well as his books and films and their reviews. The intention to equate the heartlessness and outlaw status of drug addicts with artists is clear. But self-revelation is not self-reflection, and it is hard to admire the searing honesty of someone who is an exhibitionist to begin with (Smith).

DAN FLAVIN, Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1105 (through today). Six of Flavin's most radically simplified fluorescent light sculptures turn this spacious gallery into an oasis of coolly luminous quietude that verges on ecclesiastical. Believers will feel blessed. Skeptics may reason that just about any tastefully spare arrangement of lights in such a space would have a similarly dramatic effect. Either way, the show speaks volumes about the idealism of radically materialist art in the 60's (Johnson).

* "THE HEART OF THE MATTER: THE STILL LIFES OF MARSDEN HARTLEY," Berry-Hill, 11 East 70th Street, (212) 744-2300 (through today). This display of nearly 60 works is said to be the first ever devoted entirely to Hartley's still lifes. Glowingly alive, varying in style from abstraction to realism and in subject from delicate floral arrangements to the depiction of fish, a dead bird and ladies' gloves, they were painted with the same power and elan that went into his intense, vibrant landscapes (Glueck).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"SALLY MICHEL, MILTON AVERY: A PORTRAIT," Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through today). Also known as Mrs. Milton Avery, the widow of the artist, Sally Michel used her own name as a painter in her own right. This warm memorial tribute to Michel and Avery mounts a group of informal, private portraits of each artist done by the other. A wall of Avery by Michel, who died in January, shows him painting, napping, smoking, reading, thinking, leaning. A facing wall of portraits by Avery (1885-1965) shows Michel smiling, mothering their daughter, March, wearing a new hat and painting a portrait of her husband. This small show is an engaging celebration of a highly productive relationship (Glueck).

* AMY MYERS, Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through today). Ms. Myers, who made her debut at Mary Boone a few years ago, makes an impressive reappearance with this show of large drawings. The single big, complicated, diagrammatic structure in each is made of countless draftsmanly parts meticulously arranged. The structures suggest many concrete things -- space ships, ectoplasmic apparitions, sexual organs, mandalas -- but remain emanations of an intensely personal exercise in hard labor and serious play (Cotter).

* DARIO ROBLETO, "Say Goodbye to Substance," Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Thursday). Mr. Robleto, who is 31 and lives in San Antonio, makes his New York solo debut with a show that suggests a Nobel Prize-worthy science fair project. Its small, laboriously handcrafted sculptures are made from, among many other things, plaster, driftwood, homemade crystals, antibiotics, prehistoric whalebone dust, gunpowder and melted vinyl recordings of the Beatles, Black Sabbath and Tammy Wynette. Its themes include utopian thinking, space travel, pop culture and American childhood, all viewed with an attitude of sunny despair (Cotter).

FRANK STELLA, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 563-4474 (through tomorrow). Big, unpainted assemblages of steel pipe bent into curves, spirals and serpentine forms, as well as sheet metal and occasional punctuations of plastic materials, fill the gallery with aggressive energy. Mr. Stella's Cubist blend of biomorphic and geometric forms has a vaguely space-age look, but it is too familiar to make these works as spectacularly surprising as he wants them to be (Johnson).

* LISA YUSKAVAGE, Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889 (through today). Ms. Yuskavage continues to paint sly, soft-porn fantasies of pneumatic women in hazes of auto-erotic reverie. This show is modest compared to more sensational previous outings, but it's still one of the most compelling painting exhibitions up right now. Painting beautifully while spoofing painterly kitsch, exploring forbidden realms of feminine desire while subversively toying with the male gaze, Ms. Yuskavage conjures an exhilarating, mysteriously ambiguous visual poetry (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A photograph in Marco Poloni's series "Shadowing the Invisible Man" in "Not Neutral," at the Grey Art Gallery in Greenwich Village. (Grey Art Gallery); A detail from an Earle Bergey illustration in "Pulp Art." (Brooklyn Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
A Summer Job for Your Home

BYLINE:  By WALECIA KONRAD

 BODY:
HERE is what summer looks like for Geoff Currier, a freelance advertising copywriter who lives year-round on Martha's Vineyard with his wife, Joyce, and 16-year-old son, Max.
 Starting July 18, Mr. Currier and his family will pack up and spend a week on Long Island with friends and his wife's family. The next week, Mr. Currier will be back at Martha's Vineyard bunking with his son in the tiny cabin of his 30-foot sailboat; his wife will linger on Long Island. Then Mr. Currier will head south again, this time to New Jersey to crash for another week at his daughter's house in Chatham. 
 Meanwhile, a lovely couple from Sweden will most probably enjoy evening cocktails on the roof deck of Mr. Currier's rambling three-bedroom, after a relaxing day in the sun and surf at nearby Lambert's Cove and before heading to dinner in Edgartown at one of the Vineyard's celebrated restaurants. All for about $3,000 a week. 
Call it the summer shuffle. Owners of desirable properties in resort areas like Martha's Vineyard; Newport, R.I.; and the Hamptons help make ends meet by renting their homes to vacationers. They, in turn, scramble to find living arrangements of their own, happily putting up with outdoor showers and microwave meals in return for rent money that at today's rates is nothing short of a windfall. Almost no hassle is too much for these once-a-year landlords. 
Take Ms. Currier's own former landlord on Martha's Vineyard. Before she married, Ms. Currier rented a summer house in Edgartown from a gentleman who seemed simply to disappear once she moved in. But one night during a rainstorm, the man appeared at the back door -- a soggy apparition begging to come in. It turns out he had pitched a tent in the trees in the back of the property and after about a week of wet weather, he simply could not take it anymore. 
The next year, he bought a boat and, like Mr. Currier, stayed on board while his tenants took over his house. The only problem was that the landlord did not exactly get the boat in the water before the summer rental season began. He was staying on the boat all right, but for a couple of days it was sitting on a trailer in the backyard.
"Everyone has their own threshold," said Michelle Kirby, a real estate agent in Newport who often rents her own house for a couple of weeks each summer. "There's a little voice inside everyone's head that says, 'O.K., for this price, I'll do anything.' " 
The end of June is prime shuffle time. Keep an eye out and you can spot the windows being cleaned, the lawns tidied and the boxes being stuffed and hauled off to storage. Laura Alexander and her husband, Alex, and their two daughters, 7 and 10, live full time in West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard in a four-bedroom contemporary farmhouse they built three years ago. But each summer she and the children abandon their hometown for 10 weeks while the renters move in. 
"I find the only way I can deal with it is to start packing a month ahead of time," Mrs. Alexander said. 
In a way, Mrs. Alexander has it easy. She and her daughters will spend 10 weeks in a cabin in Maine that she and her husband bought four years ago. "It's great for the kids to get off the island, especially in the summer when it's so crowded," she said.
The rent in Martha's Vineyard helped make the Maine house possible, said Mrs. Alexander, but she declined to say how much rent she was charging. 
Her husband, however, will not be so lucky. He is a heating and air-conditioning contractor, and summer is his busiest time of year. Aside from the occasional weekend visit to Maine, Mr. Alexander will stay in a room above his office. Friends in town let him use their outdoor shower and washer and dryer. Cooking is out of the question, so Mr. Alexander grabs meals when he calls on his restaurant clients. "This time of year I'm working seven days a week," said Mr. Alexander, "so I don't care where I am."
For some homeowners, summer rentals help keep the house in the family. Ridgely Beck inherited his five-bedroom French provincial house on Newport's famous Cliff Walk back in the 1970's. When it was easy for him to travel for the summer, he often rented his home for several weeks to help offset the costs of repairs (the house is 77 years old). 
Five years ago, however, his daughter, then 10, came to live with him full time, and the summer rentals stopped. "It's hard to uproot a young child," he said. "There's so much stuff." 
But after a huge increase in property taxes this year, Mr. Beck has decided the hassles are worth the extra income. Last year the city of Newport reassessed property values for the first time in 10 years. Oceanfront homeowners like Mr. Beck found the values of their homes had doubled or tripled, said James Smith, the Newport city manager. The result was a huge tax increase for many Cliff Walk residents. 
"Even after fighting my assessment three different times, I still had a 40 percent increase," Mr. Beck said. "That's certainly an incentive to rent this year." 
So, Mr. Beck will spend July in the South of France while another family enjoys his historic home. 
"I've got a lot of work ahead of me," he said. "I haven't even begun to put stuff into storage yet." Mr. Beck will not say how much he is charging for rent, but the going rate for a house like his is $40,000 to $60,000 a month, according to a local real estate agent.
OFTEN, a domino effect takes place during the summer shuffle. 
"You'll see people with big estates rent their house for $100,000 for the season, then move into a $40,000 rental. That person moves into a $20,000 rental, and that person bunks with family or friends," said Diane Saatchi, the president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton on Long Island.
One Middletown, R.I., resident knows what she means. "This happens to me all the time," she said, declining to give her name for fear that city officials will discover that she often rents her home to more unrelated people at one time than the city's rental ordinances allow. "In years past I rented to a woman who rented her very expensive house. Then I would simply move to one of the four cottages I have on the grounds. I'm the end of the food chain." 
This year the troubled economy and slow rental season in many areas of the country have put a crimp in the plans of some would-be landlords. Homeowners with a less-than-perfect location or a quirky situation are having trouble finding renters. 
Lisa Amols, an exercise instructor on Martha's Vineyard, has yet to find someone who wants to rent her three-bedroom house on two acres for $2,000 a week. She and her two children, 13 and 15, plan to camp out in Ms. Amols's 900-square-foot exercise studio on the property. (In return for the lack of privacy, tenants get as many free workouts as they can handle.) 
"I'm hoping for the ideal tenant who loves my house so much and loves to work out so much that they won't mind the fact that we're around," said Ms. Amols, who rented the house to friends last summer. 
Then there are Gina and Scott Bradley, who live in East Hampton. They have no tenants this year, but for a completely different reason. Ms. Bradley is expecting her first child any day. In previous years, however, they rented their house for July and August for roughly $20,000, then moved to a small cottage in Amagansett that Ms. Bradley has owned since before the couple married. 
"The Hamptons is the only place in the world you can get this kind of money," she said. "You get used to the extra income in a hurry." 
That is why Ms. Bradley figures the family will rent again next year. What's more, she said, the couple is actually looking forward to squeezing into the cottage, which has just one bedroom, during the summer.
"No guest rooms keep visitors to a sane level," Ms. Bradley said. "It's amazing how many of my friends from New York don't even think about visiting me until right about now."

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
Hidden on Maui, A Place for Art

BYLINE:  By MICHELE KAYAL

DATELINE: MAKAWAO, Hawaii 

 BODY:
IN a large, airy studio tucked beneath a mango tree, Tom Faught throws six-foot-tall pots from 1,000-pound lumps of clay, turning them on an enormous wheel. Today, many potters and painters toil in the corners of this tiny community on the slopes of Haleakala volcano on Maui, but when Mr. Faught arrived three decades ago as a teacher, he was the local art scene.
 "I won first prize at the county fair," said Mr. Faught, a self-described old hippie, with spiky white hair and a platinum stud in each ear. "No one else entered." 
 Makawao then was a barroom brawl of a town, filled with gun stores, feed depots, barber shops and saddle makers, all serving people from the surrounding cattle ranches. Makawao (pronounced MOCK-a-wow) still evokes the little-known and fast-fading Hawaiian cowboy life in its wood-shingled buildings, the horses tied up in front yards and the cowboy dolls and miniature Black Angus cattle in the toy store. Every year around July 4 there is a rodeo put on by the remaining cowboys, who are known as paniolos. (This year it is July 4 and 5.) But if cowboys are the history of this one-horse town, artists are its future. 
More than a dozen galleries line Makawao's quarter-mile main drag -- almost half of them opened in the last five years -- and art can be purchased nearly everywhere: cafes, shops and even a hair salon. Some inns are owned by artists or brag of one "in residence," and the town's visual arts center draws visiting artists from all over the United States. Painters sometimes work in storefronts and on the street, and glass blowers mesmerize onlookers by twirling liquid sand like honey on a knife.
Over the last decade or so, artists have transformed this once-dying cowboy outpost into a Sedona of the Pacific that many residents and business owners say is just starting to hit its stride. 
"As far as a local place, like SoHo used to be, that's where it's at right now," said Robert Zaleski, a painter and an owner of Gallery Maui. 
But tourists who likely know of SoHo in Manhattan and Sedona in Arizona have hardly heard of this place. An hour inland from the beach resorts that made Maui famous, and away from the busy main route to the Haleakala crater, Makawao is not on the usual tourism circuit. In this region, called Upcountry, there is not a hula girl in sight and hardly a mai tai to be had. There are just rolling cow pastures and people working the land, morning temperatures in the 50's and a softly prismed light that drifts off the sleeping volcano. Some people do find their way here, and bicycle tours that cruise through town on their way down the volcano have begun to spread the word, but it is not a destination for luau-minded travelers.
"We usually do the beach-hotel thing," said Steve Hodgson, a three-time Maui visitor from Vancouver, British Columbia, who had never heard of Makawao until the concierge at his beach resort recently recommended it. "The ambience of the place is very artistic," Mr. Hodgson said. "I like the tin roofs, and it's not overly gentrified. I could easily hang here for a week."
THE town's low profile has protected it from the commercialism that can be seen in better-known places like Lahaina, an old whaling village near the resorts that has become one of West Maui's main tourist attractions. Some Maui artists boast that Lahaina is the third largest art center behind New York and Paris, though no one seems able to say how that conclusion was reached. But there is no denying the jostling sidewalks of Lahaina and its crowded galleries selling art by celebrities like David Bowie and Jerry Garcia, well-known works like the French waiter depictions of Guy Buffet and a panoply of art from the mainland alongside Maui-made works. 
Makawao's scene, like the town itself, is comparatively obscure and thoroughly local.
"There's an emphasis on the culture of art and the spirituality of being an artist," said Annie Lawson, program director at Hui No'eau, the well-respected arts center housed in an early 20th-century estate just outside town.
Makawao's galleries vibrate with diverse work. The playful and exuberant paintings of Janet Davis recall fairy tales, while Martha Woodbury and other artists explore geometric shapes. There are, of course, some depictions of hula girls, but many artists capture the Upcountry world around them: Makawao street scenes and joyful flying cows in watercolors by Eddie Flotte, sepia photographs of Hawaiian cowboys by Randy Jay Braun and other works that celebrate the region's color and light.
Some artists invite visitors into their studios, and exhibition openings are often potluck parties where artists spread the table with homemade favorites; people are said to fight over the last slice of rum cake made by J. B. Rea, a silversmith at Viewpoints Gallery. Creatively inclined visitors can take classes themselves at the Hui, whose name roughly translates as "club of the artistic."
On a recent day, a slow-cooker full of ground meat for sloppy Joes simmered away in the former stable that now serves as the Hui's ceramics studio, and a group of potters was preparing for a lunch break that would also include home-baked lemon bars. Coffee mugs with the logo of a nearby yoga center sat drying on a multitiered cart and a bulletin board advertised "Potters needed." Anita Bachmann picked at the leafy detail on a small urn she was finishing. Scott Semple, who apprenticed with Mr. Faught, cradled a giant clay drum between his knees, rolling it and tapping it. 
"That's my thing," he said, "uncovering the acoustic properties of clay." 
Many credit the Hui with providing a nexus for the growing Upcountry art scene. Artists say they scramble up the mountain for its mystical light, which seems to compress distance; its cool breezes; its cheaper rents; and its psychic remove from the cruise ships, snorkel trips and time shares.
"It's more conducive to work up here because the temperatures are a lot better, and you're out of the craziness of the tourist towns," said George Allan, a landscape painter who moved Upcountry seven years ago, after two decades near the coast. 
Makawao's first gallery was opened in 1986 in an old plantation-style house by David Warren, a painter and printmaker who wanted a place nearer his Upcountry home to show his work. But it was years before anyone followed. It was not until a good Italian restaurant opened that Makawao began to attract "people who might buy art," said Cole Warren, who today runs his late father's gallery. 
Viewpoints Gallery, which says that it is Hawaii's largest artists' collective, was one of the next in, setting up in a long-closed theater; Hot Island Glass followed a couple of years later. Galleries continue to open
The cowboys didn't always take kindly to the artists. Mr. Faught said he won over the community by eating every day at Kitada's, a diner where a yellowing Chesterfield cigarette stand graces the counter and people have been gathering each morning for nearly 60 years over Spam and eggs to talk about problems like the wild turkey population.
But the artists received better treatment than the "freaks" (marijuana smokers) and "crystal people" (New Age enthusiasts) who came before them, said Gary Moore, the owner of HI. Hearth and Leisure and sometimes called the community's unofficial mayor. Mostly they endured only ridicule, he said of the artists. 
"We all laughed" when the David Warren Gallery opened, Mr. Moore said. "But he made it. When the others opened, we weren't laughing as much."
Some old-timers complain that the place has been overrun by out-of-towners, people they don't know and don't want to know. And despite the many authentic reminders of old Makawao -- the quaint buildings, the absence of traffic lights, the rodeo -- they mourn what they say is the loss of true cowboy life.
"We can't even ride a horse in Makawao town," said Herman-Louis DeCoite, president of the roping club, referring to the rise in motorized traffic.
Some of the artists would like to see more exposure for their art. Randy Groden, a painter who opened his own gallery, R. Groden Gallery, in February, recently printed Makawao gallery guides and delivered them personally to concierges at the high-end hotels on the coast. Kari McCarthy, a graphic artist and a painter who is one of the artist-owners at Viewpoints, is trying to start a Makawao-based fine arts magazine.
On a recent Friday morning, a dozen artists squeezed around an outdoor table at Grandma's Coffee House in nearby Keokea, ribbing their friend Frank Kane about his performance the night before in a production of Sartre's "No Exit" at the Makawao Union Church. Students from the Hui had set up easels across the street to capture the spectacular view of West Maui. This kaffeeklatsch has met every Friday for the better part of 10 years to talk about art and life, life and art, projects going, projects failing and, more recently, the sense that there is something, something very good, about to crest. 
"We've hung in there for a long time," said the painter Janet Davis. "We're in that area now where everything's great."

IF YOU GO
A Cow Town With Painters and Sculptors
MAKAWAO is 12 miles from the Kahului Airport. Weekly rates on economy-size rental cars range from $250 to $320 including fees and taxes.
The Banyan Tree House (3265 Baldwin Avenue, 808-572-9021) offers beautifully done rooms, many with colorful, Hawaiian-themed paintings by the artist in residence, Suzy Papanikolas. Cottages, which can be small, start at $85 a night; the three-bedroom plantation manager's house is $300 a night.
The owners of Hidden Falls Cottage (355 Kaluanui Road, 808-573-1173), Bob Flint and Sunny Jordan, have decorated the small cottage on their two-acre property in retro-Hawaiian kitsch. The cottage -- with a work by Mr. Flint, a muralist, in the shower -- is $125 a night. There is a three-night minimum. 
Two Web sites list a variety of Maui Upcountry vacation rentals: www.bestbnb.com and www.vrbo.com. On both simply follow links to Maui.
Once you have checked into your lodgings, you may be ready to check out some of the village's 13 galleries.
Viewpoints Gallery (3620 Baldwin Avenue, 877-646-7600; www.viewpointsmaui.com) is open Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., Sunday 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 
David Warren Gallery (3625 Baldwin Avenue, 877-572-1288; www.davidwarrengallery.com) is open daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. 
Hot Island Glass (3620 Baldwin Avenue, 808-572-4527; www.hotislandglass.com) is open daily, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; glass blowing, 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. 
Hui No'eau Visual Arts Center (2841 Baldwin Avenue, 808-572-6560; www.huinoeau.com). The gallery is open daily, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. A schedule of classes is available at the Web site.

LENGTH: 882 words

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW; 
Pillow Talk, Pillow Fight, All French, Of Course

BYLINE:  By ANNA KISSELGOFF

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., June 25 

 BODY:
The nascent modern-dance boom in France was a well-kept secret in 1983 when the American Dance Festival presented five young French troupes at its summer home here at Duke University. 
 La Maison, an uninhibited and compelling company directed by the choreographer Nasser Martin-Gousset, is the latest entry in the mind-boggling range of French dance that the festival has introduced to Americans over the last 20 years. 
 "Bleeding Stone," which La Maison presented on Tuesday night at the university's Reynolds Industries Theater, initially suggests a movie that is not a movie: a serio-comic stage version of a French film by Eric Rohmer. 
Three men and a woman sit around a living room, engaging in French wordplay about who is sleeping with whom or how to pass the day. Casually dressed, they contrast with an elegant woman in a red dress who intrudes upon the group and stirs up passions among the men. Aggression becomes a wildly imaginative pillow fight on a sofa. Possessiveness in the first woman turns into flying leaps from an armchair to the same sofa. In a sensual solo with autoerotic overtones, a man licks honey off his body. 
Like Mr. Rohmer's "moral" tales, "Bleeding Stone" comments on possible betrayals in human relations, and the setting is similarly French bourgeois. One man is in tennis shorts and sneakers (later in jogging shorts), and leisure time, rather than unemployment among the working class, hangs heavy in the air.
There is even a little Brahms thrown in for background music, although most of the accompanying tape is by the Rolling Stones, propulsive music for propulsive dancing. 
In the end, "Bleeding Stone" is a wildly original work and is indebted less to any specific French arts figure than to a general sensibility. At least three dance generations down from the French choreographers who first came to the festival in 1983, including Maguy Marin, Mr. Martin-Gousset nonetheless shares their sense of the absurd. 
Like them, he also places his nonlinear narrative in a closed space. Sartre's "No Exit" has had a stronger influence than expected. 
Yet within the emotional claustrophobia embodied in the living room, the action is unpredictable and dynamic. The structure uses free association and dissociation in its imagery. The work is also uneven in its set pieces. 
Mr. Martin-Gousset has worked with Josef Nadj, more a theatrical director than a conventional choreographer. But unlike Mr. Nadj, he is less concerned with a theatrical image than its expression through evocative movement. 
Some of the performers are apparently actors rather than dancers: Samuel Dutertre, the honey man, and Emmanuel Lescoulie, in shorts. Sophie Lenoir, a fearless, bawdy blonde who flies around the furniture and then sings out a somewhat incomprehensible lament about Ken and Barbie dolls while mopping the floor, is multitalented. So is Mr. Martin-Gousset, who can do a fashion-model strut in sunglasses and a terry cloth robe and then pummel the sofa and Mr. Dutertre as his rival in a swift thrust-and-parry duet. It is a thrilling acrobatic duel set in motion by Elizabeth Valentini as the woman in red whose angular, head-rotating solo is full of dejection. She changes the atmosphere. 
Red, the choreographer said in a talk after the performance, is the color of danger. As a child, he saw a drop of blood on a stone and assumed the stone was bleeding: hence the title. A clip from "Gone With the Wind" is included because it is his favorite film. There are also film images of a heart operation, related to the emotions on view. Mostly, however, a film behind the sofa shows trees moving in the breeze behind a gate. The dancers are never seen in this open air, although they materialize humorously from behind the sofa. 
When Mr. Dutertre spreads honey on the floor and himself and then skates on the sticky surface, he creates his own world. In a solo that repelled some but was full of elegance at the same time, he conjured an image of total escape.
A member of the audience told the choreographer that she thought that the entire work was the equivalent of reality television. In a way, she was right. "Bleeding Stone" is highly staged and a picture of how people live. 
To celebrate the 20th anniversary of the debut of the first five French companies, Charles Reinhart and his wife, Stephanie Reinhart, the festival's directors, planned a mini-French festival for this year. The entire season is now dedicated to Ms. Reinhart, who died in September. (A memorial tribute will be held tomorrow afternoon at Duke.)
The other French choreographers include Dominique Boivin (July 14-16) and Ms. Marin, whose "One Can't Eat Applause" was seen last week. She also presented "Grosse Fugue," set to Beethoven, on Sunday. 
Four women (Preciosa Gil, Sylvie Pabiot, Cathy Polo and Brigitte Valverde) often danced in unison, with one pair echoing the other in canon while passing through sharply isolated shoulder movements. The choreography's structure grew more complex and the movement quirkier (hiccuping back on a heel, bodies folding up like accordions in repeated collapses). Ms. Marin seemed to approach the music from a distance rather than plunge into it, although the impressively precise dancers looked emotionally as well as physically spent at the end.

HEADLINE: Amid a Glut, the Biggest Ship Ever Rises 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: SAINT-NAZAIRE, France, June 20 

 BODY:
In January it will carry up to 2,620 passengers, in considerable luxury, across the Atlantic. But for now the immense steel carcass resembles little more than a huge anthill.
 Some 3,000 workers scramble over the hull of the Queen Mary 2, spackling, drilling and laying air-conditioning ducts between its 17 decks. In the coming weeks, cabins and swimming pools will be installed and restaurants capable of serving thousands at a sitting outfitted. Then, in September, the ship, the largest and costliest ocean liner ever built, is to set sail on trial runs off the coast of Scotland. 
 There will be a spa, a Veuve Clicquot Champagne bar and a planetarium. There will also be a casino on board. But the biggest gamble is the 1,132-foot Queen Mary itself. It is larger and heavier than a Nimitz-class nuclear aircraft carrier and being built for $800 million by the French shipbuilder Alstom Marine for the venerable Cunard Line, now a unit of the Carnival Corporation. 
Carnival is betting that the global appetite for ocean cruises, most notably the trans-Atlantic runs between Southampton, England, and New York that will be the Queen Mary's specialty, will boom again when economies recover and the fear of possible terrorist attacks diminishes.
 On Wednesday, Carnival reported that slowed bookings and price cuts because of the war in Iraq had caused second-quarter profit to fall 34 percent, to $127.8 million, or 19 cents a share, from $194.2 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier. But revenue rose 35 percent, to $1.3 billion. It also said second-half earnings would be lower than analysts' forecasts. 
For Alstom, the Queen Mary is to be a signal that the yard can fend off low-cost competitors from Japan and South Korea in the race for complex and expensive vessels.
After trips to Florida, the Caribbean and South America next winter, the Queen Mary 2 will make its inaugural voyage to New York in April. There, it will be received with considerable fanfare, and will meet up with the Queen Elizabeth 2, the liner it is intended to replace. It will be the first time since March 1940 that two liners bearing those names will berth together in New York. (The first Queen Mary is now a floating hotel in Long Beach, Calif.; the first Elizabeth was retired and auctioned off, and was set to become a floating university until it caught fire and was scrapped in the early 1970's.)
The QE2 will cede the regular Atlantic runs to the QM2 and turn to regional cruises.
Cunard toyed with ideas for the QM2 for more than 18 months before soliciting bids in 1999 and ultimately awarding the contract to Alstom. It was the first time construction of a Cunard flagship had gone to a non-British yard.
"They wanted a mix of the old Queen Mary, some elements of the Normandie and the Queen Elizabeth," said Jean-Jacques Gatepaille, the senior naval architect at Alstom who worked on the original design. Unlike most modern cruise ships, floating, boxy skyscrapers with cabins stacked so high you wonder why they do not topple over, the QM2 was designed as a sleek trans-Atlantic liner with a sloped facade leading up to the bridge and a stepped fantail with decks for lounging.
Some naval architects criticized the single funnel compared with the two or three found on classic liners. Mr. Gatepaille said a second would have meant shifting large parts of the ship's machinery, entailing significant cost overruns.
"It is the first time in 40 years that a trans-Atlantic liner is being built for regular service," he said over a lunch of salmon in the dining room at Alstom's offices in this port city, in France's northwest.
And it is quite an undertaking.
Stood on end, the ship will be taller than the Statue of Liberty. As tall as a 21-story building, it will clear the Verrazano Bridge at high tide with little room to spare. It will steam at 30 knots, roughly 34 miles an hour, crossing the Atlantic in 6 days, with cabins of up to 2,250 square feet.
"It's little different from working on land," said Gilles Charpentier, who plastered the walls of an on-board lecture hall one recent afternoon, as electricians laid cable and carpenters glued wood paneling. Mr. Charpentier said the company he works for, which is based in Paris, would spend the next four to five months on work aboard the ship.
Carnival acquired Cunard in 1998 from Kvaerner, a Norwegian shipbuilder, and plans for the Queen Mary were soon announced. But the luxury segment of the cruise industry, in which Cunard is an icon, weakened sharply afterward as the souring of the global economy, the war in Iraq and fears of terrorist attacks and diseases like SARS took their toll on the travel industry.
In April, Carnival's shareholders approved a $5.5 billion takeover of P&O Princess Cruises, a British rival, thwarting an earlier agreement to merge P&O with Royal Caribbean International.
The industry has been struggling to fill a glut of new ships by offering bargain fares. In April, Carnival said it would add a new ship to its Princess Cruise line, take one out of service at its Holland America subsidiary and delay the delivery of three others. The move reflected greater industry caution that some analysts say could help in the long term.
Last year, the cruise industry, which is based mainly in North America, ordered only 4 new vessels, after only 2 in 2001, compared with 13 at the height of the boom in 1999. So in 2004 and 2005, cruise liner capacity is expected to grow by less then 4 percent, half the rate of growth in the last two decades.
Robin M. Farley, a UBS Warburg analyst, said in a report this month that the "North American capacity outlook is better than it appears."
That is little consolation to the shipyard workers at Alstom Marine.
Alstom was awash in orders in the late 1990's as the North American cruise market exploded, and cruise lines ordered dozens of new vessels at European shipyards, which were seeking to overcome competition from low-cost yards in South Korea and Japan by specializing in high-value vessels like liquid natural gas tankers, research vessels and cruise liners.
But Europe's shipyards are floundering. Meyer Werft of Germany and Kvaerner Masa-Yards of Finland both recently announced plans to idle employees. Thousands of suppliers are also hurting. Roughly four-fifths of the value of liners like the Queen Mary comes from suppliers like Mr. Charpentier's plastering company that deliver everything from diesel engines and gas turbines to the furniture for luxury suites.
The yards are also hurting from the weakness of the dollar, which make ships purchased for dollars in European yards more expensive. When Royal Caribbean announced this month that it had provisionally ordered two new giant cruise ships, larger than the Queen Mary and capable of transporting up to 3,600 passengers each, from Masa-Yards, it also announced a financial innovation: It linked the final contract to the dollar's exchange rate. Some analysts calculate that the dollar would have to strengthen to $1.08 to the euro, from $1.15 now, for the final contracts to be signed.
The end of the Iraq war, Alstom Marine's chief executive, Patrick Bossier, said in an interview in the yard newsletter, should spur a renewed flow of orders, though not immediately. "The cruise lines can wait, for if there are fewer vessels in service, then cruises can be sold more dearly," he said. "Yet one can nevertheless imagine that the first order coming from a major line will likely send a signal to the market and motivate others who will not want to risk losing market share."

HEADLINE: How the West Is Taxed 

BYLINE:  By Mark Baldassare; Mark Baldassare, author of "A California State of Mind: The Conflicted Voter in a Changing World," is research director at the Public Policy Institute of California.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
California is facing the worst budget crisis in history: no state has ever faced a deficit, $38 billion over two years, as large. As Gov. Gray Davis and the legislature spar over spending cuts, tax increases and borrowing to balance the budget, they are working against a deadline. If no agreement is reached before Tuesday, the start of the new fiscal year, the state will literally run out of money.
 Preoccupied with this looming disaster and lingering economic uncertainty, Californians are in no mood to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Proposition 13, the citizens' initiative limiting property-tax increases that was approved in June 1978. Instead, there have been sobering reflections about the mixed legacy of Proposition 13 -- and calls to reform it. 
 California's reassessment should serve as a warning to the many states that followed California down the path of tax reform -- 18 states placed limits on taxes and spending in the wake of Proposition 13 -- as well as those who have pointed to California's "tax revolt" as a model for the national level. For all its value to the people (and politicians) of California, Proposition 13 has been anything but a simple fix.
Proposition 13 has been highly popular with the state's residents ever since it passed -- 60 percent still support it today -- because it has provided Californians with tax predictability during two decades of rising real-estate values. No one dares question its core: the property tax can be no more than 1 percent of the actual sales price of real estate, and increases are limited to 2 percent per year. The unintended consequences of Proposition 13, however, can be debated.
Although the initiative was heralded as tax relief for homeowners, for example, its major beneficiaries were the corporations whose land and buildings avoid property tax reassessments at market value. Revamping the property tax system to protect homeowners while allowing increasing rates for commercial property is supported by a majority of Californians, according to a survey conducted this month by the Public Policy Institute of California. But such a change would require voter approval.
Some are also taking aim at Proposition 13's supermajority requirement. The initiative's authors wanted to rein in local governments, which, prohibited from making large increases in the property tax, might be tempted to pass other tax measures. So the law requires that two-thirds of the voters approve any special local taxes, which are those used to pay for specific services like schools or parks.
In the past 25 years, local officials have indeed found it difficult to gain enough support to raise such taxes. Earlier this month, for instance, voters in many school districts around the state approved an increase in local taxes to cover the expected shortfall in state financing -- but not by the necessary two-thirds majority. Some are now proposing to change the ratio necessary for approval from two-thirds to 55 percent for all special local taxes. Nearly half of the state's residents agree.
Meanwhile, Proposition 13 has shifted the balance of power between the state and local governments. While the law requires that local governments collect property taxes, it puts the state legislature in charge of distributing the money. As a result, local schools are vulnerable to statewide economic downturns. This trend has taken its toll over 25 years: Since the 1990's, California has ranked in the bottom half nationally for educational spending on a per-student basis.
It's not just schools that have been hurt by the state's boom-or-bust budgeting. City governments, seeking alternative revenue sources after losing control of property taxes, increasingly encourage the building of shopping malls and auto dealerships in order to generate more local sales tax revenue. The result? Not enough room for new housing, which is seen as less attractive because property tax money goes to the state. According to the state department of housing and community development, California needs 220,000 new units of housing every year to meet demand, yet since 1990 it has averaged 100,000.
Through the current budget crisis and beyond, it is important to remember that it was the voters who changed the tax system 25 years ago, and that most of these fiscal reforms require the voters' approval. Moreover, with the combination of a relatively inexperienced state legislature (because of term limits) and a governor preoccupied with the threat of voter recall, there is policy paralysis in state government. So it is voters, once again, who control state fiscal matters.
California's problems are not the nation's, of course, nor are California's solutions. But as the largest state, the economic and political effects of its actions will reverberate. As America is to the world -- the exceptional nation that nonetheless sets an example -- so California is to America. California's response to its present crisis may well set the stage for a new era of reform among the states.

HEADLINE: $1 Billion Offered to Settle Suit on I.P.O.'s 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON and JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Some 300 companies that sold new shares to the public during the late 1990's agreed yesterday to pay $1 billion to settle an investor lawsuit contending that the stock offerings' prices were artificially inflated.
 But under the terms of the deal, which has not been approved by all the parties, the companies -- mostly technology concerns -- will pay nothing if the investors also win a settlement of at least $1 billion from the brokerage firms that underwrote the stock offerings and are also being sued. 
 Lawyers for investors have contended that the firms sold shares to favored clients who agreed to purchase additional shares in the open market, driving up the price. The issuing companies, they argue, participated and benefited from the arrangement. 
The settlement of the class-action suit provides a guarantee that investors who bought initial public offerings from 1998 through 2000 will receive at least $1 billion, before legal fees. The companies that issued the shares, meanwhile, are betting that the investors' lawyers will prevail against the 55 brokerage firms, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse First Boston and many smaller firms. If the lawyers were to win more than $5 billion from the Wall Street firms, the companies in the settlement would recover legal fees and other expenses incurred in the litigation.
Any payment to investors will be delayed, potentially for years, until the securities lawsuits against the brokerage firms are resolved. "The case proceeds very actively against the underwriter defendants," said Melvyn I. Weiss, a partner at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach and the chairman of the plaintiffs' executive committee in the securities litigation, at a news conference yesterday in Midtown Manhattan. 
Which investors may share in the settlement will not be known until the class has been certified by Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of United States District Court, who is presiding over the shareholder suit in Manhattan, lawyers said. Given the settlement's many parties, approval of the deal could take six months. The settlement is separate from the $1.4 billion deal reached in April by the New York attorney general's office and 10 large Wall Street firms relating to biased stock research.
In their complaints against the companies and the brokerage firms, the shareholders contend that the firms sold shares in hot new companies to favored clients in exchange for fees or for agreements to purchase additional shares of the companies in subsequent public trading. "That caused, we allege, artificial inflation of the market price," Mr. Weiss said. 
Most of the 309 companies involved in the proposed settlement are technology concerns whose shares were in demand among investors during the bull market. They include Ask Jeeves Inc., Global Crossing, Aether Systems, Clarent, Copper Mountain Networks and VA Linux, now VA Software. If the companies wind up paying the $1 billion, the money will come from their insurers. 
Wall Street firms raised buckets of money for fledgling companies during the late 1990's. In 1999, for example, more than $75 billion was raised in initial stock offerings, about the amount that was raised in new stock issues during all of the 1980's. 
During that boom, many individual investors were frustrated when they could not obtain new shares at their offering prices and instead had to buy them in the open market, after they had risen significantly. In 1999, for example, the average first-day leap of a new stock was 60 percent, up from the 10-percent moves that were typical from 1986 to 1994, according to Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. First-day gains on all initial offerings exceeded $29 billion in 1999, more than the gross domestic product of Bolivia.
A lawyer representing about 40 of the companies in the settlement said that his clients were looking forward to getting the deal approved. "If the settlement is finally approved, many issuers will be pleased to have this behind them and be able to concentrate on their businesses," said Jack Auspitz, a lawyer at Morrison & Foerster in New York. "This is probably the most complex securities litigation that has ever been brought. There are over 1,000 defendants, either individuals or corporations, and there were over 300 class actions." Mediation has been going on for more than a year in the case. 
The agreement could create an incentive for the companies that settled to help the plaintiffs' lawyers in their continuing lawsuit against the Wall Street firms. The companies have agreed to provide documents and other support to the shareholders' lawyers, Mr. Weiss said. Under the agreement, the settling companies will also assign their potential claims against the underwriters to the investors, he added. Some of the companies are defunct.
But a lawyer involved in the case cautioned against concluding that the issuers would be eager to help the investors' lawyers make their case against the brokerage firms. 
It is unclear how much of the $1 billion would be paid to the lawyers bringing the case, Mr. Weiss said. Any fee would have to be approved by the court.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Modest Gains as Investors Reassess the Fed's Rate Cut

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A report suggesting that layoffs might be stabilizing helped reassure Wall Street yesterday and sent stocks moderately higher, although the gains were limited by news of a sluggish gross domestic product. 
 Analysts said much of the advance was also a bounce back from Wednesday's sharp decline after the Federal Reserve voted to cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. 
 "It's a directionless day in the aftermath of the Fed cut," said Michael Palazzi, managing director of equity trading at SG Cowen Securities. "Investors are looking forward to the end of the quarter and dreading the preannouncement season," when companies issue warnings about earnings, he said. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.51 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 9,079.04, after falling 98 points Wednesday. 
The broader market also finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 31.35 points, or 2 percent, to 1,634.01. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 10.50 points, or 1.1 percent, to 985.82. 
The Commerce Department reported that the gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent during the first quarter. That was lower than the 1.9 percent reading estimated a month ago. 
But the Labor Department said new claims for unemployment benefits fell last week by a seasonally adjusted 22,000, to a three-month low of 404,000, suggesting that layoffs may be stabilizing. 
"They were sort of in line as expected," Mr. Palazzi said. "The market is gingerly moving along with healthy skepticism. We've had such great gains, there's more than a bit of caution." 
Stephen J. Massocca, the president of Pacific Growth Equities, agreed. 
"Had those reports delineated a clear direction for the economy it would have been meaningful" for the markets, he said. "But itdidn't really. The big new items the market is waiting to hear about are how poorly or good companies did in the second quarter. That will begin in earnest after the July 4th holiday."
Gainers included Intel, which rose 59 cents, to $20.63, and I.B.M., which advanced $1.86, to $84.35. 
The American International Group rose 55 cents, to $56.20, after the company said it would buy General Electric's Japanese insurance operations as well as its United States auto and home insurance business for about $2.15 billion. G.E. gained 8 cents, to $29.15. 
Decliners included GlaxoSmithKline, which fell 4 cents, to $41.35, although the company, based in Britain, said it got approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its antidepressant Wellbutrin.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Decline
By Reuters
Treasury prices fell yesterday as the market adjusted to the Federal Reserve's latest rate cut, which was smaller than some had anticipated. Many had expected a reduction of half a percentage point.
John Canavan, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, said that over the longer term, the Fed's commitment to keep interest rates low to address its main concern of falling inflation would support bond prices. In the short term, though, the market might experience more bond sales, he said.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 1 4/32, to a price of 100 22/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.54 percent from 3.41 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 25/32, to 112 20/32. The bond's yield rose to 4.57 percent from 4.46 percent on Wednesday.
