HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
San Francisco

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER HALL; CHRISTOPHER HALL is a journalist in San Francisco.

 BODY:
A sound not heard in San Francisco for two years reverberated along the waterfront 12 days ago. The clock on the historic Ferry Building, frozen during a renovation completed in March, was set in motion and once again chimes on the hour and half-hour. The clock had been stopped only three times before, by earthquakes, and its chiming signals the Ferry Building's rebirth. Though its soaring interior still feels slightly empty after being closed for three years, the Ferry Building is slowly filling with permanent vendors who will turn it by summer's end into a showplace of Bay Area food.
 The building could be a metaphor for San Francisco in 2003: all gussied up, but a little empty. After the renovation of many public spaces in the past few years, among them Union Square and the new home of the Asian Art Museum, the city is looking mighty fine. But tourism has been in a funk, leaving normally bustling sights like Fisherman's Wharf curiously uncrowded. 
Still, the city's charms, including summer fog, endure despite rocky economic times, and you'll never find it easier to score a table at a good restaurant or stay at a top hotel for a bargain price. And thanks to a new Bay Area Rapid Transit extension, it will be easier to get to the San Francisco airport. (Details, Page 3.) 

Events
 On July 4, the San Francisco Mime Troupe will present the premiere of its latest political comedy, "Veronique of the Mounties," the fictional tale of an impending United States invasion of Canada known as Operation Frozen Freedom. Through next Sunday, performances, all free, are at 2 p.m. in Dolores Park, 18th and Dolores Streets; (415) 285-1717;www.sfmt.org. Until Sept. 1, the show will play at parks in San Francisco and around the Bay Area. 
 Nine programs will be screened with piano, orchestra or organ accompaniment during the San Francisco Silent Film Festival, July 12 and 13. Included are "The Crowd," King Vidor's acclaimed 1928 movie about the life of one ordinary man; an early Walt Disney cartoon series combining live action with animation; and the 2001 American silent "Claire," filmed with a vintage hand-cranked camera. The festival takes place at the ornate 1921 Castro Theater, 429 Castro Street; (415) 777-4908; www.silentfilm.org. Tickets $12 to $14. 
 From July 26 to Nov. 4, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art will present "Marc Chagall," a retrospective of 153 paintings and works on paper, many never before seen in this country. The museum, which will be the sole site for the exhibition outside Paris, is at 151 Third Street; (415) 357-4000; www.sfmoma.org. Closed Wednesday. Tickets to the Chagall show are $15, which includes $10 general admission.
 A blanket or beach chair is the preferred seating as the Stern Grove Festival, through Aug. 17, presents free Sunday 2 p.m. concerts, from the San Francisco Symphony next Sunday and the San Francisco Ballet (July 27), to the band <1>Cubanismo! (Aug. 10) and the funk-soul group War (Aug. 17). Concerts take place in the grassy natural amphitheater at Sigmund Stern Grove, 19th Avenue at Sloat Boulevard in the Sunset District; (415) 252-6252; www.sterngrove.org. 
 At the Festival of Cheese on Aug. 2, you can sample more than 400 artisan and farmstead cheeses from across North America as well as California wines and other specialty foods. The event is 7 to 9 p.m. at the Ferry Building, Embarcadero at Market Street; (502) 583-3783; www.cheesesociety.org. Admission is $65 in advance, $75 at the door.
 The Brazilian singer-guitarist-songwriter Joao Gilberto will perform solo at 8 p.m. on July 25 and 26 at the Masonic Auditorium, 1111 California Street; (415) 776-1999, www.sfjazz.org. Tickets, $25 to $60.

Sightseeing
 The new home of the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco has been a hit since opening in the Civic Center in March in the city's former main library. The 1917 Beaux-Arts building contains 33 permanent galleries showcasing 2,400 objects, from massive stone Buddhas to delicately carved netsuke. The audio guide, included with admission, provides a lively survey of Asian art, and allows visitors to investigate topics in greater detail. On display through Aug. 31 is "Warrior Kings and Divine Jesters: Indonesian Puppets From the Herbert Collection." The museum is at 200 Larkin Street; (415) 581-3500; www.asianart.org. Closed Monday; admission, $10.
 The Anchor Brewing Company has been around since 1896, though its current incarnation as a small maker of traditional handcrafted beer dates from 1965 when Fritz Maytag, an heir to the appliance fortune, bought the company and helped start the modern microbrew renaissance. During once-a-day free weekday tours, visitors get a dose of both company and San Francisco history, a technical overview of the brewing art and a chance to taste beers. The brewery is at 1705 Mariposa Street, in Potrero Hill; (415) 863-8350; www.anchorbrewing.com. Reservations required.
 South of Market Street between Third and Fourth Streets, the five-acre Yerba Buena Gardens complex has a variety of attractions, including a children's play area, vintage carousel, indoor ice rink with skyline view, contemporary art gallery and an interactive art-and-technology center called the Zeum. But the central grassy area is what makes it the green heart of downtown. Popular with lunching office workers, the lawn also is the site through Oct. 26 of the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival, a free series of concerts and cultural programs that includes a performance by the San Francisco Chamber Orchestra July 27; (415) 543-1718, www.ybae.org.

Where to Stay
 At the Hotel Adagio, 550 Geary Street, (415) 775-5000, fax (415) 775-9388, www.thehoteladagio.com, to open Tuesday in a vintage Spanish Colonial Revival building about two blocks from Union Square, the 171 handsome rooms come with stylish modern furnishings in warm Mediterranean tones, Aveda bath products, Egyptian-cotton linens and high-speed Internet access. Introductory rates of $119 to $159 for a double room continue to the end of the year.
 The Handlery Union Square Hotel, 351 Geary Street, (415) 781-7800, fax (415) 781-0269, www.handlery.com, which completed a major renovation in March, offers 377 contemporary-style rooms in pale grays and olives. The hotel also has a barbershop, restaurant and heated outdoor pool. Doubles run $119 to $169.
 Budget: The Cornell Hotel de France, 715 Bush Street, (415) 421-3154, fax (415) 399-1442, or visit www.cornellhotel.com, is a friendly 55-room Gallic outpost, with reproductions of a different French painter in each floor's hallway. The owners are French and most of the staff French-speaking. Doubles are $90 to $139, including a full breakfast in the cozy French-country restaurant.
 Luxury: Housed in a 1909 neo-Classical landmark building, the Ritz-Carlton, 600 Stockton Street, (415) 296-7465, fax (415) 986-1268, www.ritzcarlton.com, is an oasis of elegance, serenity and impeccable service on the side of Nob Hill. The marble-columned lobby feels like the hall of a great English estate, with wood paneling, crystal chandeliers and oil paintings. Amenities include a garden, indoor pool and top-notch French restaurant, the Dining Room. Decor in the 336 rooms and suites is understated and traditional, with down duvets and Frette linens on the feather beds, and Italian marble bathrooms. Doubles $299 to $450; suites $549 to $5,200.
 The Prescott Hotel, 545 Post Street, (800) 283-7322, fax (415) 440-3016, www.prescotthotel.com, occupies two renovated 1911 buildings about a block from Union Square. The lobby and adjacent "living room" feature a large fireplace and kicky furnishings like modern art-glass light fixtures and club chairs upholstered in purple and oxblood leather. In the 164 rooms, the look is more traditional, with Empire-style furniture, richly colored Ralph Lauren fabrics and brown marble counters in the baths. Room service is provided by the in-house Wolfgang Puck restaurant, Postrio. Doubles $175 to $275, suites $255 to $500.

Where to Eat
 Tucked into the ground floor of a vintage luxury apartment building, CharlesNob Hill, 1250 Jones Street, (415) 771-5400, showcases the intricate and intensely flavored French-California cuisine of 26-year-old Melissa Perello. Dishes like fiddlehead fern salad with morels, delicata squash puree with caramelized Nantucket Bay scallops, and a sweetbread and porcini ragout are served by a polished young staff in two small, quiet, clubby rooms. You can order a la carte or one of the prix-fixe menus, which are $48 a person for three courses to $100 for a seven-course tasting menu. Dinner for two with wine runs over $200. Dinner Wednesday to Saturday.
 La Table, 3640 Sacramento Street, (415) 345-8600, which opened eight months ago in the Presidio Heights neighborhood, features seasonal brasserie and modern French fare like braised lamb medallions with summer vegetables, and duck breast with chestnut-flour polenta fries and semidried apricots. There are two dining areas, one a smart, tailored space with chairs upholstered in faux-tiger, the other a dramatic room with giant swag drapes and oversize paintings of waterlilies. Dinner for two with wine is about $130.Lunch and dinner daily.
 At the foot of Telegraph Hill, nine-month-old Piperade, 1015 Battery Street, (415) 391-2555, offers updated Basque classics like braised seafood stew in red pepper sauce, and a warm sheep-milk cheese and ham terrine. The dining room is warm and rustic, with a wood-beamed low ceiling and red brick walls. Large groups occupy a communal table in the center. Dinner for two with wine: $100. Lunch weekdays, dinner Monday to Saturday.
 There's often a crowd at year-old Limon, 3316 17th Street, (415) 252-0918, in the Mission District, where Nuevo Latino and Peruvian specialties like halibut ceviche with yam, corn and mussels, and a pork chop with cabbage-potato hash and a mushroom ragout are served in a tiny dining room whose walls glow in shades of lemon, lime and tangerine. Dinner for two with wine is $75. Closed Monday.
 Chow, 215 Church Street, (415) 552-2469, near the Castro District, offers American comfort foods like braised short ribs with mashed potatoes, grilled lemon-herb chicken, and apple or pecan pie in a down-home room where a Hershey's syrup can on each table holds flatware wrapped in brown paper napkins. A second location near Golden Gate Park, Park Chow, is at 1240 Ninth Avenue; (415) 665-9912. Lunch and dinner daily. Dinner for two with wine or beer, about $40.
 The city is full of no-frills Vietnamese coffee shops where you can generally find milky, sweet Vietnamese-style coffee, fruit-based pearl tapioca drinks and noodle soups. Sandwiches known as banh mi are made of warm, crusty French bread holding meat, slivered vegetables and cilantro. Among the busiest and best such shops is Little Paris, 939 Stockton Street, (415) 982-6111, in Chinatown, which has a branch in the Richmond District at 444 Clement Street; (415) 221-6028. Breakfast and lunch (until 5:30 p.m.) daily. Lunch for two with tea, $7 to $12. Cash only.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Midwood; 
Bustling Area With a Touch of Country

BYLINE:  By DULCIE LEIMBACH

 BODY:
WITH their deep front porches and overhanging eaves, Midwood's predominantly shingled two-story houses with front yards and driveways feel more like suburbia than like Brooklyn. Developed at the turn of the century as an alternative to Manhattan congestion, Midwood lies directly south of Flatbush and offers a fast link on Ocean Parkway to the borough's beaches.
 It is home to variety of ethnic groups, with Orthodox Jews prevailing but Chinese, Pakistanis, Haitians and Russian and Syrian Jews also represented. The picturesque houses convey tranquillity if not solidity, though some houses are gently shabby. 
 Which is not to say that Midwood is without luster. In May, the lawns were pristine, with dogwoods and lilacs interspersed among more mature maples and oaks. And on the eastern side of Ocean Avenue, which bisects Midwood, the homes tend to be luxurious, frequently done in a brick French chateau mode with mansard roofs and precision landscaping. 
Robert Viscusi, a novelist and English professor at Brooklyn College, said the birds near his house in Midwood, where he has lived for 24 years, provided the only sounds to be heard in the morning. "We get blue jays and cardinals and monk parakeets," he said. "I live in a one-family house and have a 10-minute walk to work."
As Jacob Gold of Jacob Gold Realty said: "People move to Midwood for a touch of the country, the tulips and the driveways. It's a touch of suburbia with an easy commute, no through traffic on some streets. It gives the illusion of escapism." But some street organizations hire private patrols, signs on lawns announce security systems and discreet bars are installed on windows.
Midwood may be luring more striving immigrant families than it did, say, 20 years ago, but it remains a relative bargain for people who want to live in old roomy houses and head to Manhattan by subway. The Q express can get riders to Midtown in about 45 minutes and the aboveground subway tracks are embellished with wisteria.
The H Avenue station, on the border of Midwood and Flatbush, is an example of the area's old-fashioned charm. The 97-year-old structure was originally a real estate office, but now serves riders on the Q local. New York City Transit is rehabilitating the Q stations, so Avenue H's future is up for debate. The wooden station is considered a fire hazard by the authority, which proposed to demolish it and build a new station. Community District 14, representing Flatbush and Midwood, is fighting that plan. "We have gone back to the drawing board," said Deirdre Parker, a Metropolitan Transportation Authority spokeswoman. "We are looking for alternative ways to keep it the way it is."
Meanwhile, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission is considering a request to designate the station a landmark and the surrounding neighborhood in Flatbush, Fiske Terrace, a historic district. The petition cites the enclave, named for the family that sold the property to the developer, for its distinguished older Victorian homes, many with curving front porches.
The northern boundary of Midwood is the Long Island Rail Road tracks just above Avenue I, and Avenue P and Kings Highway are the southern boundary. The eastern border is Nostrand Avenue, a strip of car dealerships, among other enterprises, and Coney Island Avenue to the west, where Pakistanis have settled. Their numbers, however, are dwindling because of a backlash resulting fromthe Sept. 11 attacks.
Nevertheless, Midwood is a "very stable community," said Ron Schweiger, the Brooklyn borough historian.
To enter the neighborhood's public library branch, on East 16th Street, during a weekday afternoon is to experience a traffic jam: the tables and aisles are packed with children doing their homework or checking out books. English classes are available for immigrants, and a recent lecture about the Jews of Afghanistan typifies the library's programs to keep residents in touch with current events. An elder storytelling program encourages residents to share their tales of Brooklyn and immigration.
On Avenue J, a low-key commercial strip, stores reflect the tastes of Midwood: kosher restaurants, delicatessens, pizzerias and butchers abound, but others specialize more narrowly, like one bakery concentrating on Russian bread. Ostrovitsky's Bakery sells buttery cookies that dissolve in your mouth. A number of large fruit grocers offer produce at competitive prices. But Avenue J can also be too hectic during weekdays, with cars making U turns and creating precarious crossing conditions for pedestrians.
There are at least a dozen yeshivas in Midwood, and most Orthodox children attend those schools.
An equally bustling street is Avenue M, where there is another elevated subway station; here the stores are more cosmopolitan, one finds a Godiva Chocolatier, Chock Full o' Nuts cafe and Nesle Caffe, selling smoothies, among other drinks. Many shops close by 3 p.m. on Friday, and the street is a veritable ghost town on Saturdays. Below Avenue M, the houses shrink, sitting on tight lots, fewer of them with driveways; apartment buildings, low-rise and brick, are more abundant, particularly along Ocean Avenue, which is four lanes wide but less traveled than other major north-south streets in the neighborhood. 
Midwood consists mostly of one- and two-family homes and multifamily walkups. Except for stores, there are few commercial operations; parks consist of the Rachel Haber Cohen Playground and adjacent basketball courts, near Edward R. Murrow High School. The playing fields of Brooklyn College and Midwood High School are generally open to the public when the schools are not using them.
MIDWOOD, whose name is derived from the Dutch word midwout, which means middle woods, was settled in 1652 and ultimately overtaken by the English. It was a rural area until developers started offering irresistible deals to farmers in the early 1900's to create middle-class housing tracts. Vitagraph Studios, on Avenue M, sprouted around 1907 to make silent movies. (It is now a yeshiva, the Shulamith School for Girls, covering prekindergarten through 12th grade.)
House prices have been rising over the last few years, thanks to an increasing population of professionals and extended Orthodox Jewish families, who often relocate to larger homes within Midwood as their families expand. The average price in 2002 was $475,000 for a one- to four-family house, said Jacob Shayovitz, a local broker. He said that the market was virtually idle now, with few houses for sale. "There is no inventory," he said. "When a house does land on the market, it can sell overnight."
But Sora David, a broker with Eisberg Lenz in Midwood, said that there was plenty for sale, although properties did not stay on the market for long. "This is a very close-knit community," she said. "We're really in our own world here."
This spring, a house at Avenue M and East 21st Street sold for $675,000, said Mr. Gold, who handled the sale. Mrs. David's office sold a two-family house at 1916 Ocean Avenue for $550,000 a few months earlier.
Prices are deemed so high in Midwood that less expensive areas near by, like Marine Park to the southeast, Mr. Gold said, are becoming destinations for buyers.
As for co-op apartments, Mr. Shayovitz said the average price for a two-bedroom apartment was $100,000 to $150,000. Rentals, however, are languishing. "The economy has made it not as busy as usual," said Robert A. Svoboda of Jacob Gold Realty. One-bedroom apartments are $900 to $950 a month; two bedrooms are $1,150 to $1,300.
Brooklyn College's Georgian style architecture sets an Ivy League tone at the northern edge of Midwood. Since Christoph M. Kimmich became president three years ago, one of his purposes, he said, was to allow residents to partake in the library and athletic facilities, including the pool and tennis courts, through a community membership program. The school's performing arts center and health and job seminars are also open to the public. "Once a year, we engage our students and faculty and the neighborhood in a cleanup day," Dr. Kimmich said. This spring, they tackled graffiti.
The larger public high schools in the area -- Midwood High School and Murrow High School -- are both widely praised. Midwood High School, on Bedford Avenue, is renowned for the number of Intel science talent search awards it has won. Although there is no entrance examination to the school, half the students are admitted based on achievement in middle school.
Murrow emphasizes a broad college preparatory curriculum of English, science, social studies, foreign language and math, with an additional concentration on fine arts, drama and music. Applicants for the special fine-arts programs must submit portfolios or audition. Priority to Murrow is given to students who live within three blocks of the school, but all Brooklyn residents are eligible; and anyone who has scored in the highest 2 percent on the seventh-grade reading test is automatically admitted if the school is listed as the student's first choice. Murrow is progressive: no letter grades are assigned; classes meet four times a week, with the fifth day spent on independent study, and there are no athletic teams. Advanced placement classes are offered in calculus, music theory and economics, among many.
Other high schools close to Midwood in Flatbush are Brooklyn College Academy, an alternative high school on the campus of Brooklyn College, and Brooklyn Night High School, an evening school on the campus of Midwood High School.
Public School 193, the Gil Hodges School, is a prekindergarten through fifth-grade program at 2515 Avenue L. A gifted program there attracts kindergartners who are already reading; fifth graders immerse themselves in "The Odyssey." Additional tracking takes place below the gifted level. P.S. 193 was cited in "New York City's Best Public Elementary Schools," a guide by Clara Hemphill with Pamela Wheaton that lists the city's better public schools by borough and district. This year, 68 percent of the fourth-grade students met state standards in the English-language arts test. In 2002, 64 percent met the math criteria (this year's math figures are not available yet).
At P.S. 199 on 1100 Elm Avenue, the curriculum centers around literacy and technology. School uniforms are mandatory; immigrant children are from Russia, Ukraine and Pakistan. On the English-language test this year, 82 percent of the fourth graders met the standards; in 2002, 83 percent met the math standards.
On East 22nd Street near Nostrand Avenue, P.S. 197 offers an extensive reading and writing curriculum for its prekindergarteners through fifth graders, even extending English classes to parents, some of whom are Russian or Ukrainian. This year, 61 percent of the fourth-grade students passed the English-language test, while 62 percent passed the math exam last year.

COMMUTING TIME TO MIDTOWN: About 45 minutes total, starting on the Q local (which stops at Avenues H, J and M) and switching to the Q express at Newkirk Avenue.ALPHABET AVENUES: The east-west avenues in Midwood are lettered, starting with Avenue I and ending at Avenue P. They were named that way primarily to help newcomers navigate the area in the early 1900's. "The name of the community was Midwood Manor," said Ron Schweiger, the Brooklyn borough historian, and on a map from 1908, there were actually more letter names. Some of the roads' names have changed, however. Just north of Midwood in Flatbush, Avenue F is now Farragut Road and Avenue G became Glenwood Avenue. Most north-south streets are numbered in Midwood, and there has never been any movement to give them more felicitous names, Mr. Schweiger said. The cost of the earliest houses in Midwood Manor, he said, were comparably high: on East 10th Street and Avenue I, for example, new single-family homes were $4,000; two-family, $5,000, in about 1907 or 1908. HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
How to LearnFrom Closed-End Funds, Without Buying

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BUYING a closed-end fund at its initial offering is rarely a good idea because of the hefty sales commissions that underwriters earn on the deal, according to Owen Lamont, an associate professor of finance at the University of Chicago.
 But Professor Lamont says investors can still learn a lot about the stock market by analyzing the types of new closed-end funds that are being sold to the public. 
 Unlike traditional mutual funds, closed-end funds have a fixed number of outstanding shares. Except in rare circumstances, a closed-end fund cannot issue more shares to meet investor demand or redeem existing shares in response to selling by investors. 
Because of this, the prices at which closed-end funds trade often diverge significantly from their net assets per share. If demand for a particular fund is strong, an investor may have to pay a premium above its net assets per share. If demand is weak, a seller may have to accept a discount.
Until about 1990, some contrarian market timers successfully based their trading on the average premiums or discounts of closed-end equity funds in general. Large discounts were considered bullish signals, while small discounts, or premiums of any kind, were seen as bearish. In January 1987, for example, 10 months before the crash, the average discount of closed-end domestic equity funds narrowed to less than 1 percent.
But this market-timing system did not work well in the 1990's. According to Donald Cassidy, senior research analyst at Lipper, the average discount of closed-end domestic equity funds narrowed sharply in 1993, at the early stages of a long bull market. Moreover, the largest average discount since 1990 -- more than 17 percent -- was at the end of 1999, just before the bear market.
But Professor Lamont, an expert in the study of market inefficiencies, says another aspect of closed-end funds -- the number of new funds that focus on certain market sectors -- sheds more light. Because closed-end funds can be hard to bring to market, fund companies tend to start new ones in those market areas where individuals are most eager to invest. That often means that these sectors are overvalued in comparison with the rest of the market.
Because underwriters typically earn a sales commission of 7 percent on a new closed-end fund, he said, "investors are being asked to pay a dollar for significantly less than a dollar's worth of assets." This looks like a good deal only to investors who are wildly enthusiastic about a sector. 
Before 1999, for example, no closed-end equity funds focused explicitly on the Internet and high-technology companies. But in that year, two such funds came to market, raising nearly $600 million. A third arrived in June 2000, raising more than $100 million. The market peak for Internet and high-tech stocks was in the first half of 2000.
SIMILARLY, many closed-end funds focusing on specific countries' stocks were issued in the late 1980's and early 90's, reflecting investor enthusiasm for foreign stocks. The number of new funds in the category reached a peak -- 11 -- in 1990, raising more than $1.3 billion.
That year was also a peak in foreign stocks' relative strength. Over the 10 years through 1990, the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe, Australasia and Far East index, or EAFE, beat the Wilshire 5000 by an average of 4.4 percentage points a year. By the end of 1995, however, the EAFE had fallen behind the Wilshire, when measured over the trailing 10 years; it has stayed behind ever since.
Recently, real estate has been the focus of many new closed-end equity funds. During the 1990's, only one such fund was issued -- in 1993, raising just over $100 million. But two started in 2001, and six more in 2002, raising a total of more than $2.1 billion.
Because of that popularity, investors may want to bet that real estate will lag behind the rest of the stock market over the next decade.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Narrower Discount"Closed-end domestic equity funds often trade at a discount to their net asset value. The discount widened at the end of 1999, and has narrowed recently. Graph tracks the average discount of all domestic equity closed-end funds(as of the end of each year) from 1990 through June 20, 2003. (Source: Lipper)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Seeking to Overturn a Ruling on Delinquent Taxes

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
THE New Jersey Supreme Court is being asked to resolve a dispute over the way Jersey City arranged to collect delinquent property tax money a decade ago. The issue, according to parties on both sides, is of moment today not only to the taxpayers who were then delinquent and the bank and finance companies who gained control of their tax liens -- who have $27 million at stake -- but also to current and future delinquent taxpayers and any municipality that arranges for private tax collection.
 Last month, a state appellate court reversed a two-year-old lower court ruling that had awarded the $27 million -- a figure that included triple damages -- to delinquent taxpayers who complained they had been victimized after Jersey City transferred their tax liens to private companies. 
 Now the taxpayer group is asking the state's highest court to strike down the appellate court's ruling and reinstate the damages. As long as the appellate court ruling stands, private companies that have purchased municipal tax liens may negotiate whatever terms they can get delinquent property owners to agree to in order to extract payment, according to lawyers for both sides. 
And what is the problem with that? Attorneys for the companies involved in the Jersey City transactions argued there is none, since property owners are free to hire lawyers to negotiate the best possible terms for paying off their tax debts.
According to attorneys for the taxpayers and an organization representing municipal tax collectors, however, the problem is that those facing delinquency are financially vulnerable, may not be able to afford a lawyer and can easily fall prey to unscrupulous practices. 
The roots of the legal dispute go back to 1992, when Jersey City had severe financial problems and a backlog of $44 million in unpaid real estate taxes -- and a new mayor, Bret Schundler. Mr. Schundler, who had been a bond broker and knew his way around financial markets, pioneered an idea for solving Jersey City's money problems by using a technique he had learned on Wall Street: securitization.
Mr. Schundler -- who went on to become the Republican candidate in the gubernatorial race two years ago -- in effect proposed securing a private loan for the city, using owed taxes as collateral.
Mr. Schundler persuaded state lawmakers to pass a law enabling Jersey City to bundle its tax liens and transfer them to a trust, in exchange for $25 million in cash and a $19 million promissory note. The cash would come from investors who purchased bonds from the trust, and the promissory note was to be paid off with some of the money collected from delinquent taxpayers.
In 1993, the former Bankers Trust -- now part of Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas -- issued the bonds and hired the Breen Capital Services Corporation of Bordentown to collect back taxes and foreclose on property if necessary.
In 1994, the same participants handled another 1,200 real estate tax certificates worth about $14 million to the city, with the financing arranged in the same fashion, part cash to Jersey City and the rest in a note.
Municipalities have long auctioned off tax sales certificates to individual investors who try to collect back taxes or else foreclose on individual properties. In fact, in the brief filed to the appellate court on behalf of Banker's Trust and Breen, the practice of "tax farming" is referred to as historic and is said to have been used in ancient Egypt, Greece and the Roman Empire and during the Middle Ages in Italy and England. 
But Jersey City was the first municipality in the country to introduce large-scale securitization into the field of tax farming. Hundreds of others, in New Jersey and around the country, have since followed.
Initially, the move brought a raft of favorable publicity for Mr. Schundler, along with the infusion of cash for the strapped city.
But things soured after a time. Court documents say that Breen was unable to collect enough cash from the sorely delinquent taxpayers to pay off all the investors, and one group of investors took Breen to court. Jersey City also sued Breen and wound up collecting only $6 million on the $19 million note.
Meanwhile, several property owners who had failed to keep up with their payments and forfeited their homes to Breen hired lawyers who filed a class action suit on behalf of all 2,300 delinquent taxpayers, claiming that installment plans were illegal unless arranged by a municipal tax collector -- and furthermore that they had been victims of consumer fraud because Breen had overcharged them on interest and fees.
Breen, headed by J. Douglas Breen, who had also been in the bond business, had set up installment plans for only about 600 property owners, and 80 percent of them made their payments and kept their houses.
But that left more than a 100 other cases. Ruth J. Fails, for example, one of the taxpayers who initiated the lawsuit against Breen, was described by lawyers as a struggling grandmother who had raised six children in the house at 150 Bergen Avenue that she bought in 1977.
Judge Jose Fuentes, who awarded summary judgment and the $27 million in damages to the taxpayers in November 2000, noted in his opinion that Mrs. Fails was approached by Breen to enter into an agreement regarding a payment plan "at a time of great vulnerability, when her economic world was collapsing around her." The company took the opportunity to "extract from her the last financial breath," he wrote.
Mrs. Fails, who still resides in the Bergen Avenue home, continued working as a postal clerk beyond retirement age in order to stay there and now pays rent to a landlord, said Jeffrey Herrmann of Cohn Lifland Pearlman Herrmann & Knopf of Saddle Brook, the law firm representing the taxpayers.
Officials on the other side of the case respond that Mrs. Fails didn't pay any taxes from 1990 on. After Breen started a foreclosure, she agreed to an installment payment plan and then stopped paying. It is hardly surprising, they said, that someone who had not paid taxes for 10 years would lose her house. 
But Joseph E. Rauch, who is the former executive director of the Tax Collectors and Treasurers Association of New Jersey, noted in a letter to New Jersey tax collectors alerting them to the appellate court ruling, that Mrs. Fails had made three payments to Bankers Trust and Breen totaling $3,700 before Breen foreclosed on her property.
"Some of these lien buyers are unscrupulous," Mr. Rauch contended. "They want the money, and the property too.'
MR. RAUCH is now retired and living in Florida, but continues actively with his professional group and spurred it to file a friend-of-the court brief on the side of the taxpayers. He said municipal tax collectors are required by strict laws and professional standards to do everything possible to avoid foreclosure. 
About 50 of the first group of Jersey City taxpayers wound up making arrangements to settle their tax debts with the municipal tax collector, Mr. Rauch said in his letter -- after making one or more tax payments to Breen.
In the original taxpayer complaint, Breen was also said to have charged 18.25 percent annual interest, when the legal limit is 18 percent, and to have charged an illegal $25 bad check fee. Attorneys for the taxpayers acknowledged in their most recent brief, however, that Breen had dropped those practices after taxpayers complained.
Mr. Herrmann, whose firm filed formal notice two weeks ago that it would seek to have the case considered by the Supreme Court, the highest state court in New Jersey, argued that taxpayers under duress are still likely to get hoodwinked.
"The installment payment plans offered by Bankers Trust/Breen resemble the age-old scheme commonly known as the lay-away plan," he wrote in his brief for Judge Fuentes, "in which customers are enticed to make payments on a piece of merchandise they cannot afford to buy, inevitably miss a payment and then lose the merchandise and whatever payments they have made." 
The appellate court, which agreed with both sides' contention that the issue of privately administered installment plans was the key issue it had to decide, noted that taxpayers agreed to them voluntarily and said in its opinion that they had the legal right to do so.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Measuring the Time Needed to Succeed

BYLINE:  By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
THE secret to Jagdish (Jay) Patel's formidable stamina and reliability is a strong constitution, the ability to get by on six hours sleep and the jigger of scotch that he says he drinks every night before retiring. Clears the head, he says, and keeps a small businessman from "thinking too much" about his business. 
 As owner of Henry's Fine Foods, an old-fashioned small grocery store in Verona, N.J., Mr. Patel, 43, keeps a schedule thatwould seem punishing to anyone but another small businessman. His store is open every day of the week. And holidays too, including Christmas. He is even open during snowstorms, like the time last winter when Verona got hit with 29 inches. He slept in a cot in the backroom and opened the next morning, as usual, just after five. 
 Since Mr. Patel bought Henry's in 2000, not a single day has gone by without the front door opening and the cash register clanging. But that achievement pales besides that of his predecessors in the store. Henry Percevault opened the store on Bloomfield Avenue in 1930 and did business each and every day for years. His son Joseph took over and kept the streak going until his own retirement in 2000, when he sold the business to Mr. Patel.
In all, Henry's has opened every day since the beginning of 1930, a total of 73 years, or 26,843 days and counting. It is probably some kind of record, and if it's not, it should be.
Mr. Patel, who started working on his father's businesses in India when he was 16, expects to keep up his brutal schedule for 10 more years, by which time his three children will be on their own. Then, he said, he and his wife will "just take a rest," though he expects he will continue to get up at 4 a.m. out of habit. 
Someone once defined an entrepreneur as a person willing to work 16 hours a day so they don't have to work 8 hours a day for someone else. Managing time is one of the single most important determinants, besides money, of a new business's success.
"Time and time management are definitely on the list of success factors," for a small business, said Kris Solie-Johnson, president of the the American Institute of Small Business, a book company in Minneapolis that publishes "How to Set Up Your Own Small Business," an 850-page reference work carried by many local libraries. 
As the national economy has slowed, the number of people starting their own business has risen. According to the United States Small Business Administration, 550,100 new firms were opened in 2002. 
But it takes more than a clever idea or original concept to build a new business. Only about half of newly created firms survive at least four years, and miscalculating the amount of time required is to blame for many failures. 
"We always advise people that before going into business they should put together a business plan that gives a more realistic sense of what the real time commitment is going to be," said Miguel Centeno, a public affairs officer for the Small Business Administration office in New York. 
The Small Business Administration also runs a counseling service for entrepreneurs called the Service Corps of Retired Executives, or SCORE, (www.score.org) which can help answer questions and give advice. 
"Running a small business isn't hard," said Martin R. Lehman, a retired retailer with SCORE, "it's 25 hours a day."
For those who do not have the stamina for 80-hour weeks with or without scotch, Ms. Solie-Johnson offered a few time management hints. She uses an online payroll service that produces time savings enough to more than compensate for the small fee she pays. And she turns off her cellphone while driving the 45 minutes to and from work. 
Henry J. Coleman, owner of Alchemy Answers, an online service that provides information and advice for small businessmen (www.alchemyanswers.com) along with several retail businesses, said he learned some fundamental rules about time management after putting in 100-hour weeks trying to get a stock brokerage going. 
"The lesson I learned is that time management is not deciding what to do but what not to do," he said. "Once you do that, it's amazing how much time you create." 
Instead of putting together a to-do list, Mr. Coleman, who now runs five different companies, prepares a list of things that are not his responsibility. "I knew from Day 1 that my time would be finite," he said. "I refused to build an enterprise where the only way to grow was for me to put in one more hour. Once you start down that road, there is no end."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Affirmative Action, Productive Potential

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
THE Supreme Court's decisions on affirmative action brought a raft of social issues to the fore last week. But what of the economic consequences?
 By its nature, affirmative action takes innate attributes that may have nothing to do with ability and makes them part of an educational or professional selection process. An economist's knee-jerk reaction to any policy like this is usually that it will keep a market from matching buyers and sellers in the most efficient way. In other words, you had better have a darn good reason to do it. 
 An economist may also object to affirmative action because it gives current importance to past actions by people who, in most cases, are no longer around. Moreover, the benefits of affirmative action accrue to many people who did not directly feel the consequences of those actions. In a tremendous oversimplification, you might imagine Chevrolet sending out checks to its car owners today because of the exploding gas tanks in Ford Pintos 30 years ago.
But given what economists know about educational and professional attainment, this point of view is naive and incomplete. There are definite connections between generations; a parent or grandparent's success, material or otherwise, can directly influence a child's prospects in life. In addition, bad blood within communities can harm the smooth workings of a society, not to mention an economy.
The theory seems especially inadequate when faced with the reality. Careful studies of the economic effects of affirmative action have found mostly an upside.
Research conducted in the 1980's by Jonathan S. Leonard, chairman of the Haas Economic Analysis and Policy Group at the University of California at Berkeley, found that affirmative action had increased the employment of minorities and women in the 1970's.
In the 1990's, Harry J. Holzer, a professor of public policy at Georgetown University, and David B. Neumark, a professor of economics at Michigan State, looked at how workers in those demographic groups fared. Examining data from four major metropolitan areas, they found that companies with affirmative action policies employed blacks and Hispanics with slightly less education or credentials than those employed by companies without the policies. But the professors also discovered that the performance of minority workers hired under affirmative action was no worse than that of those who weren't.
At least indirectly, these studies give credence to an idea long held by supporters of affirmative action: that most standard measures of aptitude, like the College Board tests, are biased against minorities. In a market for labor based on these measures, minorities would be underemployed relative to their productive potential.
One might arguethat the labor market in the United States is much more subtle, taking account of many different markers of future success. Yet can it delve beyond all superficial traits to measure a person's true potential, without bias? If it could, there would be much less need for affirmative action.
IN fact, research by Professors Holzer and Neumark showed that affirmative action might help fine-tune the labor market. It appears to increase the use of recruitment and screening procedures for job applicants. It also leads to more hiring of "stigmatized" applicants, including those who have criminal records or have been on welfare, who may still be productive workers. In a 1999 working paper, the professors concluded that "the empirical case against affirmative action on the grounds of efficiency is weak at best."
They also noted that affirmative action could still have hurt some groups. Whites, for example, might have missed opportunities to work or learn as a result of affirmative action, as the plaintiffs in the Supreme Court cases argued. But if this occurred because colleges and companies had begun to value the potential of minorities and women more accurately -- even by giving them the benefit of the doubt -- then economic efficiency was probably served.
Because the second of the Supreme Court's decisions on affirmative action required that race, sex and ethnicity be considered in combination with other factors, the policies' effects are likely to be diluted. Upper- and middle-class blacks and Hispanics, for instance, may no longer receive special consideration when applying to universities or for jobs.
The full economic consequences will therefore depend on the answer to another question worthy of research: If there is indeed a bias against minorities in standard measures of educational and professional potential, does that bias disappear when an individual has had other advantages in life? If it does, the Supreme Court may have fine-tuned the labor market even more.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Chevrolet Corvette; 
At 50, You Should Look So Good

BYLINE:  By NORMAN MAYERSOHN

 BODY:
THE Chevrolet Corvette, a balm applied to countless egos bruised by midlife crisis, is celebrating its own 50th birthday this weekend in Nashville with caravans, parades, vintage-car displays and a rock concert. To reach the half-century mark, America's iconic sports car has persevered through trying times, starting with a so-what initial reception from buyers and, in later years, the upheaval created by antipollution regulations, all the while fending off rivals' repeated attempts to dethrone it.
 No matter that the Corvette never had to endure the creepy menu on some tropical island, or nerves boiled to the breaking point in an Amazon jungle. Chevy's two-seater is a bona fide survivor, having outlasted earnest contenders that were, at times, faster performing, better handling and lower priced. And although it represents the wane of the fifth-generation model, the 2003 Corvette is both tautly athletic on the street and thriving on the sales charts, posting its best-ever month in April (with a little help from manufacturer incentives, admittedly). 
 Enthusiasts with long memories might point to the popular Ford Thunderbird of 1955 as the first real threat to the Corvette's existence, but in fact by then General Motors executives themselves had already tried to vote their slow-selling model off the island. Plans to cancel the Corvette -- justified by fewer than 4,000 total sales in the first two model years -- were rescinded late in 1954 after Zora Arkus-Duntov, the car's swashbuckling guardian angel and its first chief engineer, risked his career with an impassioned memo arguing that a high-performance sports car would make all Chevrolets more appealing. (In a twist of fate, it is the revived two-seat Thunderbird that faces extinction, partly because of its undistinguished performance.)
Near-death experiences revisited Corvette in the 1960's as G.M. considered plans to make the car a four-seater; in 1975 when the output of the standard engine dipped to just 165 horsepower, as exhaust emissions and fuel economy took priority; and again a decade later when the fourth-generation car was so late going into production that the entire 1983 model year was skipped. A loyal following, which bought Corvettes in record numbers even when quality and performance were at their nadir, kept the Corvette alive. "When you're in love with a car, you tolerate a lot," said Martyn Schorr, the founderof Vette magazine and a former public relations representative for G.M.
A test drive of the 2003 model quickly reminded me of the formula that has sustained the Corvette in spite of those challenges. The willingness of a muscular V-8 engine, styling that pays homage to beloved predecessors (including scooped sides and a quartet of egg-shaped taillights) and the view forward from a two-place cockpit over a seemingly endless hood all register as hot buttons to the Corvette faithful, many of whom have aspired to ownership since grammar school.
Less desirable traits carry over, too: it is not an easy car to enter or exit, and the switches are too obviously lifted from the same parts bin that supplies econoboxes to rental fleets.
Commemorative-edition Corvettes haven't always been subtle, but the 50th Anniversary Edition is a model of restraint, painted a deep burgundy -- not gold, thank goodness -- with Champagne paint on the spoked wheels. Modest five-oh badges (especially in comparison with gaudy Indianapolis 500 Pace Car trim of the past) are affixed outside and embroidered into the seats and mats. The anniversary package is a $5,000 option and can be added to the hatchback ($44,435) or convertible ($51,335), though not to the higher-performance Z06 hardtop.
Although the first Corvettes took to the road with a drivetrain ill-matched to the car's dashing profile -- a barely warmed-over six-cylinder from the passenger-car line and a lowly two-speed automatic transmission -- the 50th Anniversary Edition suffers no such indignity. The standard engine is the LS1 V-8, successor to Chevy's original small-block design of 1955. It still uses pushrods, rather than overhead cams, to actuate the 16 valves -- 2 for each cylinder.
Forget what those specifications imply about outmoded technology: with 350 peak horsepower, and bountiful torque at low speeds, the Corvette is very forgiving if you're lazy with the six-speed manual gearshift. That's just as well, because the transmission, while much improved through the years, still doesn't feel like pulling a hot knife through butter.
If you can live without the anniversary reminders and whatever dubious extra value the markings might command from future collectors, there's the 405-horsepower Z06 hardtop, too.
Though I am as susceptible to the charms of a Corvette as any red-blooded American, Chevrolet's sweetheart hasn't always been a favorite in my driveway. Often, it seemed too much of a chore to enjoy on anything but smooth country roads far from city traffic. The current generation -- dating to 1997 -- is a pleasant surprise, however.
The incessant rattles of earlier models were almost entirely absent in the 2003 test car, partly because of vastly improved assembly quality and somewhat attributable to a ride that is no longer slam-bang harsh. Anniversary models are equipped with G.M.'s Magnetic Selective Ride Control, a variable-rate suspension system that adjusts the stiffness by using the action of electromagnets on iron particles suspended in fluid within the shock absorbers.
The suspension computer can fine-tune the system to driving conditions and road surfaces 250 times a second. The driver can toggle between touring mode (for a better ride) and sport mode (for optimum handling) when the desire strikes.
Low production and a legion of forgiving owners make the Corvette an ideal platform to experiment with new technologies and features like the heads-up display, an optional readout of essential information projected in front of the driver.
Chevrolet's product planners have done an effective job of carving out a niche for Corvette. It offers V-8 performance well in excess of two-seaters like the Audi TT and BMW Z4 (though at a somewhat higher price), yet undercuts the cost of less well-rounded, more powerful offerings like the Dodge Viper SRT-10. This clever positioning encourages buyers to base their choice on emotional issues, where Corvette's legacy and race-bred image stand out.
The next-generation Corvette will make its debut at the Detroit auto show next January and arrive in showrooms later next year as a 2005 model. (The '04 Corvette will be the last of the current generation.) Recent history suggests that the changes will not be radical, which is appropriate considering the performance and refinement of the 2003 model. "For the first time, the outgoing car is not an anachronism," said Jerry Burton, editorial director of Corvette Quarterly and author of a new biography of Arkus-Duntov. "You can't help but respect it."

INSIDE TRACK: A half-century old, but forever young.

HEADLINE: Psst! Want to See the Next 'Vette? 

BYLINE:  By NORMAN MAYERSOHN

 BODY:
AS the current Corvette nears the end of its production cycle, speculation about its successor is approaching the roar of an engine at the red line. Industry sleuths are digging for clues, enthusiasts are swapping rumors and magazines are promising full disclosure.
 The fifth-generation car (known to enthusiasts as C5) is due for a makeover, having been introduced for 1997. Dave Hill, vehicle line executive for Corvette, said in a telephone interview that the next car, C6, would make its debut in January at the Detroit auto show and go on sale next summer as a 2005 model. 
Some details are already in the public domain, thanks to the impending introduction of the Cadillac XLR, a two-seat luxury sports car that shares its structure -- and its assembly plant in Bowling Green, Ky. -- with Corvette.
 The car that is suggested from the mix of educated guesses, insider tips, clandestine spy photos and artists' drawings is not a great departure from today's. Forget about the grapevine of years past, when there were rumors of midengine layouts and four seats. Fixed headlamps, rather than the pop-ups used since 1963, will be among the significant changes, and greater definition is expected in the curves of the fenders and side vents.
 History suggests that horsepower (and, quite likely, engine size) will increase with the help of racetrack innovations. That doesn't necessarily mean gas mileage will suffer, given whispers that G.M. may give the engine displacement-on-demand technology, which deactivates cylinders when they are not needed, and variable valve timing, which optimizes both performance and economy.
The XLR's specifications sheet reveals that the wheelbase of the shared chassis will be 105.7 inches, slightly more than an inch longer than C5's, though overall length is said to shrink in an effort to increase the Corvette's appeal in Europe. 
Mr. Hill, who spent 27 years at Cadillac before becoming chief Corvette engineer, insists that the XLR won't steal sales from Chevrolet's halo car, but will attract its own following. The Corvette, for instance, will not share the XLR's folding metal hardtop. "The two have almost nothing to do with each other," he said. "It's not a zero-sum game."
 NORMAN MAYERSOHN

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS; 
You Might Want to Put Your Credit to the Test

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT

 BODY:
RECENTLY engaged and hoping to buy a house, Amy Mitchell paid $12.95 last February to view her credit score, that important single number that summarizes her overall creditworthiness. She then played with her score: What would it be if she paid off all her credit card balances each month, if she applied for an auto loan, or if she declared personal bankruptcy?
 Ms. Mitchell, 34, a management consultant in San Francisco, was trying a new online simulator that allows consumers to see how making certain financial choices, like applying for a mortgage or even closing a credit card account, could alter their credit scores. There are two available right now -- one from the Fair Isaac Corporation of San Rafael, Calif., whose FICO credit scores are used most often by lenders, and another from CreditXpert of Towson, Md., a company that designs credit management tools. 
 The simulators are an important addition to the credit industry. Only a few years ago the credit-rating agencies kept credit scores secret from consumers. Credit experts say these tools will help people make better decisions and give them more control over their finances. That could be especially helpful as the home-buying season moves into full swing and as more people take advantage of low interest rates to refinance mortgages. 
"People don't have to feel that they're at the mercy of financial services providers; they can change their financial lives," said Ms. Mitchell, who recently bought a home in Orinda, Calif., a San Francisco suburb, with her fiance, William Weber, 35, a political consultant.
By working with the simulator, Ms. Mitchell said she learned that paring down her credit card debt would raise her credit score significantly. That may help her if she ever needs to borrow money to fix up or furnish her home, or even refinance the mortgage. "I had a plan for paying off my debt, and this sort of reaffirmed my decision to do that," she said.
The credit simulators are also being used by credit-reporting bureaus and credit counseling agencies as an education tool. And some lenders and brokers are using the programs to distinguish themselves from their competitors in counseling prospective borrowers. 
Credit scores have always stumped consumers. Even people who know their FICO scores often don't understand the logic behind them. (They range from 300 to 850, and the higher the number the better.) A person's credit score is based -- in decreasing order of importance -- on the person's payment record, how much is owed, how long the person has used credit, the characteristics of the newest credit and the types of credit being used. Owning too many credit cards often hurts a score, but so does owning too few. 
Credit simulators help demystify the scores. Ms. Mitchell used the one from myFICO, Fair Isaac's consumer division.
Introduced a year ago, the FICO Score Simulator offers six kinds of financial conjectures. For example, customers may hypothetically transfer credit card balances, push the spending limits on their credit cards or pay bills on time for the next month, three months or six months. They may even pretend to miss a few payments. (By the way, if your score is now 707, and you missed payments this month on all accounts on which a payment is due, your score would drop to the range of 582 to 632. But if, instead of missing the payments, you paid all your bills on time for the next month, your score could increase to 727.)
Consumers can use the score simulator for 30 days through two packages that can be bought on www.myfico.com (click on "products"). For $39.95, consumers get credit information from the three major credit-reporting bureaus -- TransUnion, Experian or Equifax -- plus their FICO score, an analysis of the score and use of the FICO score simulator. For $12.95, they get the FICO score plus a credit profile from one bureau and the use of the simulator.
The six options in the FICO simulator correspond to customers' most common concerns, according to myFICO, but some people may want more choices. For instance, the simulator cannot allow more than one hypothetical move at a time.
For a larger selection of financial situations, there is the What-If Simulator from CreditXpert. Introduced in February, this simulator can also advise consumers on how to achieve goals like refinancing or simply improving their scores. Unlike the FICO Score Simulator, it allows customers to see how multiple actions would affect their scores. 
The What-If Simulator is not available directly from CreditXpert but can be bought at varying prices from some lenders, credit reporting agencies and other sellers of credit reports. A list of some sellers is at www.creditxpert.com (on the "consumers" page). Among the brokers that offer it are 1st Republic Mortgage Bankers in Floral Park, N.Y., and Capitol Mortgage Finance in Columbia, Md. It is available for $9.95 from Intersections in Chantilly, Va., which sells credit reports and privacy protection services; Intersections calls it the Credit Analyzer.
Christos Balis, 37, a chiropractor in Herndon, Va., recently used the What-If Simulator to look at the cumulative effect on his credit score of refinancing his mortgage, paying $3,000 on one of his credit cards and taking out a loan for some home renovations.
He was simulating a plan that he and his wife, Tamara, 32, a director at a Montessori nursery school, were considering to help them finance a $10,000 remodeling of their kitchen.
Dr. Balis said he learned that his credit score would gain twice as many points if he made a sizable payment on one particular credit card than it would if he made a comparable payment on another card. (He was closer to the credit limit on the first card.) He also found that a loan to remodel the kitchen would have little effect on his score. "That actually was news to me," he said. "It gave me a sense of security."
He said that before using the simulator, he was more inclined to spend his and his wife's savings on the kitchen. Now they are more likely to apply for a loan, he said, and to put some savings toward the credit card as suggested by the simulator.
LENDERS generally do not use CreditXpert's scores to make their lending decisions. But CreditXpert said the scores use the same principles as the FICO scores; they were developed when Fair Isaac still withheld its scores from consumers.
"The fundamental principles behind credit scoring are the same; it's just a matter of how you put the pieces together," said David G. Chung, CreditXpert's interim president and vice president for business development. "The things that will move you up our scale will move you up somebody else's scale."
Because a person's credit profile can change constantly, both myFICO and CreditXpert say that the actual score may not increase or decrease by the exact number of points calculated by the simulators. But it should certainly move in the expected direction, they said, and often by roughly the same number of points.
The companies say that just as high school students routinely take practicetests to raise their College Board test scores, so, too, can consumers use simulators to help raise credit scores. That would give people more control over their credit -- and what they pay for it -- the companies said. 
"Consumers by and large are very aware of credit reports; they are now getting to have awareness of how to improve their credit scores," said Sue A. Simon, the vice president of myFICO. "It's a whole different ballgame when you realize it can save you $300 a month on your mortgage payment."

What Makes a Credit Score Rise or Fall?
YOUR financial decisions can affect your credit score in surprising ways. Two credit-scoring simulators can help consumers understand the potential impact.
The Fair Isaac Corporation, which puts out the industry-standard FICO scores, offers the myFICO simulator. A consumer with a score of 707 (considered good) and three credit cards would be likely to add or lose points from his score by making various financial moves. Following are some examples:
* By making timely payments on all his accounts over the next month or by paying off a third of the balance on his cards, he could add as many as 20 points.
* By failing to make this month's payments on his loans, he could lose 75 to 125 points.
* By using all of the credit available on his three credit cards, he could lose 20 to 70 points.
* By getting a fourth card, depending on the status of his other debts, he could add or lose up to 10 points.
* By consolidating his credit card debt into a new card, also depending on other debts, he could add or lose 15 points.
The other simulator, the What-If, comes from CreditXpert, which designs credit management tools and puts out its own, similar credit score. A consumer with a score of 727 points (also considered good) would be likely to have her score change in the following ways:
* Every time she simply applied for a loan, whether a credit card, home mortgage or auto loan, she would lose five points. (An active appetite for credit, credit experts note, is considered a bad sign. For one thing, taking on new loans may make borrowers less likely to repay their current debts.)
* By getting a mortgage, she would lose two points.
* By getting an auto loan or a new credit card (assuming that she already has several cards) she would lose three points.
* If her new credit card had a credit limit of $20,000 or more, she would lose four points, instead of three. (For every $10,000 added to the limit, the score drops a point.)
* By simultaneously getting a new mortgage, auto loan and credit card, she would lose seven or eight points. JENNIFER BAYOT

HEADLINE: Business; 
Natural Food Stores Pursue Organic Seals of Approval

BYLINE:  By DENNIS BLANK

 BODY:
AS far as Joe T. Flueckiger Jr. is concerned, the exhaustive inspection and voluminous review of paperwork needed to get organic certification for the natural-food store he manages was well worth it.
 "This speaks volumes for the commitment we have made to organic foods," said Mr. Flueckiger, the store team leader for a Whole Foods Market in Baltimore. "Retailers are going to benefit tremendously because of the assurances we are giving our customers." 
 In early June, Whole Foods Market Inc. of Austin, Tex. -- the nation's largest chain of organic-food supermarkets, with sales of $2.7 billion last year -- became the first major grocery chain in the nation to receive independent organic certification for every one of its stores, 140 in all.
"I see it more as investment spending in the brand consistent with what Whole Foods' strategy has been: to make a national brand consistent with its mission statement," said Andrew Wolf, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets. "It will bring more shoppers into the store." 
The certification is intended to assure consumers that produce, meats and other foods that are sold as organic -- free of conventional pesticides or fertilizers, antibiotics or growth hormones -- are not mixed with nonorganic foods when processed, shipped or stored. Inspectors also check whether storage areas are free of pesticides that might find their way into organic foods.
Until recently, only farmers and processors had sought organic certification, which involves a review of purchasing and shipping documents and inspection of fields, crops and processing plants. The cost of certification accounts for part of the higher prices of organic food.
The private companies that certify the supermarkets -- Quality Assurance International of San Diego and Scientific Certification Systems of Emeryville, Calif. -- say their organic seals of approval generally cost $1,000 to $2,000 a store. Certification of stores is not required by the federal standards for organic food that were introduced last fall, unless the stores were involved in processing. If stores choose certification, however, they must separate organic foods from conventional ones, especially in the produce area. 
Some retailers' interest in certification appears to reflect a sort of competitive arms race among some grocers.
"My gut feeling is they are trying to get one foot up on the competitors to instill consumer confidence," said Ray Green, director of the organic program of the California Department of Food and Agriculture. Last year, California became the first state to require registration of retail stores selling organic products.
Whole Foods' main competitor, Wild Oats Markets, based in Boulder, Colo., which has 101 stores and had almost $1 billion in sales last year, said that it was now considering pursuing organic certification of its coffee and juice bars. Some smaller independent health food stores are also lining up, and more than a dozen have been certified.
Many stores are not pursing certification, particularly traditional supermarket chains that sell nonorganic as well as organic produce, meats and other foods.
"We are not planning on becoming certified, but our practice is to buy from growers and brokers who are certified," said Nicole Townsend, a spokeswoman for Raley's, a 134-store, traditional supermarket chainbased in West Sacramento, Calif. "We take great steps in the produce department to separate organic from nonorganic so they are not commingling, and we also do this in our distribution center."
But chains like Whole Foods that specialize in organic products want their customers to know that their organic peaches, say, or organic pot roasts are as organic in the store as they were on the farm.
Ellen P. Holton, the marketing director of Quality Assurance, said a team of inspectors needed more than 10 weeks to certify all of Whole Foods' stores in the United States and Canada.
She said the voluntary certification process "exponentially raises the confidence level of even more organic consumers."
Jeff Stephens, a spokesman for Scientific Certification, said, "The primary motivating factors are a good-faith effort to meet the intention of the U.S.D.A.'s National Organic Program, and to demonstrate to their customers they are doing more than is required by law."
The Organic Trade Association, based in Greenfield, Mass., is teaching its' members' workers and store managers how to keep organic foods free of contaminants. More than 450 stores have already participated. "It is more of a discipline in record keeping, and many of the stores have implemented that out of common sense," said David Gagnon, the group's director of operation.
Certification by consultants is not limited to organic supermarkets. Safeway hired Quality Assurance four years ago to certify its milling operations that produce the chain's Select brand of organic breads.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a Whole Foods Market in Baltimore, organic and conventional produce are sold in separate bins. Whole Foods now has independent organic certification for all its stores. (Steve Ruark for The New York Times)
