HEADLINE: Who's Minding the Drugstore? 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN

 BODY:
FEDERAL regulators decided last year that a national television commercial promoting a drug called Prevacid was misleading viewers by failing to make clear that the medicine was for serious heartburn problems and not for occasional indigestion.
 But the letter that regulators wrote to Tap Pharmaceutical Products, the maker of Prevacid, demanding that the ads be stopped, sat for 78 days in the offices of Daniel E. Troy, the chief counsel of the Food and Drug Administration, while millions of viewers continued to see the commercials. After the letter was finally sent, the company pulled the ads and refashioned them to address the F.D.A.'s grievance. 
 Government auditors warned regulators about such delays last fall, and the F.D.A. promised to do better. But now, delays are not the problem. Far fewer actions themselves are being taken, even though industry critics say they continue to see promotions that illegally market unapproved uses of a drug, understate risks, overstate benefits or make claims not backed up by studies, in an industry that is spending more than ever to promote its products. 
Until mid-June, when a reporter called to ask about the decline in enforcement actions, the F.D.A. had sent only four such regulatory letters this year. After that call, the agency issued four more letters. At that rate, it is now sending an average of fewer than two letters a month on promotions it says are illegal. That is down from about 10 letters a month, on average, from 1997 to 2000.
Critics, including members of Congress, former F.D.A. officials, lawyers, doctors and consumer groups, say they see a clear shift in how the agency is performing one of its main functions: policing the marketing of drugs, food and medical devices. The agency has become willing to let some problems slip by, these critics say, and to allow the companies it regulates to go further with their marketing claims.
"The core of the agency's mission has always been protecting the public's health," said William B. Schultz, a lawyer who was the F.D.A.'s deputy commissioner for policy from 1994 to 1998. "Now the agency is thinking about allowing other considerations that would undermine that."
Dr. Mark B. McClellan, the F.D.A. commissioner, defended his agency's efforts, saying in an interview that the decline in regulatory letters had begun in the Clinton administration and that it should not be taken to mean the agency had become less aggressive in enforcing drug marketing laws and regulations.
"We will be enforcing the law on misleading promotion," said Dr. McClellan, who took office eight months ago. "The F.D.A. does not let important public health problems slide."
Indeed, Dr. McClellan said that regulators were now trying to work more with drug companies before advertisements run to try to prevent misleading ads. He also said the F.D.A.'s enforcement decisions were affected in part by the outcome of several court cases in which the agency was found to have gone too far in trying to rein in corporate promotion of regulated products.
Dr. McClellan said the agency had decided that the lawyers in Mr. Troy's office should review each letter before it was sent to make sure it could withstand a court challenge by the drug company.
Mr. Schultz and others, however, say they are especially worried about a move by Mr. Troy last year to open up the agency's regulations to a wide-ranging review. The aim, the regulators say, was to ensure that the rules did not violate the First Amendment by going too far in restricting a company's right to tell the public about its products. Dozens of drug makers, food companies and businesses that market dietary supplements have provided written suggestions to the F.D.A. on how the rules should be rewritten so that they can more easily promote their products.
IN a 167-page response prepared by Pfizer, for example, the company said the F.D.A's current rules on prescription drug promotion had "led to a regime where manufacturers are precluded from using advertising for its intended purpose."
Pfizer's lawyers continued: "One has only to watch a laundry detergent ad to realize that the vendor does not have to disclose the stains that the detergent cannot remove in addition to the ones that it can." 
The review has delighted Mr. Troy's former clients. Before joining the F.D.A. in 2001, Mr. Troy was a private lawyer and prominent advocate of commercial free speech for clients that included tobacco and pharmaceutical companies. He brought two significant cases in which he argued that the F.D.A. had overstepped constitutional law.
In one, filed by the Washington Legal Foundation, a nonprofit conservative group, Mr. Troy contended that regulators were violating the First Amendment as they tried to prevent drug companies from telling doctors how their medicines could be used for conditions the drugs were not approved to treat.
Federal law states that drug companies cannot promote their products for unapproved uses. The approval process ensures that drug companies perform extensive studies to show their products are safe and effective for a condition before that use is promoted to the public.
But lawsuits like the one brought by Mr. Troy and the Washington Legal Foundation, which won a partial victory in court, have created gray areas in the rules. Since that lawsuit, for example, the agency has generally been allowing drug companies to distribute copies of published studies to doctors on the effectiveness of a drug in a certain area, even though those studies may include only small numbers of patients. The danger, according to critics of the practice, is that other studies, of which doctors might be unaware, could have found that the medicine did not work for that condition.
The agency said Mr. Troy declined to be interviewed for this article.
Peter Barton Hutt, a lawyer for food, pharmaceutical and other industries regulated by the F.D.A., said Mr. Troy was doing "superbly" in his job. 
Mr. Hutt, who was the F.D.A.'s chief counsel in the Nixon administration, said he believed that the agency had a new policy, although unwritten, to limit its enforcement actions so as to minimize the risk that a court could find that it had violated the First Amendment. "Clearly, their policy now is to apply the First Amendment," he said.
One of Mr. Hutt's clients, the Grocery Manufacturers of America, was the first to benefit from Mr. Troy's opening of regulations to a review.
In December, the F.D.A. took Mr. Hutt's advice, detailed in a 57-page submission, and changed guidelines to make it easier for food companies to make health claims about their products. Rather than requiring that a claim be backed by "significant scientific evidence," the F.D.A. will now allow qualified claims in which the science is still uncertain but the evidence supporting a claim outweighs the evidence opposing it.
Mr. Hutt used the example of omega-3 fatty acids, found in fish. Studies have shown that consuming these fatty acids may reduce the risk of coronary heart disease, though the evidence is not conclusive.
Dr. McClellan said the new food labeling guidelines would help consumers get more information about possible health benefits of certain products even though the science was not settled. "We want to see more of that type of information" on food labels, he said.
BUT some critics say that consumers are in danger of being misled by the new labels.
"The claims on labels that consumers see will no longer be as reliable," said Bruce Silverglade, director of legal affairs at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a nonprofit consumer group in Washington. "The consumer is the loser."
Mr. Silverglade noted that there had once been promising evidence that beta carotene supplements might reduce the risk of cancer. Studies in 1996, however, showed that beta carotene appeared to increase the risk of lung cancer in smokers.
Some lawyers for pharmaceutical companies say they expect the F.D.A. to make changes soon in drug promotion rules.
James M. Beck, a lawyer who represents pharmaceutical companies at Dechert, a law firm in Philadelphia, said he believed the F.D.A. had little choice but to open up its regulations to review because of several court cases it had lost. Last year, for example, the Supreme Court ruled that the First Amendment prevented the F.D.A. from stopping a pharmacy from advertising drugs it had made itself in a practice called compounding. The case was originally brought by the Western States Medical Center, a compounding pharmacy in Las Vegas.
"The decision is emboldening some people," Mr. Beck said. At a recent conference, he said he had been struck by how forthcoming some pharmaceutical executives had been in discussing the methods they were using to market products for unapproved uses.
Indeed, it is not hard to find companies spreading the word about ways their drugs can be used that have not been approved by the F.D.A.
Cephalon, a company in West Chester, Pa., recently paid for video and audio segments for use in newscasts to detail how its drug Provigil can be used to treat attention deficit disorder in children and depression in adults. The drug is approved to treat excessive daytime sleepiness associated with narcolepsy. The segments were distributed to hundreds of television and radio stations around the country.
"The advantage of Provigil over other drugs is that it will treat the symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder with fewer side effects," says a doctor in the video who was involved in a clinical trial of the drug. "This is all very exciting news for parents of children with A.D.H.D."
In an audio format distributed to radio stations, the announcer, sounding like a news anchor, says, "Depression is a serious illness, affecting more than 10 million Americans."
She adds that preliminary research data indicates that "Provigil, taken along with the antidepressants Paxil and Prozac, helped patients almost immediately."
Robert W. Grupp, a spokesman for Cephalon, said both segments were produced after scientists presented results from Provigil studies at a medical meeting. He said the company had paid for the videos to tell the public about important new scientific information concerning Provigil, and not to promote the drug.
"We can't promote off-label," he said. "We're very careful not to do that."
He said that about 75 percent of Provigil's sales were for unapproved uses.
PRODUCERS of videos like those made for Cephalon say that more local television stations have been incorporating them into their newscasts because of limited budgets in the sluggish economy.
Mr. Grupp said 2.5 million viewers had seen the videos about Provigil and attention deficit disorder -- a number the company considered small.
The drug companies have long used such video new releases. After the Senate challenged the practice in hearings in 1990, the F.D.A. told the drug companies that they should send a copy of each video news release to the agency for review, although the productions did not have to be approved in advance.
Brad Stone, a spokesman for the F.D.A., said the agency policy has not changed since then. Any video news release "that deals with the promotion of a drug would be subject to our jurisdiction," he said. "If we saw something that we thought was violative, we would take action."
He said he could not comment on Cephalon's videos specifically. 
Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said the F.D.A. could move drug regulation back 40 years, to a time when companies did not have to prove the effectiveness of the products they advertised, if it began allowing the promotion of unapproved uses.
Such a change, he said, "would be a terrible, terrible result that would lead to a lot of serious health risks."
But the drug industry and its lawyers say doctors need to know information about drugs that may be important for their patients.
Dr. McClellan said the F.D.A. had no plans to give the companies wide leeway to promote their products for unapproved uses. "We don't condone off-label promotion," he said.
He said, however, that he thought television ads used by the drug companies served a good purpose. They "help people who need treatment" by prompting them to see a doctor, he said.
The pharmaceutical industry spent $2.6 billion on consumer ads last year in the United States -- more than double the amount spent in 1998, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, which monitors advertising spending. 
But while the F.D.A. sent 158 regulatory letters in 1998 to companies about ads the agency found to be false or misleading, it sent only 26 last year.
Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the health research group at Public Citizen, the watchdog organization founded by Ralph Nader, said he was troubled by the decline in letters that began in 1999. "Regulation by the F.D.A. was already diminishing then," he said. But he called the more recent decline "really frightful." 
"Ads are running now that would not be allowed to run in 1998," Dr. Wolfe said. "The amount of damage done to consumers by these false and misleading ads is enormous."
Representative Waxman wrote to the agency last fall, stating that while the drop in enforcement actions "may be a welcome development for the drug industry," it "poses serious dangers to public health."
The number of complaints to the F.D.A. about false and misleading drug ads has not declined, Mr. Waxman said, even though the agency's drug marketing enforcement division -- which has 40 workers, 10 more than in 2000 -- has been taking far fewer actions against the companies. He said that from 1999 to 2001, the F.D.A. sent one warning letter for every 2.8 complaints about false advertising. But in the first six months of 2002, he said, it sent one letter for every 13.5 complaints.
Dr. Michael Wilkes, vice dean for education at the School of Medicine at the University of California at Davis, has studied prescription drug advertisements and said he had found more problems recently. The companies, he said, seem "willing to push the limits a bit."
"The current administration is not going to step in unless there are gross violations," he said. "The word has gotten out."
At Representative Waxman's request, Dr. Wilkes and other experts last fall reviewed some television ads and found dozens of problems.
For example, a commercial for Ambien, a sleeping pill that is a controlled substance because of its potential for abuse, includes a warning that states, "People who abuse sleep aids may develop addiction."
Dr. Wilkes said the warning was misleading because many viewers do not believe they will ever misuse pills. Anyone, he said, can develop an addiction.
Leslie Hare, a spokeswoman for the manufacturer, Sanofi-Synthelabo, said that that ad is no longer running for Ambien, although the F.D.A. had reviewed it. 
The F.D.A. has strengthened the rules for one product area: dietary supplements. After ephedra was cited in the death of Steve Bechler, a Baltimore Orioles pitcher, Dr. McClellan announced new rules to require that dietary supplements not be contaminated in manufacturing and be accurately labeled to reflect their ingredients. The changes, however, did nothing to tell consumers whether the supplements might be dangerous or if they worked.
THE F.D.A. has pleased drug makers on a different front, by announcing several efforts to help speed new medicines to market. Dr. McClellan said last week in a speech at a biotechnology industry conference that the agency was committed to reducing by at least 10 percent the total time it took regulators to review an experimental drug.
"Based on published estimates, a 10 percent reduction in regulatory review time reduces the total investment required to develop a new medication by over $12 million," Dr. McClellan said in the speech. "By shifting down the time and cost of developing new medications, patients will benefit from earlier and greater access to more safe and effective medications."
Dr. Len Lichtenfeld, deputy chief medical officer at the American Cancer Society, said he welcomed the change, as long as the agency is given the resources to do the faster reviews properly. 
"We need to look at the process carefully to make sure that drugs that are clearly beneficial to patients are not held up," he said.
But some consumer groups have begun to worry that the faster reviews could result in the approval of medicines that carry dangerous side effects or do not work.
Larry D. Sasich, a pharmacist and research analyst at Public Citizen, pointed to the F.D.A.'s recent approval of Iressa, a lung cancer drug. The agency approved Iressa in May even though the drug shrank tumors in just 10 percent of patients and has been linked to the deaths of more than 200 patients in Japan. 
"We're starting to get really concerned about what is happening at the F.D.A.," Mr. Sasich said. "Drugs are only as good as the regulators."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Slowing Down the Treadmill, With Help

BYLINE:  By LAURA KOSS-FEDER

 BODY:
ANNICK BAUDOT-MOHAGEG says she often had trouble saying no to her bosses and colleagues at Adobe Systems, which is probably why her workweek typically averaged 45 to 50 hours. Then her company cut its work force, and Ms. Baudot-Mohageg, a senior marketing manager, found herself feeling even more overworked, with little energy left for her husband, Michael, and son, Lucas.
 That was more than a year ago. She says she is feeling much less frazzled these days, having participated in the last year in a mentoring program sponsored by Adobe, which is based in San Jose, Calif. The program -- intended, among other things, to help better budget time -- included monthly workshops with other women executives and one-on-one meetings with her own mentor from outside Adobe. 
 Ms. Baudot-Mohageg, 40, says she has learned to focus on details of projects that are relevant only to her, rather than trying to do other people's work for them, and to conduct staff meetings more efficiently. As a result, she estimates, her productivity has increased by about 50 percent. She says she also has more time to spend with her family. "Mentoring helped me set objectives in my life," she said. 
Thirty-five executive women have participated in the Adobe program since its inception four years ago, according to Angela Szymusiak, a human resources manager at the company. Adobe does not have specific data on the results. But in informal surveys, the participants said -- and their superiors agreed -- that they were more productive, better able to organize their assignments and more confident as decision makers, she said.
Recognizing the dueling demands on working women, and looking to improve productivity, more companies have been offering mentoring programs like the one sponsored by Adobe, or modifying their executive coaching programs to better suit the needs of women who are managers. Some other companies that have adopted mentoring or coaching programs include Texas Instruments, Verizon Communications and Marriott International.
Many women must care for children or aging parents, or both, sometimes in addition to increased responsibilities at work because of job cuts. Many of those cuts occurred after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, put new strain on a sluggish economy.
FORTY-FOUR percent of professional women surveyed recently said they have felt more stress at home and on the job since 9/11, and about 60 percent said they had little emotional strength left for life outside the office. The survey, of 561 women, was conducted by WorldWIT, an online networking organization of professional women in technology and business, and GLS Consulting of Brookline, Mass.; the results were released last winter.
Liz Ryan, WorldWIT's founder and chief executive, said she was concerned that "this increased level of stress could translate into lost productivity in the workplace if they are just too tired, distracted and unenthusiastic about their jobs."
Jean M. Otte, the founder and president of Women Unlimited in Manhattan, a company that provides leadership development programs for women, agreed. "These professional women are not going to be effective leaders if they keep running like hamsters on a wheel; they're either going to the kids' soccer matches, sending their bosses e-mails at midnight or thinking about doing one or the other," she said. Ms. Otte's company creates programs, including mentoring, at large companies like Adobe. Over the past year, she said, her client list has grown by 30 percent.
Companies in general are devoting larger portions of their human resources budgets to hiring professional coaches -- an estimated 25 percent more than they did five years ago, according to Gail E. Aldrich, the senior vice president for member services at the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va.
At the financial services firm Ernst & Young, executive women who serve clients participate in the Women's Partner Leadership Alliance and Network, a six-year-old company program that includes mentoring and coaching. The company is also the host for discussion groups. Deborah K. Holmes, who oversees the program and is the director of Ernst & Young's Center for the New Workforce, which is dedicated to advancing the careers of women in the firm, estimates that the initiatives help save the company about $12 million annually by reducing turnover.
Carolyn Libretti, 37, a senior manager in the international tax services department at Ernst & Young in Manhattan, said she certainly found them useful. Last year, she said, she met with a coach twice a month, from March through December, to help her manage her time while she worked on a major tax restructuring project for a client. She had to coordinate the work of more than 100 employees in 42 countries, and she often put in 14-hour days. 
"I learned how to delegate more, so that I didn't feel like I had to do it all myself," she said of the coaching sessions. "And I learned how to look outside of the office and take part in more of my personal interests, which just made me feel better." She has managed to cut her workweek by five or six hours, she added, and even enroll in an interior-design certification program outside the office. "I actually became more focused at work because of all this," she said.
Ms. Baudot-Mohageg, the executive from Adobe, says that because the company's mentoring program has made her more efficient on the job, she now has more time and energy to do the things she enjoys outside the office. She says she spends about an hour a week assisting in the physical education class of her son, Lucas, who is 8. And at the end of the day, she said, "instead of just watching television and vegging after work because I was so wiped out, I now have the energy to communicate in a meaningful, relaxed waywith my husband and son."
But what about women whose companies do not provide coaching or mentoring services? Experts suggest seeking out mentors in their own companies or even hiring professional coaches themselves. The International Coach Federation, a professional group based in Washington (www.coachfederation.org), offers a free referral service.
Women can also join or create their own networking groups. Kim Merkin, 39, of Lafayette, Calif., began a group called EBUG, or East Bay United Gals, with four friends about a year ago. Ms. Merkin, an executive at a trade show exhibit company, said long hours on the job had given her little time to socialize, and she often felt isolated. 
The group, described by Ms. Merkin as "the book club without the books," now has 44 members in different professions who meet every other month in someone's home after work. Each gathering has a theme.
"We've had a chocolate party one time, a picnic another time, and a clay-sculpting party on another occasion," Ms. Merkin said. "When I have a really long day, this gives me something special to look forward to after work and I feel so much more connected to other women and my community as a whole."
Online networking is another outlet. WorldWIT, for example, has discussion groups and allows its members to post messages on the organization's Web site, www.worldwit.org. Another site, www.bluesuitmom.com, provides tips on how to balance professional and home life. It also helps users form groups of working mothers to socialize within their neighborhoods through message boards.
"Parenting and mothering groups in any form are a good way to exchange ideas and partner with one another -- to help out with things like picking up each other's children from day care when you need an extra hand," said Marcia Brumit Kropf, the vice president for research and information services at Catalyst, a national organization that studies trends involving women's roles in business. "Professional women need these kinds of networks more and more these days."
Beth Bull, the treasurer of Texas Instruments, says she has participated in coaching programs at her company over the years, and she also remains active in two women's groups outside the company. She and the other members organize activities like dinners and movies at least once a month and exchange tips on balancing their time. After Sept. 11, she said, her priorities changed.
One day last fall, instead of arriving at her Dallas office at her usual time of 8 a.m., Ms. Bull joined her son, Adam, 9, on an in-line skating jaunt to his elementary school. "I raced back home after dropping him off, fixed myself up, and just made it to my 10 a.m. meeting," Ms. Bull said, with a laugh. "I would have never done something like that prior to 9/11."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Women CallFrom Home, Men From Everywhere Else

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
When it comes to cellphones, men rule the airwaves -- not to mention the sidewalks, trains and airports. According to a survey of 1,040 cellphone users by Cingular Wireless, men talk 14 percent more on cellphones than women. 
While women this year go wireless an average of 377 minutes a month, men drone on for 438 minutes -- and always, to judge by their tone, about Very Important Things.
 At home, though, women still rule the receiver: they talk 551 minutes a month, the survey says, versus just 314 for men. 
 Oddly, the survey shows men talking less this year, but a Cingular spokesman says this is just a quirk of this sampling -- that the trend is talk, talk and more talk. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Major Indexes Fall as Investors Grab Profits

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
The three major market indexes dropped last week as investors took profits after a long run-up in prices -- and as the end of the quarter approached.
 The market was treading water on Monday and Tuesday. 
Stocks declined sharply on Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, disappointing traders who had expected a larger cut. On Thursday, the market rebounded, only to sink again on Friday. 
 Altria rose 4.9 percent for the week, the biggest gain among the Dow industrials. A federal appeals court in Virginia ruled on Tuesday that Philip Morris USA, an Altria unit, did not illegally keep competitors' brands from prominent display in stores.
 Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, rose 18.3 percent, the biggest gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The company rejected a takeover bid.
 For the week, the Dow fell 211.70 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 8,989.05. The S.& P. 500 fell 19.47 points, or 2 percent, to close at 976.22. The Nasdaq composite index fell 19.46 points, or 1.2 percent, to close at 1,625.26. In the bond market, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 3.58 percent from 3.36 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Beautiful Minds; 
Pure Math, Pure Joy

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE

 BODY:
A mathematician, the Hungarian lover of numbers Paul Erdos once said, is a device for converting coffee into theorems. Here, then, are a few glimpses into the Truth Factory. The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute, sustained mostly by the National Science Foundation, sits on a hill above the University of California at Berkeley, where it attracts people from around the world for stints of up to a year to lose themselves in subjects like algebraic geometry or special holonomy. 
 Consider it an embassy of another world, a Platonic realm of clarity and beauty, of forms and relations, where the answers to questions not yet asked already exist. 
 Higher mathematics -- as opposed to what we do every April 15 -- has been relevant ever since Archimedes leaped out of his bath shouting "Eureka!" more than 2,000 years ago. Nobody knows when some abstruse bit of math will float off a blackboard at a place like this and become -- often decades later -- a key tool in cryptography, biology, physics or economics (as in "A Beautiful Mind").
Take string theory, a mathematically labyrinthine effort to construct a so-called theory of everything out of the notion that the fundamental elements of nature are tiny strings flopping and wriggling in an 11-dimensional space-time. It has been called a piece of 21st-century physics that fell by accident into the 20th century.
In their quest to negotiate this labyrinth, string theorists have made a hot topic of something called Riemann surfaces, invented by the German mathematician Georg Friedrich Bernhard Riemann 150 years ago, but they have also helped blaze new fields of mathematics. 
"Since our theories are so far ahead of experimental capabilities, we are forced to use mathematics as our eyes," Dr. Brian Greene, a Columbia University string theorist, said recently. "That's why we follow it where it takes us even if we can't see where we're going."
So in some ways the men and women seen here scrutinizing marks on their blackboards collectively represent a kind of particle accelerator of the mind.
But the "unreasonable effectiveness" of mathematics in explaining the world, as the physicist Eugene Wigner once put it, is a minor motivation at best for those immersed in the field. Most mathematicians say they are in it for the math itself, for the delirious quest for patterns, the thrill of the detective chase and the lure of beautiful answers.
"Math is sense," said Dr. Robert Osserman, a Stanford professor and deputy director of the institute, quoting from the play "Copenhagen." "That's what sense is."

(Photographs by Ed Alcock for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action: A Corporate Diary; 
From Coffee to Keynote

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER

 BODY:
Anthony Chan has no doubts or concerns about policies that may have helped him land where he is.
 "I was able to take advantage of many different opportunities available that some might characterize as affirmative action," Mr. Chan said. Some of the programs were very competitive, he said, like a summer program for minority college students run by the American Economics Association. 
 "When you're picking 25 out of the entire United States, it's not exactly open enrollment," said Mr. Chan, who is Chinese and Puerto Rican. 
Mr. Chan, 46, lives in Columbus, Ohio, and is senior managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, a unit of Bank One. He has traveled around the country and the world to make presentations on the state of the American economy. It is a long way from what he called his "humble beginnings" in East New York, where he grew up. In his view, policies that help other kids find new opportunities are essential.
"Many of the neighborhoods that we grow up in don't always offer the greatest opportunities unless we get a little help," said Mr. Chan, a graduate of Baruch College who received his Ph.D. in economics at the University of Maryland. "I think I did receive a sufficient amount of help that I was able to blossom," he said, adding, "I don't carry any stigma."
Of course, there are still occasional reminders that people make incorrect assumptions about him based on what he looks like, Mr. Chan said. He described how, before he was to make a presentation on the economy to several hundred people, a woman in the audience asked him to get her a cup of coffee.
"If that's not a reminder, I don't know what is," Mr. Chan said. He handled the situation by getting the coffee and even asking the woman if she wanted sugar. He then proceeded to give the keynote address.
"The people at the bank came back and many of them repeat this story to this day," he said. "You grow from these experiences, and you don't let them weigh you down." JONATHAN D. GLATER

HEADLINE: COPING; 
For a Young Striver, a Moment in the Sun

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS; E-mail: amh@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ON Wednesday, somewhere between Martin Luther King Jr. High School on West 66th Street and Little Africa in Central Harlem, you might have seen Allassane Coulibaly, who graduated third in his 170-member class from King that morning.
 At dinnertime, he was still wearing his pinstriped slacks and white dress shirt, which billowed, untucked and unbuttoned, over his thin frame in the wilting heat. But after having long been teased by his classmates for wearing cheap clothes, he was in no hurry to take off his good clothes. 
 In preparation for a small party in his honor, Allassane chased three barefoot little cousins out of his family's fourth-floor walkup, a railroad flat on Eighth Avenue and 114th Street. He served frosty glasses of water to his mother's friends as they came to wish him "Felicitations!" 
 Ten years after arriving in New York from the Ivory Coast, his mother, who braids hair on West 125th Street, still speaks mainly French and Mandingo. His father, who used to work as a chauffeur for an Ivory Coast politician, drives a truck here. Neither went to high school. 
 Allassane is 19, a year behind where he would be back home because he joined his parents here two years ago speaking no English. He is the oldest of five children, but having been separated from his parents for a decade, he finds it hard to call them Mom and Dad.
 At King, the first thing Allassane noticed was that Ibrahima Bah, last year's valedictorian, was, like him, West African, from Senegal. Allassane attached himself to Ibrahima, hoping to learn his secrets. In his living room, which is jammed with two couches, a Dell computer and a big canvas bag of jasmine rice, Allassane pulled out a treasured possession, the vocabulary flashcards Ibrahima passed down to him. These cards, along with television and immersion courses at school, helped him learn English.
 In Abidjan, where the French colonial tradition prevailed, students never wrote an essay with small words where big words would do. In New York, the teachers crossed out his big words and substituted simple ones. The only exception was Miss Cohen, who called him a risk taker, celebrated his love of words while nudging his usage, and cared enough to give him her personal e-mail address. 
 Ibrahima told Allassane that if he wanted to go to a good college, he had to do volunteer work. "How do you do all those community involvement and still excel in school?" Allassane wondered. Still, he found an unpaid job last summer filing papers at St. Luke's Hospital while spending four days a week in Upward Bound, a college-prep program.
Allassane's father wanted his son to spend his time studying and caring for his younger siblings. Allassane's classmates, many of whom were working in dead-end jobs to pay for the latest jeans and sneakers, teased him for working without pay. They accused him of acting white, and speculated that he was gay. "I wore simple shirts, small sneakers," he said. "I can say that it paid off. All the money they used to pay for clothes to show off, now they are struggling to go to college."
 Allassane has been accepted at Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., on a full tuition scholarship. Not averse to money, he aspires to be a banker like Alassane Ouattara, a prominent Ivory Coast economist who almost exactly shares his first name.
 He shrugs at the furor over this year's Regents math exam required for graduation, the results of which were voided after teachers complained it was too hard. Whatever flaws the test might have had, Allassane passed with a 78. 
 One of his classmates scored 98 on the test after arriving from Mali in the middle of senior year. But she has no green card, so she couldn't apply for a scholarship. Instead she will go to CUNY. "If you used to do very well back there, you can excel here," Allassane says. "Even if you didn't do very well back there and you put yourself into it, you can do very good here." 
 He is not naive. He knows that the achievement of the West African and Caribbean immigrants who make up almost all the top graduates is impressive only compared with the performance of poor and disadvantaged native-born children who have attended failing public schools all their lives. 
 As his apartment grew noisy with well-wishers, Allassane excused himself and walked with a visitor to nearby Morningside Park. "Bonsoir," he greeted strangers from Senegal and Guinea who were promenading with their families. 
 Instead of playing basketball on the street, he strives for something higher. Most nights, he climbs the hill to Columbia University to play pickup soccer on campus. There, he meets and often defeats college kids from across America. In the fall he will be one.

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
The Leasing of Lot 116

BYLINE:  By TOM VANDERBILT; Tom Vanderbilt is the author of "Survival City: Adventures Among the Ruins of Atomic America."

 BODY:
EVEN by the skewed parameters of New York real estate, in which people have been known to do astonishing things with scant outpourings of square footage, Lot 116 confounds the imagination.
 Nestled in a graffiti-scarred alleyway off Woodward Avenue in a quiet residential section of Ridgewood, Queens, Lot 116 runs nearly the length of the alley, a respectable 355 feet. Like all great New York real estate deals, however, it comes with a catch: The width is two feet, three inches. 
 Lot 116 is what the City Planning Department calls, colloquially at least, a sliver space. These minute, almost useless fragments of land, peculiar topographical gerrymanderings located on the periphery of or dead-smack in the middle of other properties, are found in every borough and are typically owned by the city. The value is usually zero dollars. 
 "These properties are created by surveyors' errors or were simply residual lots when the original subdivisions were created," said Warner Johnston, a spokesman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. For example, the city may have condemned 10 inches of land running along a property for a new street, but that street was never built. "So technically we own 10 inches of that building or lot," Mr. Johnston said. "It just kind of sits in our portfolio."
 (A number of sliver spaces, not including Lot 116, will be sold July 23 at auction in the Javits Center.)
 As it happens, Lot 116 does have a temporary owner, one who hopes to make it a permanent acquisition at auction next year. A number of months ago, Cabinet magazine, a small quarterly cultural journal, published out of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, petitioned the city to buy a number of these microparcels. 
 "The city has an auction in July, but we just missed the deadline," said Sina Najafi, Cabinet's editor. "They said, 'Why don't you lease them?"' And so for $125 a month, enough to cover the city's administrative costs, Cabinet is the proud renter of 10 of these properties, perhaps the largest small-property empire ever assembled in Gotham.
 Cabinet was not the first entity to own these 10 parcels, and indeed it was a kind of homage to their previous owner that sent them into the city's archives to pore over tax maps and sort through dusty records. The parcels, as they knew well, were bought at auction in 1973 by the conceptual artist Gordon Matta-Clark. He paid $25 per property.
 Matta-Clark, who died in 1978 at age 35, was a legendary presence in 1970's New York, a trained architect who channeled his artistic energy into taking buildings apart, literally and figuratively. His 1975 work "Day's End," which involved the strategic (and covert) removal of parts of the infrastructure of the abandoned Pier 52 on the West Side of Manhattan, rather shocked city officials and got him arrested. In "Bronx Floors: Four-Way Wall" he cut out symmetrical segments of four intersecting walls, from four different apartments, in a condemned Bronx tenement -- "This Old House" re-envisioned by M.C. Escher. In "Splitting," he miter-sawed his way through a condemned house in Englewood, N.J., perfectly bisecting it. "Why hang things on the wall when the wall itself is so much more a challenging medium?" he said in an interview recounted in a new book, "Gordon Matta-Clark" (Phaidon).
 The microproperties were bought for inclusion in something called "Reality Properties: Fake Estates." This work, never shown in Matta-Clark's lifetime, featured a property deed, a photograph and, as Matta-Clark put it, "perhaps a list of weeds growing there." In her book "Object to Be Destroyed," Pamela Lee says that Matta-Clark envisioned that the property itself would become part of the artwork. Not that the "owner" would necessarily be able to spend much time there, because as the artist described the project to one interviewer:
 "When I bought these parcels at the New York City auction, the description of them that always excited me the most was 'inaccessible.' What I basically wanted to do was designate spaces that wouldn't be seen and certainly not occupied. Buying them was my own take on the strangeness of existing property demarcation lines. Property is so all pervasive. Everyone's notion of ownership is determined by the use factor."
 After Matta-Clark died, his estate stopped paying taxes on the properties, and they reverted to the city, where they sat until the editors at Cabinet, Matta-Clark fans all, wondered aloud at one staff meeting what had ever become of them. And so the editors were led into one of the stranger corners of the urban fabric. One microparcel, Mr. Najafi noted, had simply been transferred back and forth many times between the members of a family named Cohen. 
 AN associate editor, Christine Potts, spent hours driving through Queens in search of the little plots. They are marked only on the map, unknown even to the landowners whose properties they abut. One parcel, Lot 160, is simply a strip of land lying between the sidewalk and a fence, in the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Another, called the outhouse because of the boxlike fence that surrounds it, is actually stranded, like a wrong puzzle piece, at the confluence of several backyards. More than once Ms. Potts's investigations aroused the suspicion of neighbors. 
 "We got stopped by a guy warming up his Mercedes," she said. "We said, 'We're waiting for someone' -- this in an alleyway. People were looking out their windows."
 Cabinet has invited artists to propose projects, speculative and actual, to occupy the parcels (the results are published in the magazine's spring issue). For the alleyway in Queens, where cars are routinely parked on the lot now leased by Cabinet, an artist has proposed installing a row of parking meters. 
 "This guy would like to install parking meters and take the money to buy this piece of land in Harlem he's been dying to get," Mr. Najafi said. "But how could he enforce it?"
 Another artist envisions putting a lone mailbox on a thin strip of Queens land. "If we ever put that up, I'd love to send mail out there," Mr. Najafi said, "but a lot of these things don't have addresses." 
 Now that he has acquired, temporarily at least, these 10 parcels, Mr. Najafi feels that he can relate to another motive that Matta-Clark expressed in his project, one Mr. Najafi learned of only recently from Jane Crawford, the artist's widow. 
 "She said that Gordon always wanted to be a gentleman, and owning land was a very gentlemanly thing to do," Mr. Najafi said. "His piece was critical of certain ways in which land was made into property, but there was this whole other psychological level as well."
 Mr. Najafi noted that a number of people in the art world had since learned of the leasing of Matta-Clark's parcels, and had expressed interest in ownership. 
 "We want everyone to know about the project because it's kind of cool," he said, "but by next July we might be bidding against people who have a lot more money than us." Asked about a possible bidding war's rocking the dormant world of microparcels, Mr. Johnston of the city's administrative services agency had an instant answer: "Well, anything that generates more revenue, especially during these hard economic times, is always a benefit."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Test of Time; 
Fixing the Race Gap in 25 Years or Less

BYLINE:  By STEVEN A. HOLMES and GREG WINTER

 BODY:
THE Supreme Court decision upholding affirmative action in university admissions seemed to carry an expiration date. "We expect that 25 years from now the use of racial preferences will no longer be necessary to further the interest approved today," Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote in her 5-to-4 majority opinion last week.
 While the justices have in the past said that affirmative action should not be used forever, never before has a justice placed a specific time limit on it. Having now done so, Justice O'Connor has raised tough questions, both broad and specific. 
 Are her views merely idle musings, or will they become an iron-clad legal principle? Should the goal be parity in graduation rates of white, black and Hispanic high school students? Or should it be equality in financing between poor school districts, which tend to have more minority students, and middle-class white ones? Can the gap between black and white students on the SAT be bridged in the next generation? 
In The Chicago Tribune, Justice O'Connor said in a rare interview that the country can tackle many of these challenges. "I hope it looks as though we don't need artificial help to fill our classrooms with highly qualified students at the graduate level," she said. "And if we do our job on educating young people, we can reach that goal."
But closing the disparities in educational achievement and opportunities for college applicants across racial and ethnic lines will involve vociferous debate over the relative importance of school financing, social inequality and student study habits. 
Statistics tell the story. On every major indicator of academic success -- the SAT, the A.C.T. and the National Assessment of Educational Progress (given to elementary and secondary students) -- the gap between white and minority students has persisted for decades. Though it narrowed somewhat on the national assessment exams from the 1980's through the early 90's, the divide has only widened since then. 
"There is some serious heavy lifting to do before we get to the dream scenario Justice O'Connor is envisioning," said Chester E. Finn Jr., president of the Thomas B. Fordham Foundation and an assistant secretary of education in the Reagan administration.
Some liberals say the gap can be closed only by equalizing the amount of money spent on educating whites and minorities. The school districts that many blacks and Hispanics attend spend $902 less per student on average than mostly white districts, according to a national study conducted last year by the Education Trust, a group focused on closing the achievement gap.
To some degree, federal and state governments can, and do, try to fix this imbalance by sending more money to schools serving poor -- and, by extension, disproportionately minority -- students. Federal assistance for poor students is increasing, and state governments gave an average of $27 more per pupil to disproportionately minority schools in 2000 than to predominately white schools, though that hardly had a perceptible impact on the financing gap. 
But even if federal and state lawmakers were bent on eliminating the financial discrepancies between white and minority districts, they couldn't have much affect. On average, states and the federal government have never accounted for more than 56 percent of schools' revenues over the last decade or so; the remainder has come from local sources, mostly property taxes. This financial structure makes parity unlikely at best. 
And conservatives argue that the focus on financial parity misses the point, and point to some minority-dominated city school districts that have high spending per student but still lag well behind less flush districts, particularly in rural areas. 
Moreover, educational parity may be linked to bigger, more complex economic factors. Most beneficiaries of affirmative action are middle-income. According to a study by Anthony Carnevale, vice president of the Educational Testing Service, 74 percent of students at the 146 most prestigious colleges and universities -- where competition for admissions is most intense and where affirmative action is practiced -- come from families in the top 25 percent of the nation's socioeconomic scale (as measured by income, educational attainment and occupations of the parents). Only 3 percent of the students at these highly selective schools come from the bottom 25 percent of the socioeconomic scale. As Lani Guinier, a law professor at Harvard University, puts it, "affirmative action is less an escalator up than it is a bridge across."
But even middle-class black and Hispanic children who are burdened with issues of crime, troubled homes and poor schools have not been able to close the test-score gap with their white counterparts.
"The gap persists across all income levels," said Freeman Hrabowski, president of the University of Maryland at Baltimore County, who has written extensively on improving the academic achievement of black students. "We're talking about generations of habits in too many homes," said Mr. Hrabowski, who is black. "Unfortunately, reading is not the No. 1 priority as a habit. There is much more emphasis on television watching."
Both sides on the affirmative action issue agree on the need to close the education gap, but not much else. Some supporters of affirmative action hope that Justice O'Connor's 25-year time frame will protect affirmative action while the country makes headway in closing that rift. 
But the decision last week does not invalidate laws in California and Washington State that ban the use of race in public university admissions, hiring and government contracting. Ward Connerly, the black California businessman who was the force behind passing those laws, has already vowed to make Michigan his next target.
Demographic pressures will also come into play. The Educational Testing Service estimates that from 1995 to 2015, the percentage of whites on college campuses will decline from 71 percent to 63 percent, while Hispanics will increase to 15 percent, from the current 11 percent, with blacks holding steady at 13 percent.
But with minorities making up a larger proportion of students going to college -- and with the children of young immigrants approaching college age toward the end of Justice O'Connor's 25-year target -- Hispanic and black parents may be clamoring even more forcefully that their children not be shut out of top schools. 
In the end, the debate has not changed. Opponents of affirmative action will continue to say that such programs keep the country from focusing on what needs to be done -- namely, helping minority students meet higher standards. The supporters of race preferences counter that the country cannot end affirmative action without first fixing the education system. All agree that unless a commitment is made -- by society and minority families themselves -- the old arguments will still be around in 25 years.
Lisa Navarette, vice president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic advocacy group, said, "If all we do over the 25 years is affirmative action, then we will still need affirmative action."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 6, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A timeline last Sunday recalling moments in the history of affirmative action referred incorrectly to a body formed under the Kennedy administration by Executive Order 10925. It was the Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity, not the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission. (The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is an agency created by Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.)

(Yuli Wu for The New York Times)(pg. 1); Diversity, 2002: The University of Michigan Law School defended its policy of considering race in its admissions. (Yuli Wu for The New York Times); (United Press International); (Associated Press)(pg. 14) Chart: "Affirmative Actions: The selective history of an American idea" March 6, 1961 -- President John F. Kennedy issues Executive Order 10925, which introduces the term "affirmative action" and creates the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission. July 2, 1964 -- President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act, which, among other things, outlaws discrimination in federal programs. September 1969 -- The Nixon administration develops the Philadelphia Plan, which requires contractors on federally supported projects to set minority hiring goals. 1975 -- The Harvard sociologist Nathan Glazer publishes "Affirmative Discrimination," a critique of racial preferences. 1977 -- The Public Works Employment Act provides $4 billion for projects in distressed areas. Ten percent of the money is reserved for minority businesses. June 28, 1978 -- In Regents of the University of California v. Bakke, the Supreme Court, by a 5 to 4 majority, strikes down the racial quota system of the University of California at Davis medical school. Allan M. Bakke, a white applicant who said he was passed over by the school in favor of less qualified minority applicants, is admitted. Dec. 16, 1985 -- The Justice Department fights employment quotas in federal court, supporting white firefighters and members of the engineering department of Birmingham, Ala., who say they were passed over for promotion in favor of blacks. June 23, 1989 -- In City of Richmond v. Croson, the Supreme Court strikes down a plan that set aside 30 percent of contracts for minority-owned companies. The court calls affirmative action a "highly suspect tool," which must be subject to "strict scrutiny." 1990 -- In "The Content of Our Character," Shelby Steele, a black scholar and essayist, argues against affirmative action. 1991 -- Stephen L. Carter's book "Reflections of an Affirmative Action Baby" outlines the personal costs that beneficiaries of affirmative action face. March 18, 1996 -- In Hopwood v. University of Texas Law School, the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit suspends an affirmative action admissions program, outlawing any preferences based on race. Nov. 5, 1996 -- With a strong push by Ward Connerly, a University of California regent, Californians pass Proposition 209, which forbids any consideration of race, sex or national origin in hiring or school admissions. April 6, 1998 -- Nathan Glazer says in a magazine article that he now supports affirmative action, arguing that the failure to integrate institutions would "undermine the legitimacy of American democracy." Dec. 3, 1998 -- Washington State voters eliminate all preferential treatment based on race or sex in government hiring and school admissions. June 23, 2003 -- The Supreme Court upholds the affirmative action program at the University of Michigan law school, but strikes down the university's undergraduate system that awarded extra points to minority students. (pg. 14)

HEADLINE: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 226th Session 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY 

 BODY:
The 226th annual session of the New York State Legislature ended on June 20, a day later than it was scheduled to, after a flurry of last-minute negotiations that stretched into the early hours but failed to resolve disputes over several major bills.
 The tempestuous finish of the regularly scheduled session capped an unusual year in which the Senate's Republican majority and the Assembly's Democratic majority banded together in May and passed a $92.8 billion budget over Gov. George E. Pataki's vetoes. 
 It was not only the first time in two decades that the Legislature had brushed aside a governor to enact its own spending plan, but it was also the first time in modern memory that the lawmakers approved increases to the sales and income taxes despite the governor's opposition. Mr. Pataki's relationship with his fellow Republicans in the Senate was severely strained. 
The cooperation between the Senate and the Assembly fell apart toward the end of the session, and several important bills on which compromises were possible and, in some cases, imminent were left stranded. Among these was a bill to refinance the state's program for cleaning up toxic waste sites and to create incentives for developers to build on abandoned industrial sites.
Efforts to forge a compromise on how to reduce the mandatory sentences for drug crimes also fell flat, as did a bill to make lobbyists seeking state contracts disclose their clients and expenses. The Legislature did not reach agreements on renewing a law to regulate where power plants are built.
Neither did lawmakers pass a bill to reduce fraud in the auto insurance industry, a problem that has been driving up premiums. Bills to reform the state's outdated budget process died as well. So did a bill that would have saved money in the Medicaid program by requiring people to use a list of inexpensive drugs unless they had state approval for more expensive medications.
Perhaps the most important bill to pass this year was a statewide ban on smoking in the workplace. The Senate and the Assembly also agreed to ban the dietary supplement ephedra. The Legislature approved increased penalties for sexual assault, at the same time removing from the state's laws outdated references to "sodomy" and "deviant sexual behavior," a change that gay rights groups sought.
Lawmakers also passed a bill stiffening penalties for filming people in private places without their knowledge. Another bill that was enacted made it illegal to discriminate in housing or employment against New Yorkers serving in the military. The bill also gives people in the service new benefits.
For New York City residents, partisan bickering in the session's final days produced an eight-year extension of state rent laws. Many tenants saw this as a defeat because it kept rules that have let landlords deregulate thousands of apartments.
The Legislature also voted in the wee hours on June 20 to allow for a water filtration plant to be built in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, giving Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg a victory but angering many residents of the borough.
In the end, both houses of the Legislature passed 761 bills, with most of them addressing narrow local issues like property transfers and taxing authority for cities and towns. Mr. Pataki has signed 83. He vetoed 119 lines in the appropriation bills, as well as the omnibus bill enacting new taxes and other changes to support the budget. He also rejected a bill that would have extended the date for holding school budget votes and an aid package for New York City. All the vetoes were overridden.

Budget

LEGISLATION ENACTED
It was a raucous and historic budget battle in Albany this year, pitting the legislative branch against the executive branch, a fight that sapped both sides' energy and led to a remarkably unproductive end of the session.
For the first time in two decades, the Legislature overrode a governor's vetoes of its spending plan. The lawmakers revived their budget, which increased state sales and income taxes to restore billions of dollars in spending on schools, hospitals, nursing homes and local governments. In the end, the lawmakers passed a $92.8 billion budget on May 15, handing Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, the biggest governing loss in his career. He fought back, however, saying the Legislature's budget was larger than lawmakers claimed, was unbalanced and would worsen the state's financial crisis, the worst since the Great Depression.
Mr. Pataki maintains that the enacted budget will actually cost about $94.4 billion, a 3.9 percent increase over last year, but legislative leaders have stood by their $92.8 billion figure, which would amount to a 2 percent increase in spending.
The truth is that both the original $90.8 billion plan that the governor proposed, on Jan. 29, and the final plan the Legislature enacted were each flawed, independent fiscal watchdogs and budget experts on both sides of the political aisle said.
To help close a projected $11.5 billion deficit, both relied on billions of dollars in one-time revenues and on $4.2 billion in borrowing backed by future payments from tobacco companies from a nationwide court settlement.
As a result, the state is already facing a deficit of at least $5 billion as legislators are heading into an election year, budget analysts have said. Making the problem worse, the state's highest court ordered the Legislature last week to spend more on New York City schools.
The personal income tax increase was sold by state lawmakers as merely a surcharge on the amount of taxable income a family earns above a certain level. But for people in high-income brackets, it was a tax increase on all their taxable earnings, a detail that did not emerge quickly in opaque Albany.
The state sales tax went up one-quarter of a percentage point on June 1. A few days later, the city sales tax rose by one-eighth of a percentage point, meaning that New York City residents pay a combined sales tax of 8.625 instead of 8.25 percent.
An aid package for New York City also figured prominently in this year's debate. There again, the Assembly and Senate rolled over Mr. Pataki, adopting legislation on May 19 worth $1.79 billion to the city, after negotiations among Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the state's two top legislative leaders and the City Council.
Many analysts complained, however, that all the Legislature succeeded in doing was to approve a way to let the already fiscally winded city increase taxes on sales and income to help solve its $3.8 billion deficit and stave off the severe layoffs the mayor had threatened under a so-called doomsday budget.
Lots of new taxes and fees on obscure items were tucked away in both the state budget and the plan for the city. One example is that New York City residents got a backdoor cigarette-tax increase, because the state will now collect its cigarette tax not just on the price of the cigarettes, but on the price after figuring in the city's tobacco tax. That was seen as a quiet way to raise an extra $11 million without raising the tax rate.

Crime, Justice and Security

LEGISLATION ENACTED
Makes secretly filming people in places where they expect privacy, like a bedroom, a felony. The law against so-called video voyeurism is called Stephanie's Law, named after Stephanie M. Fuller, 29, of Bay Shore, on Long Island, who was secretly videotaped by a landlord.
As part of the budget, the date on which the blood alcohol content that constitutes drunkenness for drivers will be lowered to 0.08 percent from 0.10 percent has been moved up. The change, originally scheduled to go into effect on Nov. 1, was moved to July 1, allowing the state to collect millions of dollars more in federal funds.

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would increase the minimum sentence for some teenagers convicted of second-degree murder to 7 1/2-to-15 years, from 5-to-9 years. The bill, known as Penny's Law, was prompted by the killing of Penny Lea Brown, 39, of Salamanca, N.Y.
Would require the state's Office of Public Security to evaluate and report on security measures being taken to protect the state's power plants, including nuclear plants, transmission lines and hubs, from terrorist attacks. It would allow the State Public Service Commission to order all of the plants, except the nuclear plants, to enhance security.
Would amend the Sexual Assault Reform Act of 2000, creating new crimes, like persistent sexual abuse, and providing greater protection for sexually abused spouses. It would also toughen penalties for using date-rape drugs and eliminate obsolete terms like sodomy and deviant sexual behavior.

LEGISLATION FAILED
For the third straight year, New York's top two legislative leaders failed to break a protracted deadlock with Governor Pataki over changing the state's penalties. Proposed legislation would have eased the Rockefeller-era drug law penalties, and made drug treatment available more often as an alternative to prison.
Would have required members of the clergy to report to social workers or to police any allegations of sexual abuse.

Housing

LEGISLATION ENACTED
Extends rent laws for eight more years for tenants in more than 1 million rent-stabilized apartments, primarily in New York City, and strengthens existing regulations that allow landlords to charge market rates for their apartments once the monthly rent reaches $2,000.

Business and Labor

LEGISLATION ENACTED
As part of the budget, allows state liquor stores to stay open on Sundays. Repeals the so-called Blue Law and requires stores to close on one other day during the week.

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would amend the state's Human Rights Law to protect New York residents serving in the military from being discriminated against by employers or landlords, and extends the package of financial benefits to those called to active duty. Among other things, the so-called Patriot Plan would allow them to terminate car leases and extend health insurance. The families of those killed or seriously wounded while fighting in the Persian Gulf or in the war on terrorism would receive full scholarships to the State University of New York or the City University of New York, or equal credit to attend a private college.
Would create create a program to provide health insurance for people in the entertainment industry, including Broadway actors, stagehands and others.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have improved working conditions for farmers by granting them several crucial benefits, ranging from overtime pay to the right to collective bargaining.
Would have billed local governments for half the costs of property-tax breaks offered to businesses in state economic development zones, a savings to the state of about $4 million annually.

Education

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would replace New York City's community school boards with parent councils. The new councils would comprise nine parents elected by parents of children in the district, two community members appointed by the borough president and a nonvoting high school senior appointed by the district superintendent.

Consumer Affairs

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would establish a receipt system for transfer of bodies from funeral directors or undertakers to owners, operators or managers of places of burial, cremations or other final dispositions. Establishing a paper trail for custody of a body will ensure that families know who is responsible for the body at any given time.
Would require those who practice electrolysis to be licensed, and set educational requirements and other regulations to protect customers' health.
Would require beer kegs to be clearly marked with an identification label or tag listing the seller and buyer, allowinglaw enforcement agencies to track down the purchaser of kegs found at parties where underage drinkers are present.

LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have made car-leasing companies immune from lawsuits when leased cars are involved in accidents.
Would have attempted to curb spiraling auto insurance rates by making it harder to commit fraud under the state's no-fault insurance plan.
Would have changed a law regulating kosher food to require that all advertisements identify who certified the product as kosher, as well as other measures.

Environment and Energy

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would increase penalties for tree-stealing from a civil fine of $10 per tree, a standard set in 1909. The proposed law would make it a misdemeanor offense, and increase the penalty to $250 per tree, or three times its market value, or both, at a judge's discretion.
Would allow the construction of a water-filtration plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have refinanced the state Superfund program, which ran out of money for new projects in 2001, and would have created a comprehensive program for the cleanup of abandoned industrial sites known as brownfields.
Would have extended a 1992 state law, known as Article X, that streamlined the approval process for selecting sites for new power plants. The old law, which expired on Jan. 1, created a separate regulatory process for power plants that produce at least 80 megawatts of electricity.
Would have expanded the so-called bottle bill, a law passed in 1982, requiring a nickel deposit on any bottle or can holding carbonated beverages, to include noncarbonated drinks including sports drinks, juices, teas and water. It would also have sent unclaimed deposits, which now stay with the bottling industry, to the state's environmental protection fund, to be used for grants for local governments to defray the cost of recycling.

Health Care and Mental Hygiene

LEGISLATION ENACTED
Prohibits indoor smoking in restaurants, bars and nearly all workplaces across the state under one of the toughest antismoking bans in the country, and closes loopholes in the New York City smoking ban enacted earlier this year.

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would ban over-the-counter sales of the herbal supplement ephedra, fining stores that dispense it without a doctor's prescription up to $500 for each violation. It would make New York only the second state, behind Illinois, to adopt such a ban.
Would require all hospital emergency rooms to provide emergency contraceptives -- high doses of birth control pills that can prevent pregnancy -- to women who have been raped. Many New York hospitals already offer the pills.
Would prohibit the sale of gutka, a sweet chewing tobacco from India, to minors, but allow sale to adults.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have raised sales tax on junk food, video games and DVDs, among other things, to raise money for childhood-obesity-prevention programs.
Would have allowed pharmacies to dispense emergency contraceptives without a doctor's authorization.
Would have tightened regulation of the state's adult homes for the mentally ill.
Would have established a preferred list of drugs that Medicaid patients must use unless they received state permission to use more expensive drugs.

Transportation

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would require a notice posted in every taxicab and livery cab encouraging passengers to buckle their seat belts. Known as Adam's Law, the measure would require that seat belts be clearly visible, accessible and maintained in good working order.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have considered those who ride a motorized two-wheeled device like the Segway Human Transporter be considered pedestrians. That would have meant that the device would not have been considered a motor vehicle and would not have been subject to provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.

Government and Elections

AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would establish a fiscal control board for Buffalo, a boon to the city, in western New York, which has been teetering on the edge of bankruptcy for years.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have required that lobbyists trying to win state contracts disclose the names of their clients and their expenses and compensation to the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying.
Would have instituted a federal voting program intended to overhaul New York's election system for years to come. The Help America Vote Act, which Congress enacted last year, was meant to streamline the nation's election procedures in the wake of the 2000 presidential election. New York's share, about $235 million, would pay for replacing outdated polling machines, training poll workers and setting up a statewide database of registered voters, among other things.
