HEADLINE: An Aging Europe May Find Itself on the Sidelines 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: BAD FUSSING, Germany, June 25 

 BODY:
This spa town in the Bavarian countryside, blessed with natural hot springs with reportedly curative powers, does not resemble Fort Lauderdale or Miami Beach, but it is the rough German equivalent, the place where retirees go for their comfort and well-being.
 But if Bad Fussing is small compared with senior citizens' centers in the United States, it nonetheless represents a big part of the future in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, where a population that is both living longer and producing fewer children is beginning to change some of the fundamentals of both social and political life. 
 The changing demographic picture has produced political uncertainty and crowds of angry demonstrators in European countries whose governments, reacting to the shift from youth to the aged, are moving to reduce social services, including the pensions that millions have been counting on for their golden years. 
"We've only seen the beginning of that," said Wolfgang Lutz, a demographer at the Austrian Academy of Sciences who projects a steep upward curve in the average age of Europeans in the years ahead. 
But while pension reform is the urgent political issue of the moment in Germany, Austria, France and other countries, many experts see it as a harbinger of things to come, a sign of a demographic shift with important implications not only for the welfare of retirees but also for European societies as a whole. The crucial factor is age. 
One study by William Frey, a demographer at the Brookings Institution in Washington, predicts that the median age in the United States in 2050 will be 35.4, only a very slight increase from what it is now. In Europe, by contrast, it is expected to rise to 52.3 from 37.7.
The likely meaning of this "stunning difference," as the British weekly The Economist called the growing demographic disparity between Europe and the United States, is that American power -- economic and military -- will continue to grow relative to Europe's, which will also decline in comparison with other parts of the world like China, India and Latin America.
With its population not only aging but shrinking as well, Europe seems to face two broad possibilities: either it will have to make up the population shortfall by substantial increases in immigration, which would almost surely create new political tensions in countries where anti-immigrant parties have gained strength in recent years, or it will have to accept being older and smaller and therefore, as some have been warning, less influential in world affairs.
"The European countries are aging in a world that is becoming younger," Mr. Frey said in a telephone interview. "And in a global economy, they're not going to share in the energy and vitality that comes with a younger population."
Mr. Lutz, who with Brian C. O'Neill and Sergei Scherbov wrote an article on the subject in Science, agrees that the crucial issue is less a smaller population than an older one.
"There is a fear that just as the world is entering its most competitive stage ever, Europe will be less competitive vis-a-vis the United States and the Asian economies, which are much younger and are benefiting from what you might call a demographic window of opportunity," he said.
The first effect of this has taken the form of efforts by European governments both of the left and of the right to trim the pay-as-you-go pension system, under which the taxes paid by current workers are used to pay the pensions of current retirees. This has produced angry protests. In Austria, which has one of the most generous social welfare systems, workers have staged the first general strikes in that country since the end of World War II. In France, there has been a series of national one-day work stoppages as the conservative government has put forward a proposal that would require workers to stay on the job several more years than at present to be eligible for pensions, which would be smaller.
But some experts are convinced that the reform efforts being proposed, difficult and controversial as they are, will prove inadequate to cope with an aging population.
"In reality, a legal retirement age of 80 is what we should aim at," Erich Streissler, an Austrian economist, wrote in a newspaper article. 
Mr. Streissler's basic argument is one that applies to most of the countries of the European Union: people are retiring well before the official retirement age of 60 to 65, depending on the country.
Across Europe, only 39 percent of men age 55 to 65 still work, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
This means, given the historically low birthrates of "old" Europe, that a decreasing number of young people are paying into pension systems that have to support a larger number of people who, on average, will be in retirement for almost as many years as they worked to earn their pensions in the first place.
Or, as Mr. Streissler put it about his own country, the system works "to give every Austrian the right to retire in midlife with what is internationally a particularly high pension, so that he can waste an ever increasing portion of his lengthening life expectancy in unemployment." 
Here in Bad Fussing, the population trends in Germany are easy to see. Forty years ago, when this village decided to turn itself into a holiday resort, the local population was a grand total of 38, according to Rudolf Weinberger, the spa's director. Now, Mr. Weinberger says, Bad Fussing is the biggest spa in Europe, with 250,000 guests coming each year and a permanent population of 6,400, including 2,400 retirees.
Two other spas in addition to Bad Fussing have sprung up in this area not far from the Austrian border, along with four- and five-story chaletlike hotels, guesthouses, restaurants and shops.
"It's a good life in Germany as a retired person," Gunther Burhenne, 67, said, immersed in an indoor pool at one of Bad Fussing's three elaborate hot-spring bathing complexes. Behind him was a gaudy mosaic of fish and sea anemones. Outside, a crowd did calisthenics while standing waist deep in sulfuric water.
There are many people here like Mr. Burhenne, who had a 34-year career in the German Army, and then worked briefly as a real estate agent before he retired. The guests at Bad Fussing seem far from old and decrepit. They are just a bit beyond middle age and are still vigorous enough to play 18 holes at one of the eight golf courses built near here in the last two decades.
But that is the point about Germany, which, like Austria, is at the leading edge of European population change with its anxieties about the future. People like Mr. Burhenne can enjoy their retirement, but some people here see the national debate about what is called pension reform as a dark cloud on the horizon.
"It will definitely get harder because there are not enough jobs," said Helga Schimpfhauser, 63, reclining on a chaise longue in another part of the spa. "They talk about raising the retirement age, but nobody will hire you after 50 anyway."
Lounging with his wife nearby, a man who would give his name only as Reinhardt was fuming because the spa refused to accept his state health insurance this year and he had to pay the $8 daily entrance fee out of his own pocket. He had not been told that most health insurance programs in Germany removed spa treatments as an automatic benefit last year, though if doctors prescribe such treatment a person is still covered for one visit every three years.
For European governments, there is no alternative to reform, which means lower benefits and higher retirement ages. Austria, despite the labor walkouts, has passed legislation cutting benefits by 10 percent and gradually raising the retirement age to 65 from 60. Similar legislation seems almost certain in France and here in Germany, which has one of Europe's lowest birthrates.
Indeed, Germany's Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth has compiled figures showing just how much the population is changing. The fertility rate itself is 1.34 children per woman, well below the rate of 2.1 said to be needed to maintain a stable population.
The reasons given for this apply throughout the industrialized world: people in highly developed, prosperous societies tend to have fewer children; women postpone childbearing to pursue careers, or forgo having children altogether.
In Germany, among women born in 1950, 14.9 percent of west Germans and 8 percent of east Germans are childless. By comparison, of women born in West Germany in 1965, 31.2 percent are childless along with 26.4 percent of women born in East Germany.
Even more striking are the differences by social strata. Fully 39 percent of the most educated German women are childless, the government's statistics show, compared with under 25 percent for women with less education.
"The more money you make, the greater is the opportunity cost for having children," said Bernd Raffelhuschen, a member of a German governmental commission studying pension reform. 
Projecting the population into the future is difficult because nobody can be sure that the birthrate will not begin to increase, as it has, for example, in recent years in France. Indeed, a higher birthrate, combined with immigration, could significantly halt the trend toward an older and a smaller European population.
Mr. Lutz and his colleagues estimate that one million immigrants a year into Europe would be the same as women having on average one more child. But one million immigrants a year would mean 50 million by 2050, and that alone would be a demographic shift that many Europeans find culturally and politically unacceptable.
In Germany, all government projections show a downward population trend, even after factoring in a high number of immigrants.
But more important in Germany, as in the rest of Europe, is the rapid growth in the numbers of the elderly. In 1950, 30 percent of the German population was under 20 and only about 2 percent was over 80. By 2050, under-20's are expected to be only 16 percent, while the over-80's are estimated to reach about 12 percent.
The consequences of this shift are already striking, Mr. Raffelhuschen said. "At the moment, we really have two working people and one retired person," he said. "In 2035 or so, every worker will support one retired person." 
The solution being recommended by the pension reform commission is to reduce the pension amount from 70 percent of the average national salary to less than 60 percent. 
That is a large drop in a country where 80 percent of pension income comes from the state, but few experts see any hope that this reduction can be avoided.
This is because even if there were to be a sudden increase in the fertility rate, it would take a generation for the additional people being born to enter the work force.
"The only thing that can help a little bit," Mr. Raffelhuschen said, "is age-specific immigration, people 20 or 30 or so, because they would substitute for those who are not being born."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on June 29 about Europe's aging population and its consequences for pensions misstated the percentage of older European men who are employed. According to a report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the figure is 49 percent of men in the organization's European countries, aged 55 to 64, not 39 percent.

HEADLINE: Reeling In Many a Mealon the East River, and Maybe a Risky Mess of PCB's 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Alfredo Castellano stabbed his hook through a hunk of raw fish and cast bait and sinker toward Queens. Then he sat next to his wife, Carmen, their backs to the thigh-high retaining wall separating them from dense traffic on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
 The sun had just dipped behind the housing projects of East Harlem, offering slight relief from the evening swelter. Their 7-year-old son, Giovanni, jumped and giggled, dodging his friend Jasmine, 11, as she swung in a hammock strung between a plane tree and a lamppost. 
 Sure, the Castellanos said, they catch fish from the East River. Maybe two or three times a week, they catch them and eat them. Giovanni does not like fish, but Ms. Castellano allows that she probably ate it when she was pregnant with him.
"I eat them all the time, and I never got sick," she said. "If it was dangerous, there would be signs out here, right?" There are no signs in sight. "It doesn't worry me," she said.
Maybe it should.
The State Health Department regularly publishes advisories warning that because of PCB contamination, most adults should eat fish caught from the East River no more than once a month and should avoid eels entirely. The state says children under 15 should not eat any of the fish, nor should women of child-bearing age, whose bodies can store the toxins and pass them on to their children during pregnancy or while nursing. Similar advisories apply to the waters of the Hudson and Harlem Rivers, New York Harbor, and to many rivers and lakes around the state.
A recent report showed that of more than 200 people interviewed at East Harlem centers for the federal Women, Infants and Children nutrition program, one in 10 ate locally caught fish. The report, by researchers at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, was published this month in the Journal of Urban Health.
"A lot of the people we talked to who were receiving fish from the local water were aware, in some form, of the health advisories," said Laura Bienenfeld, a clinical instructor who was one of the authors of the study. "But that didn't mean they were aware of how it could affect their children, or that they understood how persistent these toxins can be in our bodies and our environment."
The study showed that most people who ate local fish broiled or grilled it, reducing the PCB concentration by melting off the fat that stores the chemicals most readily. Fewer fried it, which would retain the fat and a higher level of PCB's.
On a warm day, especially in the evening, the thin strip of paving stones and grass along the river in East Harlem bristles with fishing rods, and so does the southern edge of Wards Island, a short hike across a pedestrian bridge. Fishermen -- and they are, nearly all of them, men -- crowd every bench and patch of shade, telling stories, drawing on cigarettes, waiting for a tug.
People can be found fishing almost anywhere on the city's many shorelines, but the waterfront alongside East Harlem is one of the busiest, thanks to a combination of economics, geography, culture and misinformation.
Poverty plays a role, of course; pulling a meal from the river is cheaper than buying it at a market, and some anglers earn a few dollars by taking their catch back to the barrio and selling it. And few poor neighborhoods in the city offer as ready access to the water as East Harlem.
Many people talk of fishing as a pastime picked up during childhood in Puerto Rico or in the Dominican Republic. In fact, some say they fish just to fish, and throw back what they catch.
"I'm from Santurce, in Puerto Rico; my father was a fisherman, and I've fished all my life," Ramon Rivera, sitting at the tip of Wards Island, said with a laugh and a shrug. "I don't eat them. I just like to fish. It's what we do."
But many of the people who eat fish from the East River have only a vague comprehension of the peril, or none at all. Polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, were used as insulation in electrical equipment until the 1970's and were dumped into some of the nation's waterways, notably the upper Hudson.
They settled into the underwater silt and were slowly buried over time. The concentrations in the water dropped over the years, but the advisories remain. PCB's are thought to pose a risk of cancer and, with prenatal or early childhood exposure, of developmental disabilities.
"These fish aren't from here, they come from upstate or somewhere, and then they swim over here, so they're safe," one fisherman, Ponce Rome, said, incorrectly.
"We've been eating them for years, me and my wife," he said, showing off his catch for the day, a gorgeous, two-foot striped bass and a 16-inch bluefish with a mouth full of tiny, needle-sharp teeth. "We eat this fish maybe once a week -- more this time of year."
With all the publicity given to PCB's in the Hudson, there is a widespread but mistaken belief that fish from only that river are dangerous.
Jose Santana, sitting under a tree with his 17-month-old daughter, Julia, said he fished on the East River twice a week. He said his wife, Diana, had not eaten local fish when she was pregnant, but had beforehand and while nursing.
"Bluefish I don't worry about -- those are good," he said. "I heard the striped bass could be dangerous, so I usually don't eat those." Other fishermen insisted it was the other way around. In fact, the advisory applies to all species.
A police car rolled slowly up the walk, and the officer behind the wheel said he had heard of the health advisories, though he did not recall the specifics.
"I come by here every day and I tell these people, 'I wouldn't be eating what I catch here,' " he said. "But they keep coming back."

HEADLINE: Closed Since 9/11, a PATH Station Is Set to Reopen Today 

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN WEISER

 BODY:
The PATH station at Exchange Place in Jersey City, closed since the September 2001 terror attack, is set to reopen today, a move that should ease commuting in and out of Manhattan. 
 The train station, which was used by 16,000 commuters daily before the attack, was closed immediately afterward because firefighting efforts at the World Trade Center had flooded the tunnels between Lower Manhattan and New Jersey. 
 To restore service to Exchange Place, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the PATH trains, spent $160 million on track work and other repairs, according to Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority. 
With the closing of the PATH stations at Exchange Place and the World Trade Center, the overall daily ridership of the PATH system fell by 100,000, or almost 40 percent, to 160,000, Mr. Coleman said. Commuter traffic at the PATH stations at Christopher and Ninth Streets in Greenwich Village increased significantly, causing overcrowding. 
Many commuters are expected to resume use of the Exchange Place station, where they can catch ferries into Lower Manhattan. PATH service is expected to be restored at the World Trade Center site in November. 
Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey called the reopening "a significant milestone in the resurgence of the New Jersey-New York economic region," according to prepared remarks he is scheduled to give at a ceremony this morning.
Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham of Jersey City said he was elated by the reopening of the station. 
"This is something that was destroyed," he said yesterday in a telephone interview, "and it's back now. It's open. It's doing what it's supposed to do, and that's going to make it easier to facilitate the rebuilding of the ground zero area."
He noted that many people moved to the area around the station because of its convenience to Manhattan. When the station closed, Mr. Cunningham said, "a significant number of people had begun to relocate, and that will stop." 
A Jersey City police spokesman, Sgt. Edgar Martinez, said use of the station might even increase over pre-Sept. 11 levels because a number of businesses have since moved from Lower Manhattan to Jersey City. The police are prepared for the influx of pedestrian traffic, he said.

HEADLINE: This Land Is Made, Finally, for Chinese Settlers 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY

DATELINE: LOCKE, Calif. 

 BODY:
Look long and hard enough in the dying light of day and it is almost as if ghosts are sitting on the splintered benches and withering balconies along Main Street.
 Connie King says she sees them sometimes. They give her a smile or a knowing nod, the kind that says: We are counting on you, Connie. Do the right thing. 
 "The old Chinese people left a lot of spirits here," said Mrs. King, 80, resting on a bench where she recalled encountering a long-departed neighbor late one evening. "That is maybe one of the reasons that I am living longer, to finish the job." 
Mrs. King feels good about the ghosts of Locke these days. That is because the job she mentioned is almost finished.
What is about to happen here is an extraordinary effort by the county government not only to restore life and health to a crumbling town, but also to right the racist policies of an earlier age, when immigrant Asian laborers were allowed to work the land but forbidden to own it.
For the first time since Chinese immigrants established Locke nearly 90 years ago, on a rented peach orchard tucked behind an earthen levee along the Sacramento River, the land beneath its rickety clapboard and rippled metal buildings is being prepared for sale. Over the coming months, county officials will put together a plan to carve Locke into 50 private lots.
The subdivision will finally undo an anachronistic property-leasing arrangement created under the state's 1913 Alien Land Law, which effectively blocked Chinese immigrants and their children from owning land. The law was part of a wave of legalized discrimination against Asian immigrants that swept across the nation nearly 150 years ago.
"I remember a lot of Chinese people leaving the town over the years, and they would say to me, 'Connie, we never got our land, but you keep trying,' " said Mrs. King, who complains of the usual aches and pains but shows no sign of letting up in her pursuit of that goal.
County officials say that one of the new lots will be sold, for about $5,000, to Mrs. King, who moved here in 1949, when she married her husband, Tommy, who has since died.
In a story typical of the times, the newlyweds had looked up and down the delta for a place to settle, even finding a couple of perfect homes on the river's edge. But they wound up converting a rented garage in Locke, the town where Mr. King had grown up, because the doors to those lovely homes kept closing.
"We saw one little ranch on the side of the road, and we took our checkbook with us," Mrs. King recalled. "I said to my husband, this is the house. We should qualify. But the man inside said, 'I can't sell to you. You are Chinese.' "
The Alien Land Law, which was copied by more than a dozen other states, was struck down in California in 1952. Two states, Florida and New Mexico, still have versions of the statute on their books, although they are not enforced.
"What happened in Locke was subordinate to a larger policy of keeping Asians out of the country, starting with the coolie laws in the 1860's and the laws that assumed all Asian women were prostitutes," said Gabriel J. Chin, a professor of law at the University of Cincinnati. 
As part of the subdivision plan, the Sacramento County Board of Supervisors, which governs the 10 acres on which Locke was built, has asked to have a list made of the people who lived here when the land restrictions were in place. Officials will interview longtime residents like Mrs. King and cull names from census data and other public records.
The board has also created a nonprofit group to run the town, with the instruction to alert Locke's early residents and their relatives on the list when a building or home comes up for sale. Current owners of buildings will have the first opportunity to buy the land, but should any decide to sell, the descendants would be given a chance to match the best offer.
Although the nonprofit group will have the final say, and could settle on a buyer without a Locke connection, the county's intention is to encourage ownership by Asian-Americans with family ties to the town.
"The overriding issue was righting a historic wrong," said Stephen L. Young, director of community development for the Sacramento Housing and Redevelopment Agency.
Even so, some of Locke's 90 or so residents, mostly low-income and not of Chinese descent, have expressed a stronger interest in preserving the present.
Some worry about having to pay property taxes for the first time. Others fear the town might lose its idiosyncratic charm if wealthy outsiders spruce up the old buildings.
The town's biggest property owner, Locke Property Development Inc., a group of investors from Hong Kong, has gone along with the subdivision idea, but not without some different worries. Faced with the overwhelming task of repairing the town's dilapidated sewer system, the investors, who bought the land beneath Locke and several hundred acres of orchards around it in 1977, sold the town's 10 acres to the county last year for $250,000.
Clarence Chu, the company's general manager, said he feared that new investors might avoid Locke because of the uncertainty that would come with the nonprofit group's oversight.
"We need people with some money to help preserve the history of Locke," Mr. Chu said. "The history is more important than pursuing some dream of bringing Chinese people back here."
Even some who support the subdivision plan confess that the redress comes late. Many of those who cared the most about owning land in Locke are dead, or have moved and have no interest in returning.
At one level, some current and former residents said, Asian-Americans have done so well for themselves that they no longer need Locke and all that it represents.
"I would like to see the town preserved, but it is more like a living memorial than a place to live," said Ping Lee, 85, a businessman who moved to nearby Walnut Grove 12 years ago and whose father was a founder of Locke.
Yet as what historians say is the only surviving town in America that was built as a Chinese settlement, Locke carries a burden of history far greater than its four blocks of mostly unkempt buildings would suggest.
Christina Fa, a pediatrician and member of the Chinese American Council of Sacramento, which was an advocate for subdividing Locke, said the town was a symbol for Asian-Americans nationwide.
Even if no former residents returned, Dr. Fa said, the changes being proposed amounted to an important form of restitution by drawing attention to Locke's racist past, and the largely unsung contributions of Chinese laborers in the Sacramento-San Joaquin delta.
"Without them, the delta would still be a swampland and California agriculture wouldn't be nearly as advanced and as much a world player as it is now," Dr. Fa said.
Locke came into being at a time when many Californians felt economically threatened by Chinese immigrants, who had begun arriving in significant numbers in the mid-1800's looking for gold.
By the turn of the 20th century, most of the Chinese had given up on mining and had settled into agriculture, the mainstay of the delta, a flat and mostly fertile expanse of islands between San Francisco and Sacramento protected by a labyrinth of levees built by Chinese laborers.
In 1915, after a fire raced through the Chinatown in Walnut Grove, one of the many delta towns that had a section for Chinese farm workers, some residents from the Zhongshan district of China's Guangdong Province decided to set out on their own.
They looked about a quarter mile up the winding levee road, where the heirs of George Locke, a Sacramento businessman, had inherited several hundred acres of orchards. There was already a wharf and a Chinese store and saloon there.
With the Locke family's permission, the outpost grew into a full-fledged Chinatown, all built on land leased to Chinese tenants to skirt the land law.
Over the years, Locke became well known in the delta for its rowdy gambling halls, clandestine opium dens and abundant bordellos. At its peak, the town's population swelled to more than 1,000.
"What was different about Locke was that it wasn't just a small section of some town that others had founded," said Sucheng Chan, a historian who wrote the foreword to "Bitter Melon" (Heyday Books), an oral history of Locke.
"When people write about the Chinese in the United States, and they focus only on the urban Chinatowns, it gives an incomplete and distorted view of the early history of the Chinese-Americans," Ms. Chan said.
That same early history is what motivates longtime residents like Mrs. King, who is known around town as "Locke Mom."
When the final subdivision plan is approved, perhaps as early as next year, Mrs. King says she expects to see some of the old-timers again.
"Yes, I believe in ghosts," she said, "and I think they are watching and waiting."

From left, Peter, Ruth and Caroline Kiert outside a store.; Connie King hopes to restore the spirit of Locke, a California town settled by Chinese laborers who by law were not allowed to own land. A plan has been developed to sell the land to residents or their descendants. HEADLINE: BASKETBALL; 
Nets' Top Pick Learned To Play in a War Zone

BYLINE:  By LIZ ROBBINS

 BODY:
Zoran Planinic woke up to air-raid sirens when he was 10 years old and followed his mother and older sister downstairs into the basement.
 Living in Mostar, a city in Bosnia-Herzegovina, his family ate from humanitarian aid packages during the war in the Balkans in the early 1990's. 
 For six months they were without electricity. For 10 days, he was without his father, Jozo. The family had made frantic attempts to reach Jozo while he was fighting for Croatia but heard nothing. Then one day, Planinic saw his father through the basement window, walking through the door of the apartment building. 
The war stretched for four years, but its scars are still embedded in Planinic's consciousness at age 20. 
"It was hard," Planinic said Friday, sitting in the lounge bar of the Regency Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. "But we made it somehow."
Shrugging, he added, "That time I have kept to myself; I don't think about it."
He was too young to dream of playing professional basketball when bombs were hitting 50 meters from his apartment building.
"I just wanted to go and fight," he recalled.
He could not imagine that the Nets would select him, a 6-foot-7 point guard, with the 22nd overall pick of the 2003 N.B.A. draft.
"I play basketball to have fun," Planinic said with a smile. "I don't think to play basketball for money. I just want to be good and win. If I think in that way, the money is going to come along."
Planinic (pronounced PLA-ni-nitch) became the first Nets player from Croatia since Drazen Petrovic, who died 10 years ago in a car accident. They both played for Cibona, Croatia's legendary club team. Planinic was given Petrovic's No. 10 when he joined the team in 2001. But the similarities end there.
"When they say, 'Do you play like Drazen?' I say, 'No, there's only one; nobody can compare,' " he said.
Petrovic was a 6-5 shooting guard. Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, and Ed Stefanski, their director of scouting, who saw Planinic play in Croatia, were impressed with his size. But he was not always so big.
"When I was 15 Iwas short, and in one year I grew so much," he said.
He shot up nearly six inches, but he kept the point guard's mentality. 
"Every game, no matter if it is basketball or soccer, I always want to have the ball; I always want to have that control," Planinic said, grinning.
Soccer was his sport until he tried basketball at school with his friends when he was 12. His father, an accomplished soccer player, took him to a tryout for Cibona in Zagreb when he was 16. He joined the team's junior club.
In 2001-2, Planinic was named the best Croatian young player -- despite playing with a stress fracture in his right foot -- and was a member of the under-22 Croatian national team. He helped Cibona win the national championship in 2001 and 2002.
This season, Planinic averaged 7.8 points and 2.8 assists and shot 52.4 percent from the field. 
"What I like about him is his court awareness," said Nets Coach Byron Scott, who watched Planinic in workouts and on videotape. "I love the fact that he's a 6-7 point guard, has a great feel for the game. He's athletic."
The Nets hope to sign Planinic before the Boston summer league begins in mid-July. They are having problems negotiating the release of their first-round pick last year, Nenad Krstic, from his Serbian team, Partizan, but Planinic said he would not have a problem. The Nets will pay a $350,000 fee to bring him to the N.B.A.
For three weeks before the draft, Planinic stayed in an apartment on East 60th Street in Manhattan with three Serbian players who are also represented by his agent, Marc Cornstein: Darko Milicic, the No. 2 pick by Detroit; Alexsandar Pavlovic, the No. 19 pick by Utah; and Slavko Vranes, the Knicks' second-round pick, a 7-6 center.
They became close, going to workouts at John Jay College on 10th Avenue, and eating lunch and dinner together.
"They're all Serbs; I like them," said Planinic, who is comfortable speaking English. "For now, if they need blood, I will give it to them."
He does not like to speak much of the war. His father, now unemployed, was a foreman in an aluminum factory that shut down, Planinic said, because of the war. 
His mother, Milka, is a doctor who specializes in treating breast cancer. His sister, Milena, 26, has finished pharmacy school.
Planinic had never been to the United States before June 5. Since then, he has been to the top of the Empire State Building and witnessed the best in street basketball, the Rucker league in Harlem. "I like the moves," he said, smiling. 
In his first season with the Nets, Planinic will earn $816,900.
"I've never had such money in my hands," he said, noting that he will eagerly transfer some back home. 
It is too soon for Planinic to envision his N.B.A. career. "I'm just in the beginning," he said. "In 10 years, I'll see where I'm going to be."

HEADLINE: Can't Find a Summer Job? Blame All the Layoffs 

BYLINE:  By R.S. FLINN

 BODY:
THE summer of 2002 was supposed to be the last time William Wells Cimarosa of Westport worked on the beach. But a bad economy and a lack of jobs in finance made him sign up again for this summer.
 "Ideally, I would have liked to get out of school and get a job and get a career started," said Mr. Cimarosa, who graduated from college last year. Mr. Cimarosa has worked as a lifeguard at Compo Beach in Westport throughout high school and college until he was promoted to waterfront manager. Unable to find a corporate job, Mr. Cimarosa decided to return to the beach before attending graduate school in the fall at the University of California, San Diego. 
 "I couldn't get a better paying job," he said. "It's like high school again." 
With the national unemployment rate hitting its highest level in nine years in May, at 6.1 percent, coupled with what economists call "a jobless recovery," many high school and college students looking for entry-level positions or internships are facing one of the toughest markets in years, said guidance counselors and career experts. To make matters worse, these youngest workers are competing against adults who have been laid off. Wal-Mart, for example, which just opened a store in Norwalk, said it received more than 5,000 applications for 300 positions, with experienced adults filling some jobs that traditionally would have gone to younger people. 
Connecticut's unemployment rate has risen steadily since the summer of 2000. For the period May through September 2000, the rate averaged 2.18 percent. During the same period in 2002, the rate averaged 4.36 percent. So far this year, the unemployment rate has averaged 5.38 percent.
Stuart McCarthy, director of Parks and Recreation for Westport, said the number of positions the town is filling this summer has stayed the same as previous years. But more college students are returning to positions they held last year and that has meant fewer jobs for high school students.
"The number of applications we are getting is higher than the normal rate," Mr. McCarthy said. "We are seeing a higher number of returning staff. Normally, as kids get toward their junior or senior year in college, they take internships. But as businesses are cutting back on internships these students are looking for jobs as lifeguards," as well as tennis instructors and gate personnel, he said.
Typical summer jobs such as these can be easy to find, said John Tirinzonie, a state labor economist. But getting work from a corporate employer can be difficult.
"Most of the traditional types of jobs that high school students would get into are still out there," Mr. Tirinzonie said. "The Department of Environmental Protection is hiring tons of people for seasonal jobs." These jobs, which are listed on the department's Web site, www.dep.state.ct.us, include lifeguard positions, campground supervisors and first aid attendants.
"Where you run into problems is college graduates," he said. "In the past, they had jobs before they graduated. Now, we're not seeing a lot of hiring. I think a lot of college students are at the point now where they are looking for more permanent careers, but are holding on to temporary positions until they find it."
And that could mean fewer jobs for younger students.
"We may have a situation where high school students who want to work may findit more difficult or not find it at all," he said.
The hiring that is taking place is much more competitive, according to Richard Bayer, chief operating officer of the Five O'Clock Club, a New York-based career coaching and outplacement network.
"We deal with professionals, managers, and executives, and we've had people take jobs in retail," Mr. Bayer said. "We had a $100,000-a-year woman who took a job as a receptionist. And a former president of his own company took a job at the Gap."
These two examples are not exceptions, Mr. Bayer said.
"More senior people are taking junior jobs to pay the bills and get out of the house," he said.
This trend puts college graduates in direct competition with experienced professionals, said Gail Howard, director of Norwalk Community College's Cooperative Education Program. She helps place students in internships.
"Paid internships and entry-level jobs are very competitive," she said. "The problem is, people who were laid off have three, four, five years of experience and are taking those paid internships."
By most standards, Robert Sobelman of Westport is a great candidate for an internship. The high school junior will be the student body president his senior year and had a 3.6 grade point average. But he almost didn't have a job this summer.
"I was rejected by five offices," Mr. Sobelman said. He had applied for internships with senators Joseph I. Lieberman, Christopher J. Dodd, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer, with no luck. He eventually was accepted into an unpaid internship program for Representative Christopher Shays. 
Charles Bassos, president and chief executive of Fairfield County Savings Bank, said that turnover at his bank had slowed. Without open positions to fill, he has watched the number of applications from recent college graduates pile up.
"I've been getting more resumes across my desk than I have in the past five years," Mr. Bassos said, estimating that he has received between 10 to 15 a week. These resumes come from all parts of the country, he said, from college students to vastly experienced people looking to obtain entry-level professional positions.
"People are staying put," Mr. Bassos said. "We haven't hired a recent college grad for some time."
Anand David, director and regional head of campus recruiting in the Americas for UBS, has worked at the company for three years and has noticed a sharp increase in the number of students who attend recruiting events on college campuses.
"There is a huge difference in the level of attendance," Mr. David said. "It's double or triple what we saw three years ago."
The company has hired 1,038 college students this summer for internships, 78 of which are in Stamford. Last year, it had 678 interns and 64 in Stamford.
Robert Reed, store manager for the new Wal-Mart in Norwalk, was surprised by the number of applications the store received. In a five-week period, more than 5,000 applicants turned out at the hiring office. He still receives 50 to 100 applications a day, although the store is fully staffed. Mr. Reed said that high school students have as good a chance as an adult with experience to work at Wal-Mart, but the number of people seeking work made it more difficult.
"We've had so many applicants to go through, we had to pass up a lot of good people," Mr. Reed said. "From people with no experience, to people that made $70,000 to $80,000 a year who are applying for entry-level positions."
Lisa Rivieccio, a Norwalk teacher with the city's School-to-Career Program that pairs students with local businesses, described this summer's job prospects for students as "bleak."
"The market is tight, but not impossible," she said. "It will require more legwork; students will not be able to walk in the door and get hired."
She said that companies had cut back on part-time jobs, usually the positions that students occupy. Compounding the shortage, graduating seniors, who usually give up their School-to-Career jobs to try something different, she said, have kept their positions. That means incoming students to the program have nowhere to go. Fortunately, she said none of the 80 students in the program have lost their jobs due to cutbacks.
According to a national survey of teenagers taken by Junior Achievement, an organization that educates young people about business, economics and free enterprise, 81 percent of teens plan to work this summer, down from 85 percent in 2002 and 86 percent in 2001. Additionally, 30 percent of teens who held a job in the summer of 2002 are somewhat pessimistic about finding a job this summer, while 45 percent are somewhat optimistic.
Bianca Romero, 17, of Westport, has asked all her friends with jobs if they knew of any openings. She has gone up and down Main Street and the Post Road in Westport, asking retail store managers if they would hire her.
"They were basically like, 'We don't think we are hiring,' or 'We're full for the summer,"' Ms. Romero said. Although she worked as a camp counselor for a country club last summer, some stores seemed to turn her away because she did not have experience in retail.
"If I can't find a job, I'll will try to baby sit a lot," Ms. Romero said. "I need something to take up time this summer. I am also trying to save up for spring break, because my mom won't pay for it."
Terrance Carter, 17, lives in Hartford and was looking forward to working another summer as a program assistant for ConnectiKids, a nonprofit community organization that tutors children. But Mr. Carter said he was told the group was not hiring program assistants this year.
After trying to find a job at a clothing store without any success, Mr. Carter is trying to find work elsewhere.
"Now I'll take anything," Mr. Carter said. "I never had this problem before. I've had a job since I was 14. I don't know what I'll do."

HEADLINE: The Rains of June Have Left Behind Soaked Businesses 

BYLINE:  By JAMES LOMUSCIO

 BODY:
LAST week's sun did little to console Joseph Romeo, owner of Joey's by the Shore, a waterfront restaurant at Compo Beach in Westport.
 "It's too soon to tell if a few days of sun will make a difference," said Mr. Romeo, whose business has been down 70 percent since Memorial Day. "It would be nice if the sun came out on a weekend, but right now next weekend isn't looking too good either. I don't even want to look at the forecast anymore. It's been a bad year." 
 How bad? His restaurant, usually sand strewn by a procession of barefoot bathers, was mostly a haven this month for joggers or bored lifeguards looking to keep dry. 
"I cannot in my memory think of a worse, wetter beginning of the summer," said Mr. Romeo, who has operated the town concession for 14 years. "Our only hope is a good July and August."
His sentiments were shared by other weather-dependent businesses around the state, as Connecticut, like the rest of the Northeast, has been pummeled by continual rains, unseasonably cool temperatures and gray skies that have created a feeling of dusk throughout the day. And with Memorial Day and virtually all subsequent weekends a washout, everyone from carnival workers to landscapers to state park officials to clammers to outdoor events planners are cautious when it comes to a sunny outlook. A few searing days last week were a help, but businesses said they will need a lot more. Even diehard golfers who quip that it never rains on a golf course have reached their saturation point.
"People are just getting tired of playing in the rain," said Christopher Fellows, assistant manager of the D. Fairchild Wheeler Golf Course, a municipal course that straddles Fairfield and Bridgeport. "I'd say 19 out of 24 weekends so far this year had either rain or snow, and we lost at least 25 percent in business, and 25 percent is conservative." He said business was down about $50,000 from last year.Fred V. Carstensen, director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, said that although it will take at least a year to calculate the amount of revenue lost to the rain, he estimates that businesses that are "critically dependent on the weather have lost between 40 to 70 percent of their business." And, he said, that money is mostly gone and can't be made up later.
"Even if we had perfect weather over the next three months, they would only recover part of that revenue," he said.
Charles Ziegler, owner of the Peppertree Campground in Eastford, said the rain had driven away a lot of his business.
"It's not good, and they're looking for more rain this weekend," said Mr. Ziegler, whose camp operates from mid-April through mid-October. "Business is down 50 percent as far as weekend camping goes."
Mr. Ziegler added that if it were not for the campers who had previously booked sites for the entire season, "I'd really be in trouble."
"And some of the seasonals don't even come when the weather's bad," he said. "They stay home because when it rains, there's nothing much to do but sit in your camper, and we don't have cable. I'm still not booked for the Fourth of July. I think they're going to wait until the last minute."
Throughout the state, it rained 16 days from June 1 to 22. With thunderstorms predicted for this weekend, "We certainly have a pretty good shot of breaking the record," said Keith L. Eggleston, climatologist for the Northeast Regional Climate Center at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y. Connecticut's June record was set in 1998 in the town of Windsor Locks, he said, when it rained 20 days that month. Connecticut's June average for the number of days with measurable rainfall is 11. Measurable rainfall is defined as any amount of precipitation more than one-one-hundredth of an inch. As of last Monday, 6.17 inches of rain was recorded to have fallen in the state in June. The record is 13.6, set in 1982.
"This year there's no one cause that we can point to for the rain," said Mr. Eggleston. "It's just a very persistent weather pattern we're in. And we can't blame this one on El Nino."
Nonetheless, the persistent rainfall has sprouted questions as to the cause. At tented graduation ceremonies, rained-out pool parties and barbecues moved indoors, speculation has ranged from whether the rain might be attributed to philosophical queries of whether it can all be traced to a butterfly flapping its wings in Brazil to a volcano acting up somewhere. Actually, the volcano theory isn't so far-fetched. In 1816, the so-called "year without summer," June frosts blanketed the state's farms, decimating crops, while snow fell in New Hampshire, a meteorological anomaly that has been attributed to the eruption of the Mount Tambora volcano in Indonesia.
While this year's weather peculiarities do not even come close to that experience, the rainfall has dealt a harsh blow to a number of industries, shellfishing in particular. The State Department of Agriculture's policy is to shut down some shellfish beds for seven days after a half-inch of rain. With the season's unyielding rain, all shellfish beds have been closed for an unprecedented 10 weeks from Greenwich to Fairfield. Lori Remick, who heads the Connecticut Department of Agriculture Bureau of Aquaculture in Milford, said the bans were due to high fecal coliform counts caused by sewage bypass overflows, plus fertilizers and feral animal waste washed into streams and tributaries that empty into Long Island Sound.
"In the 14 years I've been here it's been the longest wet spell we've had," she said, adding that even in coastal communities from West Haven through Branford, where a one-inch rain results in a shellfish ban, beds have been closed "most of the time."
Leslie Miklovich, co-owner of Hillard Bloom Shellfish in Norwalk, a subsidiary of Tallmadge Brothers, an oystering company in operation since 1875, said the bed closures had forced the company's clammers to move farther out into the Sound, "but when the wind blows, it's dangerous out there."
Also, she said, clams are fetching lower prices, "because the demand isn't there since mostplaces that sell shellfish are along the beach, and people aren't going out."
Some tourist destinations have also seen a sharp decline in business.
"People aren't motivated," said Peter Glankoff, a spokesman for Mystic Seaport. "Our pre-season analysis told us we would be up because of a revival in understanding the American experience. But mom and dad think twice when they get the weather report."
Mr. Glankoff said that every Memorial Day weekend the Mystic Rotary Club sponsors Lobster Fest at the museum, which usually generates 90 percent of the Rotary's annual funds for charitable giving. 
"This year they collected about one-third of that revenue, because people just tended to write the weekend off," Mr. Glankoff said. "And the people I see here appear to be depressed by this rain. This has been a tough year with the war and the economy and still thinking about 9-11. People want a diversion, they want a fun experience, and it's being thwarted by the weather."
Amusement parks and carnivals have also not fared well.
"You're basically licking your battle wounds right now in this industry," said Ronald P. Gustafson, director of communications for Quassy Amusement Park in Middlebury. "This year we had so many events scheduled, and so many events we had to cancel."
"When we look at it, we lost virtually all the major weekend days and nearly all of June," he added. "And today we're sweating bullets again because we have a laser show running Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday."
Founded in 1908, Quassy has been owned by the Frantzis family since 1937, "and they said this is the worst spring season they can recall," Mr. Gustafson said. "You can count the good days on one hand."
A major addition to Quassy this year is a water theme park ironically named Saturation Station. BTo date it has had only one full day of operation. Though a number of the parks ride's can operate in a light rain, Mr. Gustafson added, they often stop with a heavy downpour or the slightest rumble of thunder. Even the park's small railroad stops running because the trains slide when the tracks are wet, he said.
The bad weather also could not have come at a worse time for the state government, already reeling from a budget deficit. Last year the state took in $4 million at the gates of state parks that charge admission. This season, even with a $2 admission increase to $9 and $14 for state residents and nonresidents, respectively, Pamela Adams, director of Connecticut's 95 state parks, conceded, "We won't even come close."
"By and large the facilities have been empty with the exception of wildlife, though we do have people who come in and jog in bad weather," Ms. Adams said. "There are no specific numbers now, but we know that we are extremely low."
Even landscapers and lawn service workers who have had more grass to cut are feeling the weight of the rain, literally. Joseph Keller, who owns Garden of Ideas in Ridgefield, said that balled-and-bagged shrubs and trees were heavier with water and more difficult to lift to plant.
"When it's too wet out there it slows things up, because there's mud everywhere, and it's depressing," Mr. Keller said. "The lawn service people are very busy because the grass keeps growing, but even they can't go out if it's too bad."
Mr. Eggleston of the Northeast Regional Climate Center did offer some hope for the rest of the summer. With this past week's temperatures in the upper 80's and 90's punctuated by a few showers and a thunderstorm, he said the weather was beginning to show signs of a more typical summer pattern.
"I'm at least hoping so," Mr. Eggleston said. "The odds are in favor of us getting back into a more summer-like weather pattern. If I had to place a bet, that's the way I'd go."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
Katonah-Lewisboro Offers Revised Budget to Voters

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: CROSS RIVER 

 BODY:
ONE of the big reasons people move to Westchester is its generally strong public school systems. So it's not surprising that voters in all but two of the county's school districts passed their school budgets on June 3. What is surprising is that the two districts that rejected budgets, Katonah-Lewisboro and Valhalla, are far from being troubled districts, and in fact have solid academic reputations. The rejections are perhaps even more surprising given that statewide, 94 percent of the school districts passed their budgets successfully, despite the difficult economy. And Valhalla passed its budget on the second try last Tuesday.The budget defeat in Katonah-Lewisboro reflects a number of issues in a complex , far-flung set of diverse communities, with somewhat attenuated ties to the school district as a whole, people in the district say. The 4,200-student district covers 54 square miles, encompassing Katonah as well as hamlets like Vista, South Salem and Cross River. The district is economically diverse, with lavish weekend homes, modest cottages as well as new houses that sell for $825,000 in recently built housing developments. It can take a half-hour to drive from one end of the district to the other.
 Don Scott, president of the Katonah-Lewisboro school district board of trustees, pointed out that the budget lost by 168 votes, with 2,224 no votes and 2,056 yes votes. 
 "It's been a highly charged environment here for the last two to three years," he said. "There's a schism between those with kids in the school, and those without kids."
While 55 percent of the district's residents don't have children in the schools, some would suggest that the situation is more subtle than the simple division between parents of schoolchildren and others. 
"There are people who tried to send a message that times are hard," said Dr. Robert Lichtenfeld, district superintendent. In Westchester school budgets typically are the only budgets taxpayers vote on directly. The first budget called for $78.3 million in spending. The revised budget, which will be presented for a vote tomorrow is $700,000 lower, coming in at $77.5 million, which reflects a 7 percent increase in budget-to-budget spending. Steps to reduce expenses include eliminating some staff positions at the alternative high school and in kindergarten, eliminating stipends for teachers who coordinate the curriculum and reducing spending on supplies.
Under state law, a second defeat would mean that the district would have to adopt an austerity budget, with any increased spending restricted to no more than 1.9 percent above the current budget. There would also be cutbacks on academic classes, extracurricular activities and other programs. Class size would increase, with some sections rising to 30 students from 24.
Despite its initial vote, Valhalla escaped the austerity budget. The original Valhalla budget for 2003-2004 called for $29,292,556, representing an 8.7 percent increase. It was rejected with 964 no votes cast and 928 yes votes. The Valhalla budget that passed Tuesday calls for an 8.1 percent increase in spending, with a total expenditure of $29,130,956. The revised vote was approved by a vote of 988 yes votes, with 663 no votes. The 16 paper ballots had not been counted as of press time 
In Katonah-Lewisboro, Mr. Scott said: "I don't think it's about money. Lewisboro is among the lowest tax increases in the county, at 4 percent, and it's the lowest tax increase for Lewisboro in 10 years." A series of fliers prepared by a grass-roots group called Citizens for Prudent School Planning, which campaigned to defeat the first budget, as well as some letters to the editor that appeared in the local papers, suggest that there are other reasons. Some cite the superintendent's contract, which calls for a yearly increase of 9 percent for the next three years, although the actual salary, $179,000, still places Dr. Lichtenfeld in the middle of the county's superintendent pay scale. Others contend that the recent teacher contracts caused disgruntlement. Even the cancellation of the eighth-grade trip to Washington has been cited as a reason.
Particularly pointed have been criticisms of the school board (a board, it should be noted, where there has been high turnover). 
"There's a complex history of mistrust, and a feeling we haven't been listened to," said Nancy Euchner, a mother of three sons, one of whom is in a district kindergarten, and whose two older sons are in private schools. A former PTA district leader, she opposed the initial budget. "It's deeper than the recent budget," she said, citing salaries as a big issue for her. "My feelings have intensified this year. The raises to the superintendent and teachers are out of sync with the raises that working members of the community receive."
Some of the blame, said Mr. Scott, could perhaps be attributed to what he termed "referendum exhaustion." 
Since 1995, the community has been asked to vote on a $44 million construction bond, which passed; a $50 million building referendum, in January 2002, which failed; a revised $28 million construction bond, which passed in June 2002; and a $1.2 million referendum, in November of last year, to acquire nine acres of property for playing fields, which was rejected.For parents who moved to the district for the schools, the initial defeat has been discouraging.
"We were very troubled that it was voted down," said John Metaxas, a Katonah resident and father of two children in elementary school who attended a public meeting on Monday at which the revised budget was presented. "I came here to show support for the budget."
Others in the community have been just as perturbed by the tenor of the disagreement surrounding the budget.
And it's gotten nasty at times.
"Any of the pro signs get torn down," said Eve Hundt, a parent of two children in the Katonah-Lewisboro schools who has been active in organizing the Committee to Pass the Budget. A pro-bond sign that she put up one morning before driving her children to school, was torn down by the time she returned home an hour later, she said.
"The area gets blanketed with 'no' signs," she said. "The opposition group has been getting out the message that 'you can't trust the school board,' that 'we're paying too much in taxes.' What's missing is how are we doing in comparison with the rest of the county." During the past decade, the district's enrollment has grown by 60 percent. Districts all over the county are struggling with expanding enrollments, passing bond issues for new construction and experiencing class size increases that leave the schools groaning at the seams. 
So far, the budget skirmishes haven't affected property values. "In general,people move here for our schools, " said Laurel Genovese, a licensed sales agent for Houlihan-Lawrence in South Salem and the mother of two children in the district. "Fifty percent of the moves I handle are within the district." 
Despite the initial defeat, people like Ms. Hundt say the news is not all bad. "The silver lining to the budget defeat is that it's brought an outpouring of support among parents that value the school system, the reputation and what the district has to offer," she said.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Goodbye, Mr. Budget

BYLINE:  By WENDY GINSBERG

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
EVERY June, there is a little more sweat on everyone's brow here. It's not the weather -- the State House is air-conditioned. It's more a numbers thing.
 By July 1, the state constitution requires New Jersey's legislators to pass a budget for the next fiscal year. June is invariably a month of arduous partisan squabbles over what to do with surpluses or, worse, how to dig out of deficits. To resolve their differences, for the last 11 years both Republicans and Democrats have relied on one man: Alan R. Kooney, the state's chief financial adviser to the Legislature. 
 Mr. Kooney works for the Office of Legislative Services, a nonpartisan group of state employees who aid lawmakers by drafting their bills, offering legal advice and, of course, helping with the budget. 
As he explains the intricacies of the budget to legislators and prods them through the budget hearing process, Mr. Kooney adds welcome portions of dry wit and attention to detail.
"There are 120 legislators who are bombarded every day with information, misinformation and general static from every direction," Mr. Kooney, a resident of Hopewell Township, said. "It used to be said, back when I started, that legislative bodies suffered from a dearth of information. But in fact, these days the opposite is true; they suffer from an overload of information. And one of the functions that our office provides is essentially to help synthesize a lot of the volume of information down there."
Tomorrow, when the Senate and the Assembly hope to be passing a budget for the fiscal year 2004, Mr. Kooney, 58, will be on the job. But Tuesday is his first day of retirement, a result of having accepted an early-retirement package offered by the government.
Even Mr. Kooney's final act as a civil servant -- retirement -- will serve to help balance the budget he has spent years deciphering.
"He's a great loss," said Corina Eckl, who works for the National Conference of State Legislators and has known Mr. Kooney for more than 20 years. "He has a subtle and unique sense of humor."
Ms. Eckl should know. She once designed a survey for legislative employees that Mr. Kooney found so irritating he accused her of helping write the federal income tax forms.
He laughs about it himself when he talks about his current duties as the state's top number cruncher.
"I was an economics major until I got to the classes that required a lot of math, and then I realized that I was never going to make it as an economist," he said about his days at George Washington University in Washington. "That's funny considering I use numbers all the time. But the numbers I use are pretty much limited to the four functions you can do on a calcluator. In fact, I think I still use the same pocket calculator I was using 10 years ago."
Mr. Kooney left his hometown of Arlington, Va., in 1971 to take a job in New Jersey's government in a move he calls a "historical accident." In his first job, which paid $12,000 a year, he worked in the state Office of Fiscal Affairs evaluating government programs to determine their effectiveness.
Steadily climbing the ranks of the civil-service bureaucracy, Mr. Kooney took his current position in 1992.
Though he works comfortably scrutinizing the finances of the entire state, he still won't attempt to balance his checkbook at home, a task that he leaves to his wife, Sharon. "The money seems so much more real there," he said.
The public and even a lot of people in state government generally pay attention to the state budget in January when it a proposal is introduced by the governor, and then again in June and early July when it goes through the Legislature.
But Mr. Kooney insists that budgeting is a yearlong process. "This budget is almost being seen in historical perspective already because planning for the next budget has already started," he said. "There's a time synchronization going on. If you're a real budgeter, it's already being looked at a year in the future."
Though Mr. Kooney says he is not a numbers wiz, his colleagues say that his ability to dissect the budget is unparalleled.
"The great thing is that he made us a great equalizer with the executive branch, regardless of who was in power," said Senator Wayne Bryant, a Democrat from Camden who is co-chairman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee. "We could compete with them because we had Alan Kooney. We realized that when he came and he gave us information it was right and it was on the mark."
Mr. Kooney said that Senator Robert E. Littell, the Republican who is the other co-chairman of the Senate budgeting committee, would always ask him to condense the main points about the budget so they fit one small index card.
"It used to cause us some consternation," Mr. Kooney said. "But the point he was trying to get to was that you can boil this down in a way that doesn't bias it, and tells them what they need to know and what the decisions are that they need to make."
This budget year has been a nonstop partisan battle. Since Governor McGreevey introduced his proposal, advocates from every conceivable constituency have streamed to the State House to protest and offer their advice.
"Governor McGreevey is basically attempting to ration what have become very scarce state resources," Mr. Kooney said. "And the result is you get demonstrations and you get a lot of activity from people who feel aggrieved by the process. It makes budgeting difficult. If you've seen enough budgets, it's hard to say too many of them are unique. When you gain a perspective over the years, you tend to see there's a fairly regular pattern to it, and a fairly regular way in which disagreements get reconciled."
Mr. Kooney said he was almost certain that Republicans and Democrats would figure out a way to approve a budget by their deadline.
Governor McGreevey is less sure. He has threatened a government shutdown on Tuesday if the budget does not pass.
"You can tend to see this thing in terms of a self-contained mechanism and forget that fact that the budget is sort of this big sloppy clumsy plan," Mr. Kooney said. "It is organic. That's one of the reasons I said it goes on all year round. We don't enact the budget on July 1 and it just sort of sits there as some magisterial document. There are changes being made to it constantly. People think there's an extraordinary precision to this thing. But I can assure you, the budget is dynamic and it's an unruly and unwieldy process."
Last Monday, during a busy last week of work on the budget, Senator Bryant, the co-sponsor of a resolution honoring Mr. Kooney for his service to the state, took nearly 15 minutes during the Senate session to thank his departing colleague.
"You treated all of us in a very bipartisan way, and you absolutely made all of us look better," he said to Mr. Kooney in a speech on the Senate floor. "You never took the glory for it. Your ability to help us navigate and at the same in same time in a nice way chastise us when we were going overboard is endearing."
No one has been tapped to succeed Mr. Kooney. Legislators must appoint a bipartisan board to conduct interviews with candidates for the job. Albert Parroni, executive director of the Office of Legislative Services, said he would appoint a temporary successor until a permanent one is found. He hopes to have everything sorted out by the end of the summer.
Though Mr. Kooney has no specific plan for his retirement, he does plan to improve his tennis game and spend more time with his wife. He said he thought a message he got in a fortune cookie last week was a telling prophecy: "Sometimes travel to new places leads to great transformation."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan R. Kooney, the chief financial adviser to the Legislature, outside the State House in Trenton. As of July 1, he'll be retired. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Solution To Health Care Crisis 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "The Rising Price of Getting Well" (June 22) failed, as do many other articles about health-care issues, to distinguish between "cost" and "price." 
The cost of health care is related to its fundamental value as determined by the immutable forces of an aging population in an advanced technocratic society. Over time, the cost of care must increase. 
 But the price of care is determined in the health-care marketplace and is arbitrarily related to the system's need for economic viability and desire for profit. Cost of care is largely predetermined and unchangeable while the price we pay is a marketplace phenomenon. 
 The paradox is that while competition in the managed care industry may lower the price of health care, it can do so only for a limited time because the cost of care continues to climb. If H.M.O.'s don't acknowledge this basic truth they go out of business.
 Further, competition between health systems in a closed market actually accelerates the increase in cost of care because of the unnecessary reduplication of providers, technology and institutions. Competing systems may temporarily decrease prices but they increase the cost of care in the long run.
 What is glaringly apparent is that our employment-based system of managed health care is an untenable paradox of open enrollment and restricted service that increasingly fails to provide us the health-care safety net enjoyed by the rest of the industrialized world.

Lawrence A. Danto, M.D.
Truckee, Calif.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter
